I've tried to enjoy this game quite a lot, but I find it to be more frustrating than what I find it to be fun. I still haven't beaten the game so I might change my review when I do.

Here's some things I enjoyed and things I didn't enjoy:
First of, I think that the fights with the combine soldiers aren't fun. They're mostly annoying and not very entertaining. They fell quite slow and sloppy. The fights with zombies and other Xen-enemies are quite fun however.

Looting and exploring the environment is fun, but eventually gets boring. In the beginning it's very fun looting, exploring, and interacting with the environment in other ways. Such as breaking bottles, throwing around chairs and other objects for example. I think that that makes the game quite fun. But, it eventually gets old and not as fun.

Puzzles aren't fun. I don't like all those environmental "puzzles" where you have to do something slightly tricky to proceed. They're slightly fun when you get the "aha!" feeling. But it doesn't make up for the fact that I found it more annoying than what I found it fun. The hacking and looting doesn't feel rewarding enough either in my opinion.

In conclusion, I just found it more annoying and frustrating than what I found it fun. But, I still haven't beaten it yet, so I might change it later on. I would give it a 4,5/10 right now.

It's a fun game, and the VR aspect adds more immersion to the game. Great story and characters. Wish we could have a sequel to Half Life 2, but I'll take this prequel. In fact, the only reason I got VR was for this specific game, and I don't regret it. 

Valve does a good job of designing a movement system that mitigates nausea. "Teleportation" and snap-turns mitigates the risk of nausea to basically zero. I had no problems playing this game with this option turned on.

Playing on VR does make the game more challenging. You would think moving around and shooting would be more intuitive with VR, but it's the opposite. Movement, especially if you are trying to shoot at the same time, is waaay more difficult with VR. But this is not a criticism of the game itself, just of VR in general.

If you've already got a VR headset, I highly recommend this game. If you don't already have a VR headset, and you if have more money than you know what to do with, go ahead and buy the VR headset just for this game. If you're on a tight budget, save your money for something more important than a video game. VR just doesn't add enough to the experience to make the cost worth it, and it comes with significant drawbacks. Again, this is not a criticism of the game itself, but it's important to point out the flaws of VR to prospective VR players.

One of THE best VR games I've experienced.

[b] Played via NoVR Mod [/b]

[h2] “Xen Garden” [/h2]
- It’s full fledge Half Life experience in franchise and it’s a crime its hostage of being “killer app” for VR. Source 2 is cool, visually it’s great, absence of RTX is not a problem when you have top-notch environment artist team, alien flora of Xen from Black Mesa feels amateurish and lame in comparison with new Valve version.

- Its good they crossed the line of being afraid working on HL franchise, and rewriting whole story with old/original writer’s was right call as its (story) and banter between Alex end Russell are highlights of the game, rare display of cool dialogs from west company when there no activists in writing room.

[h2]“Blast From the Past”[/h2]
- I personally now don’t get notion that Valve will only make HL game if it will be breakthrough in gameplay innovation, is HLA have innovation’s ? Not playing VR version I may speculate, yes of course, but only for VR space in way classic gameplay interactions converted in meaningful and smooth way to became golden standard for VR. 

- Playing “Flat” version its clear there are zero innovation in Actual gameplay, the same old tricks and pieces from 20+ history of linear single player games, 1 type of 3D puzzle that works as intended only in VR is not an argument, downgrade into pixel hunt for ammo across environments and serious downgrade for weapons because VR have its own limitations. My personal position that they already made just great HL game without actual innovations and VR conversion is on sideway relevant only for future of VR as platform.

[h2]“I Hate You Jeff”[/h2]
- Also on the note of poking HLA’s gameplay with the stick, I think horror masters Frictional Games in its SOMA (2015) already said ALL about “eight shape loop” design where you can’t kill monster/s and only have to avoid it. Putting player as squirrel in the loop for whole chapter and not giving option to kill/stale bugger with weapons is Lame in 2020+ in my opinion.

[h2]“Textbook Jinxing”[/h2]
- How good NoVRMod ? It’s Good enough for full play through if you not afraid bugs and not perfect hand animations. Serious bugs appear after around one third of play through, just not be afraid of using no clip for flying through walls, I got around 7 critical walkthrough blockers (usually broken scripts), so it needed around 4 no clip fly’s and 3 reloaded checkpoints to progress. Also some hand animations and how animation are blended at the moment can be janky or buggy, and I assume some hand interaction can be completely absent, so in general I would say it (Mod) may be still cooking in oven for a year to a polished state.

[h2] “Crustacean Frustration”[/h2]
- Also there was claim that it is too easy in “flat” variant so I was expecting walking simulator experience, and oh, boy how it is wrong. I don’t know, maybe mod team made already rebalance but I had literally at least 4 situations where I was at edge of no ammo, and there is no melee at all…, so no ammo can mean you’re done, game over man. Sometimes it was proper horror survival experience that I initially didn’t sign up for. In conclusion, I don’t think there is need for any difficulty mods from workshop.

[h2]“On a Roll”[/h2]
- Its definitely worth playing, in age of live services no one asked for, good old-school single player experiences are rare, even if it’s in some places inferior modded version, there is no reason to wait if you want to, except mod became even better.

[b] PS [/b]

- For those who remember how HL2 EP2 ends, end of the HLA story hypes everything to the moon, they’d better not to cancel HLX (2026?), after such reinvigoration of fan base.

- Looking on ultra-cool sci-fi designs of combine soldiers, I see a ton of cosmetics for micro-transactions in upcoming Neon Prime (2025?)

Edit/Note: If you think you are going to be sick from VR, you are wrong. There is a MASSIVE difference between watching footage shot through a single eye of VR (which is what the game puts on your monitor for someone other than you to see) and actually being in the game playing. Can you get sick? Sure, but this only tends to happen when your eyes and brain are out of sync with the content coming into them. If you push on, and ignore your body, you will pay heavily. If you are on the fence, I suggest going to a local VR gaming center if you have one nearby and ask to play this game. I think you will be really surprised at the results. The game needs to be played using VR and not the mod. The mod cuts out VR content you cannot emulate, so you miss out on stuff. 

Give this a try before you just think you are not able to play the game in VR. The tech has come so far in the last few years; the displays are high-refresh with tiny pixels. This gives your brain a far more realistic view to the content you are watching/playing. 

If you are new to VR, the HL or HL2 story, or know zero about anything, you will find things to love about this title and the story within. 

Pros:
[X] Story Telling is on Point! You will come to love the banter on the radio between Russell and Alyx or some of the other people or beings you meet along the way. You don't need to skip cut-scenes or storytelling here. 

[X] Price: Worth Every Penny - No need to wait for this to be on sale. You are getting a game that expands on HL2 in ways you will love and you can learn about things that happened prior to other folks joining the game's story. If you do not have a VR headset, watch someone play the game just to see what the story is!

[X] Controls: Super Well Done VR Controls - No Gripes Here!

[X] Motion Sickness: This game will not make you sick with movement and the best type of motion is using the left control stick to move you and the right to snap-turn. Suggest 15-degree snap setting for more control.

Cons:

{] I honestly do not have MAJOR concerns, but since VR headsets are still making jumps in their per-eye resolution, I would love to see higher-res texture packs and native ray tracing in the game. This is just because I have a computer that has no issues running on max settings and at 90Hz. Pay to play baby.

One of the best games I have ever played. Half-Life: Alyx was my first VR title experience. If anyone just picked up a meta quest 3 like I did, I highly recommend this game as your first introduction to VR. The story, the immersion, the combat, everything is top tier. I was hooked the entire experience. It was not something I wanted to rush through at all. I took my time to admire all the environments and search the hidden areas looking for extra loot. It has been so long since I have taken the time to play through an entire game. I found myself looking forward to go home and hop back into the Half-Life: Alyx story. I truly have not felt this way about a game since I was a kid. I love how the game is somewhat physically demanding you to crouch and even to get entirely prone to move through certain obstacles. The combat is super immersive as well. Having to utilize cover and maneuver through fire fights was a great experience. This game is a great blend between semi-horror themes (head crab guys), shooting rounds at fascist-like soldiers and solving unique and creative puzzles. The weapon customization and upgrades are awesome as well. Taking the time to find extra resin really pays off when you have your favorite weapon completely decked out, mine simply being the pistol. The only part of the game that I disliked was the part where you encounter Jeff. In retrospect I understand why this part was thrown in since it forces you to take your time to really figure out how to get out of the situation you're in. Overall this is one of my favorite games I have ever played. I love the fact that valve has no pressure to release Half-Life 3 and would happily wait 5+ years for the release. Its clear that they truly take their time with this masterpiece of a series and I can not wait to someday finally take a crowbar to the G-Mans face (:

I do personally have a large bias towards the weaponry as if a game has a pistol in it, i try to use it for as long as possible. I really do enjoy using pistols in games and this game doesn’t disappoint me in that.

Graphics imo aged really well, after me following several vr game releases came out after hl:a, i think alyx aged the best out of them all, then again i am waiting for the new metro vr title to ship, as it looks like something half life alyx graphically, or even better.

Only two issues i have with hl:a is some of the weird bugs it has, like my hands not showing up due to me using quest 2 controllers. And the lack of the promised sdk for the game.. shame it never released..

Either way, must have game if you own a VR headset and are a large valve fan like me.

Half Life Alyx is the best VR game I've played so far. It totally redefines what VR can and should be like. Controls are very intuitive and realistic, immersion is great, optimization is great, graphics are great. 10/10.

And story-wise (no spoiler), that's a great missing piece that happens in between Half Life 1 and Half Life 2. You'll get to know more of Alyx's, Elie, Freeman and some more. However, as usual with Half Life, it raises as many questions as it answers. Still want HL3.

Side note regarding VR: No need for a Valve Index or PCVR only headset in order to play it, you can have a great experience with standalone devices that do PCVR, like a relatively cheap Pico 4 (the one I have) or a Quest 2 or 3. Though you might consider using Virtual Desktop for a better experience (and make sure your wifi is great otherwise you'll have disconnects from time to time).

If I had to come up with some complaints, outside of the frustrating limitations of VR in the current year (I want to run around and jump freely and not worry about my headset or the room I'm in, damn it), I'd say the game doesn't go hard enough with the difficulty. Once you get used to the gun reloading mechanics and movement, this game becomes mostly very easy, Even on the hard difficulty. I frequently found myself with excess healing items and the like, and the combat encounters were either a snooze fest, or a frustrating instakill fest. For some reason, dying in VR is way more frustrating than dying in front of a screen with a mouse and keyboard. The long long load times after every death don't help.

But this is getting too negative. Overall, this is one of the best games I've played in a long time, VR or no, and I wish more people could play it and see how incredible it is. If you have VR and are trying to decide whether to buy it, holy crap what are you waiting for, get it now!

This is it. This is the standard against which every single VR title will be measured. Valve's return to Half-Life comes via this game, Half-Life: Alyx, a VR-only experience. The combat, despite requiring the use of teleportation, feels so fluid. The reloading, the item acquisition, it all feels so flawless and smooth. Add to that the dense, rich atmosphere and unparalleled artistic beauty of the world, and you're looking at one of the best games ever made, not just the best VR game.
This is as close to perfection as possible. Any complaints I have would be minor or overly anal. It's a solid 10 out of 10. I hope this helps move the medium forward!

I mean, It's what we get until EP3. The environments and overall design is top notch, it looks great and feels intuitive. It gives me great hope for what valve can do in the VR space in the future. I will say though, in all my years playing VR this is the only game that has made me almost puke. There's just something about the movement, or environments or something that just doesn't agree with my stomach after a while. My guess is that it has a little to do with the scale of objects, which feels overall some of the best I've seen but can still be a bit wonky. 

The gameplay, from exploration to combat to cinematic moments feels really great. There are only a couple parts, mostly later in the game, that get a bit frustrating and feel a little dumb. But the game does a good job of introducing new enemies, hazards, and ramping up the intensity as things go on. The game also strikes an interesting balance between survival horror and action at times, with you being forced to think quickly and conserve ammo to survive.

I decided back in 2020 that until I got a VR headset and could play the game for myself, I would avoid all content related to it, so I wouldn't get spoiled.
Three and a half years later, oh my god, that choice was SO worth it.

As my first VR game, this is unlike anything I've played before, and probably will be ever since. It's clear that it was made to lean into the strengths that VR has from the ground up, and it makes for an incredibly unique and memorable experience.

I highly recommend playing in VR (not the PC mod) if you can afford a headset, or know someone you could borrow one from. On mouse and keyboard this just won't hit the same.

Greatest VR game of all times. 

I know its been almost 5 years since initial release of Half-Life Alyx but not much has changed. It is still one of the most if not the most advanced VR games. Visually it looks stunning, the storyline is great as always, although i have to note that i am considering myself a Half-Life series fan. But honestly the game is just great. All the mechanics all the attention to details and interactions feel really smooth. The graphics are stunning and it is all heavily optimized.

First i tried it couple years ago on Meta Quest 2 and it was an amazing experience. recently i tried it on Meta Quest 3 and it was even better, everything looks so clear and smooth, even tho because Quest 3 gives much clearer image you can start to see some small imperfections if you could call them that way. Because you see things very clearly you can see sometimes how mesh LODs are changing, but other than that its all perfect.

Another thing that i noted was the soundtracks, they sound just great, I was so happy that VALVE managed to keep the same style of soundtracks from their earlier games like Half-Life 2, Half-Life 2 Episode 1 and Half-Life 2 Episode 2, the soundtracks sound like they were made by Kelly Bailey even though they are not.

Long story short here is the list of things i have rated:

1. Gameplay - 10/10 - Overall gameplay is simple and smooth, everything is intuitive and still has that Half-Life vibe.
2. Music and audio - 10/10
3. Gunplay - 8.5/10 Its realistic, it is good and smooth, personally i think weapon sounds and recoil could be more realistic and punchier, but again its is not some realistic shooter so that is fine
4. Graphics - 10/10 - Its been almost 5 years since this game was release and i have not seen any game come close to it in terms of graphics.
5. Level Design - 10/10 - Everything looks natural and simple and nothing is confusing.
6. Story - 9.75-10/10 - The story itself is really good and everything is fine, it was interesting to see the game from Alyx Vance perspective, although the scene after credits has shown us alternative reality, hinting to infinite alternative universes, i guess such thing would give developers more freedom if they are planning to make another Half-Life game, i am not sure how i feel about this but i am more than sure that VALVE knows what they are doing.

Thanks for anyone who reads this review and finds it useful after all this time.

I'm a consummate late adopter, and I would not have picked up a VR headset on my own, but I received the Oculus as a gift and read that Half-Life: Alyx was the killer app for VR. It's made a believer of me. I

The game is a technological achievement that showcases incredibly immersive VR interaction, as well as highly detailed environments with many interactive objects, despite the high performance goal.

The story occurs between the events of Half-Life 1 and Half-Life 2, within City 17. This time, you're Alyx (didn't see that coming), in a journey through Xen-infested, Combine-controlled environments, saving your father and getting to the super-weapon concealed in The Vault. The campaign is about 15 hours long, and can be extended with mods from the Workshop.

Many elements from previous Half-Life games return in this entry, to the point that some parts of the game try to exactly replicate environments from previous entries. Gnome Chompski is one such feature, but at least this time he's much easier to transport.

The combat is enjoyable and tense in some spots, and there are new and returning enemies to find, as well as many (honestly, filler) holographic puzzles, however, the story and immersive presentation are the real kicker. The audio design is also dramatically improved, and despite most returning character voice actors being new, they did a perfect job.

Half-Life Alyx NO-VR review: In 1998 when HL was released, I was already a nearly-40-year-old fanboy. That means here in 2024, I’m an even much older fanboy—who, unfortunately, also has intermittent vertigo problems and suffers from severe motion sickness if I’m not careful. So, if I were ever going to be able to play Half-Life: Alyx, it would never be in its native VR form. Ah, getting old ain’t for sissies, as they say. Thanks a lot, Valve.

That’s why I was out-of-my-mind excited to hear about the Alyx NO-VR mod. I would finally be able to jump back into the dystopia that is City 17 and get gunned down by the Combine--before I croak in real life, that is. Now that I’ve made my way through the entire game using the NO-VR mod, I thought I’d write a little…update?

I won't extensively review the game. Plenty of other reviews here. But if you are reading this because you are also a longtime HL fan who can’t (or won’t) strap a contraption to your head but want to play the game, here’s my short advice: DO IT! The mod works. You can play the game from beginning to end sitting 12 feet away from a flat screen (or on your couch in front of ye ole’ TV box) and not vomit. Some of the VR-heavy functions in the game have been simplified (or removed) for flat-screen use, but the big, overall narrative experience, high-tension firefights, and creepy locations are still lovingly in place. Sure, it’s not the same innovative experience as it is in VR I guess, but also…you know…no vomit, no having to lay down for an hour to make the room stop spinning. Anyway, the game looks amazing (even now, 4 years after release), and the story and actors are as good as ever. The NO-VR mod has added in workable character models (hands, arms) and reload animations so it plays like a classic HL FPS. Maybe it’s my nostalgia talking, but wow.

However since the NO-VR mod is…well…a MOD, my recommendation has caveats. So as of February 2024, here are the hurdles I (quite happily) had to jump as I played through the HL: Alyx NO-VR mod. Since the mod is in active development, I expect many (or all) of these issues will get resolved (if they haven’t been fixed already).

GENERAL ADVICE: 1) SPAM THAT QUICKSAVE BUTTON. There are some technical issues with the current build of the NO-VR mod (again, we’re talking Feb. 2024 here…read below) that could be frustrating. Saving often helps soften those problems. There is a decent Steam community controller mod (if you play with controller) which works well, but I personally made one major configuration change to that community controller setup: I assigned the quicksave function to a single button on my controller so I could always have fast access to it. 2) BACK UP YOUR SAVES FOLDER. The way the NO-VR mod works, you only have a limited number of saves (something like 3 autosaves and 3 quicksaves that are continually overwritten, and the NO-VR mod does NOT support saves that were made in the regular VR version of the game—you must use your own NO-VR saves with the mod). The game’s save folder is located within the main install HL: Alyx folder and is clearly labeled SAVES. Take the time to create a copy of that folder and keep multiple copies of it somewhere. Why? It is possible for you to get yourself into a non-reversible situation (again, see specific issues below) and all your saves have been overwritten and you have no way out, other than starting the game from scratch. You do you, but I choose the low-frustration route.

SPECIFIC ISSUES I FACED>

CONTROLLER PROBLEMS: I play my PC games with a controller (Xbox Series X/S via Bluetooth connected to Windows 11). You might not, and if you use KB+M, then you don’t need to read this. The NO-VR mod supports both KB+M players and players who use controllers, but two issues with my controller happened. First, MOST of the time, after the NO-VR mod booted, it would NOT recognize my controller as being connected even though I had the Steam community controller configuration loaded, applied to the game, and Steam input activated (which you have to do ahead of time). It was super frustrating. BUT I finally figured out what I had to do to fix the issue. I had to boot the game AND Steam in a specific order: 1) With NOTHING running (not Steam, not the mod) and making sure my controller was connected via bluetooth to Windows, I simply had to> 2) Double-click the NO-VR mod launcher.exe itself. 3) This starts the NO-VR mod launcher. (Steam is still NOT running.) 4) In the NO-VR launcher, click play. 5) This auto-starts Steam. 6) Then Steam auto-starts HL: Alyx. If I had anything running ahead of time (like Steam already running, or the NO-VR launcher already running), my controller would not be recognized. This is how I fixed it.

CRASHES: When I would die 3 or 4 times in a row (it happens as the Combine firefights get tougher towards the end) and the game would restart from a checkpoint, after the third or fourth checkpoint load, the NO-VR mod would crash to desktop. This is one of the reasons you should spam the quicksave so you don’t lose progress. But outside of this specific situation, I NEVER experienced a crash. It only happened after several quick restarts in a row.

STUCK: Due to the nature of the mod, it can happen that you end up stuck on a piece of geometry (usually because you are somewhere you shouldn’t be). Thankfully, the NO-VR mod has auto-enabled the “no clip” cheat to a specific key (V) so it is super-easy to unstick yourself if this happens.

FORWARD MOVEMENT STOPS: This one I had to grin and bear it. But Alyx would often simply stop walking forward when she encountered even the smallest object on the ground in some places. A small rock, a tiny cardboard box, a little cable on the ground—these are things she would normally glide right over, but instead she would come to a dead stop. There were some maps where I would have to hop my way through it if there was a lot of debris around. The problem seemed to come and go, but it was especially frustrating in a firefight when I was trying to beat a hasty retreat to reach some cover…and Alyx comes to a complete stop because there was a piece of paper on the ground--and then she’s full of Combine bullets.

GUN MODS: The game has Combine machines you can insert your gun into for upgrades. After the upgrade animation ends, the gun is supposed to pop back into your hand. In some chapters though, I found that my gun was still sitting in the upgrade machine after the animation stopped, and I could not retrieve it--all I could do was look at it. I certainly couldn’t go forward without a gun. So this is why I say: Spam that quicksave! Get in the habit of saving BEFORE you do anything major. Most of the time, I would just ignore that non-working upgrade machine and wait until I reached the next one.

SCRIPTED EVENTS DON’T TRIGGER: There were two cases where major scripted events would not trigger for me, and the game would not move forward. Again, this is a reason to back up your saves folder so you can revert. One was in the “Jeff” chapter where the monster you are stealthily avoiding is supposed to follow you into an elevator. No matter what I did, Jeff would NOT get into the elevator—he was stuck in an earlier part of the map banging on an invisible door. The second instance was where I deactivated a Combine force field, but it still wouldn't let me go through. In both cases, I used the built-in “no clip” cheat that the NO-VR mod has enabled, and the game moved forward, ignoring the glitched script. Yay.

Though the above list might sound like they are all reasons to NOT play the NO-VR mod, that is not the case at all. As with so many mods (and especially one of this magnitude), you have to be prepared for workarounds, restarts, backups…all that good stuff. I was so happy to be able to play this high-quality HL game. I got those old tickly HL vibes all over again after so many years. YAY!! Oh, and that ending! Oh yeah, that ending!

My review is over 2 years late but here it comes and this is one of the only reviews I publish, because I appreciate the game so much.

First thing: Game is a triple AAA VR title and can't truly be appreciated in a non VR setting.

Second thing is and if you were never in such a situation you won't know what this game gets right. It has tons of options to combat VR motion sickness (us females are more prone to motion sickness in general).
And the accessibility options are really great, if you have any type of reduced mobility (even temporary in my case) you can 
still experience the game properly, can't bend over no problem, can't turn no problem, can't stand up or lay down no problem the game has you covered and you will still feel like being Alyx with a working body.
I can't talk about accessibility for colorblind or blind persons or one handed gameplay but Valve apparently worked on that part as well.
Also if you have an Index, a fully working body, a large play area and aren't prone to motions sickness especially in VR you are still able to use your hardware to the fullest and if you have neither of these Valve still has you covered so you can still enjoy the game to the fullest as it's just a bonus on top (nice to have but absolutely not necessary).

The third thing is great MOD support, yes you can play minigolf or visit Rapture from BioShock all via the click of a button from the Steam Workshop.
If you don't know how that works look up a YouTube video! (Hint: No other software is needed!)
All with the click of the button it's really just that easy and can be uninstalled the same way. The only hard part is finding what you want and if you want 30 things well just go ahead. You just need internet to download it (and a big enough hard drive if you're installing 500 mods on your almost full drive)
And in case a mod gets an update steam handles it like it handles updating other games and the neat part is only the changes are downloaded so if you have a bandwidth cap you shouldn't worry too much as it's usually only a few megabytes or even kilobytes.

And last but not least you get this game added to your account if you buy a (new) Valve Index at any point, alongside exclusive in-game weapon skins and an exclusive location in Steam VR.

Bonus: Jeff (I won't say more don't look it up and try to experience the game in VR.)

Only negative sides are:
- You can't switch your weapon from hand to hand in combat,
- No sprint at all. Only "jump".
- In certain areas there are places where you need to crouch to get through obstacles, but instead of letting you crouch through the obstacle, it just teleports you through it.

This is not for the faint of heart. Really. If you have some heart disease where getting real scared is dangerous for you, do not play. This is the level of realism of this thing. There is nothing scarier than being in a a pitch black room, surround by fuel and hearing noises of headcrabs coming your way. Oh, and you only have a pistol to defend yourself and limited ammo.

The game itself is amazing. You don't have a fancy inventory where you collect an unimaginable amount of stuff. You do not press a key to reload your weapon. You have one backpack to carry ammo. If you want to reload, you need to actually move your hand over your head, as of reaching your backpack and make the grab movement with your hand. Then you need to open a slot in your weapon (and this is actually by pressing a button), then make the actual movement of slidding the ammo on the right place and then the movement of loading the bullet in the chamber (or shaking the weapon for it to shut closed). To take cover, similar principle applies. You need to physically craw behind a cover for it to be effective. To throw Xen granades, you need to actually squeeze the control to activate it. And if you have fear of heights, you will actually feel the same fear when being in a high place and looking down. Heck! During my first days polaying, I found myself missing the gravity glooves in real life.

However, I must say. Towards the end, it starts to get tiresome. You have just progressivelly harder enemies to shoot and story progress very slowly. I got a bit disapointed with the ending. But then, I did not played the other HL games. So I may have missed something. Overall, it is worth it.

Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of a groundbreaking achievement in the world of virtual reality gaming. As a long-time fan of the Half-Life series, I had high expectations for this installment, and I'm thrilled to say that it not only met but exceeded every one of them.

From the moment I stepped into the virtual shoes of Alyx Vance, I was captivated by the stunning graphics and attention to detail. The level of immersion achieved through VR is unparalleled, and Valve has truly raised the bar for what is possible in the medium. The environments are richly detailed, the character animations are lifelike, and the atmospheric sound design adds an extra layer of intensity to the experience.

The gameplay mechanics are nothing short of genius. The integration of VR technology allows for intuitive interactions with the environment, making every action feel natural and immersive. From solving intricate puzzles to engaging in intense firefights with Combine soldiers, every moment in Half-Life: Alyx is a testament to the thoughtful design and meticulous craftsmanship put into the game.

One of the standout features is the gripping narrative. Alyx Vance takes center stage in a story that seamlessly weaves into the larger Half-Life universe. The writing is sharp, the pacing is impeccable, and the characters are well-developed, providing a narrative that is both emotionally resonant and gripping from start to finish.

The sheer variety of gameplay elements keeps the experience fresh and exciting. Whether you're navigating through a darkened subway tunnel, solving complex puzzles, or battling otherworldly creatures, Half-Life: Alyx keeps you on the edge of your seat. The careful balance between exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat showcases the developers' commitment to delivering a well-rounded and engaging experience.

The attention to detail extends to the world-building as well. The City 17 of Half-Life: Alyx feels like a living, breathing environment with its own history and stories to tell. The meticulous world design adds depth to the overall experience and enhances the sense of immersion.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Alyx is a triumph of virtual reality gaming. Valve has managed to not only revive the beloved Half-Life franchise but also redefine the possibilities of VR as a storytelling and gaming platform. It's a must-play for fans of the series and anyone looking to be transported into a world where the line between reality and virtuality blurs into a seamless and unforgettable experience. Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of a masterpiece, showcasing the potential of VR in ways that will resonate with gamers for years to come.

Game play 1.7/2
The guns are a good mix of tactical and fun, but I wish there was a larger variety of guns. Also, the ammo system punishes conserving ammo. If you're unaware, ammo spawns based on whatever you're low on, so stockpiling shot gun shells won't get you many shells. I also would've liked some more enemy variety and more interesting puzzles, but the enemy AI is so good that you could replay a single combat encounter 30 times and get a unique result each time. Also the gravity gloves are a perfect solution to meshing first person shooter fights and virtual reality interactivity. 

Graphics 1.8/2
Everything about this game looks good and it runs pretty well on my PC, which is difficult to get for a VR game. I won't get into my specs right now though since I want to focus on the review. The graphics are not only highly detailed, but fit very well in the Half Life style of being beautiful when it wants to be and horrifying when it needs to be. They also achieved realistic looking faces that aren't uncanny, no matter how close you get up to Russel when he's trying to explain how to save Eli. My only small issue with the graphics is that the xen overgrowth all looks the sameish, but that's it.

Music 1/2
There's no memorable music in the game but the sound design fits the game well and it's not like there are any ear grating songs. Not as good as Half Life could be. 

Story 1.8/2
Pretty solid, and good prequel to Half Life 2. I don't feel like it expands upon the HL universe that much, it just develops existing characters. It also raises more contradictions than connections. However I was very excited about the ending and the reveal at the end only made me more pumped up for HL episode 3. 

Price 1/2
Average price for a VR game at $60. I played for about 20 hours, and I did two play throughs (had to get the gnome achievement.) Most VR players would be comfortable spending $60 on a game in the first place because their minimum requires PC costs at least $500 and another $200 for the headset, and another $20 for Virtual Desktop.

[b]Standard price, AUD:[/b] $87.95

[b]Price paid, AUD:[/b] $29.90

[b]Time to finish:[/b] 19 hours to complete the story.

[b]Difficulty setting:[/b] Normal.

[b]Graphics settings:[/b] High Fidelity.

[b][u]PC specs[/u][/b]

Motherboard: ASUS ROG STRIX Z490-E
CPU: Intel i7 10700K @ 3.8GHz
GPU: NVIDIA RTX 3080 10GB
RAM: 32GB DDR4 1600MHz
Drive: Silicone Power 500GB M.2 PCIe SSD
OS: Windows 11
VR: HP Reverb G2

[b]Performance:[/b] Performance was largely good, but there were instances where I experienced stuttering. Occasionally when loading into a new area, my game would freeze and then I would get “Steam has encountered a critical error.”. These instances completely locked up my PC, but waiting a few minutes allowed SteamVR to close and I gained control of my PC again. Every time I loaded the game, it would tell me that my available video memory was low, but when I checked my resource monitor, it was only at about 30% usage. One section that noticeably affected my FPS was the [spoiler]section at the end with the Stryder.[/spoiler] As is always the case with VR titles, I’m not really going to take marks off for this kind of thing; there are just too many variables at play to say “The game is at fault for this performance.”. You sort of come to expect this kind of thing with VR titles.

[b]Graphics:[/b] What a detailed and interesting world this is! All the Combine tech stuff looks really cool. Seeing the zombies and headcrabs up close is gross and awesome. The big set pieces are massive  ‘wow’ moments. All the infested areas are so cool in that gross, alien way. They really did a great job of bringing the Half-Life world to life.

[b]Story:[/b] The story was almost in the background a lot of the way through, but not in a bad way. It does a good job at telling you what you’re trying to do or where you’re trying to go, but once you get that bit of information, it largely lets you do whatever you like in between, which I feel was the right choice for this title. It may not have been very complex; [spoiler] break Dad out of prison, then break “Gordon” out of prison[/spoiler], but it didn’t need to be, either. It just worked. I will say the end was the best part, story wise, and leaves me anticipating the next Half-Life VR game. P.S. Russel is hilarious.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] 

- Interaction: You can interact with a lot of items in the world which is nice. Shaking containers often plays a sound to hint at what might be inside; a nice touch I’ve never encountered in a VR game before. Writing on windows with markers, the way glass windows smash depending on how much force you use…these little touches go a long way in making this game feel really immersive. The Gravity Gloves were also really fun to use and so quick to learn. There were plenty of environmental hazards to exploit/avoid. The multi-tool puzzles for opening Combine machines/storage were fun and challenging.

- Weapons: You start out with a pistol that you can then upgrade in Combine fabricators with resin, which you find scattered around the world. Using the guns is great. The aim is bang on. All the other weapons you unlock as you go feel meaningfully different and the upgrades you can make along the way give that feeling of satisfaction over time.

- Enemies: Combat against the various regular enemies was enjoyable and the special enemies were designed very well. They introduced them in an informative manner and made sure you knew what to do, while remaining challenging.

[b]Misc notes:[/b] 

- You can wear a hardhats, buckets and traffic cones on your head.  The latter obscures the top 50% of your vision, but I got a huge laugh out of that and now every time I see one I have to put one on and enter a fit of laughter imagining what the Combine must think as I come sprinting at them with 2 grenades in my hands. 

- I didn’t like that we had to kill the poor little grubs for health! 

- The last level gets the “F#@k YES” award. That was one of the most enjoyable VR moments ever.

[b]Bugs:[/b] Once I had to reload a save and all the textures hadn’t loaded properly, so the world was devoid of detail. I just reloaded again, which fixed it.

[b]Final thoughts:[/b] Half-Life Alyx is one of the best VR titles, regardless of the performance issues. The quality of the game is immediately noticeable, the graphics and design are all top-notch and most importantly, it’s a heck of a lot of fun. 

[b]Do I recommend this game?[/b] Yes. At over $1 per hour of enjoyment (based on sale price, not retail price), this is one of the more expensive titles I’ve bought (I’m a cheapskate), but it’s honestly worth it at the price I paid.

[h1]HALF-LIFE: ALYX[/h1]
[b]Developed for over 4 years starting in 2016 after The Lab and Valve acquired Campo Santo, the developers of Firewatch which led to the cancellation of In the Valley of Gods.

As a massive Half-Life nerd I can't recommend Alyx enough. The graphics, gameplay, world, environment, and the VR make this a must play for any Half-Life fan or anybody with a VR headset. I played on the Index and enjoyed the game from beginning to end. This is Valves return to the series and i can't be more excited. Spoilers [s]but the future of the series, is most likely Half-Life 3.[/b][/s]

[h1]It's a great game![/h1]

[h3]+[/h3] The events of Half-Life: Alyx unfold before the events of Half-Life 2. From the very first minutes of the game it's clear that it's the same old, good and painfully familiar Half-Life. It was unreal pleasant to see the next game in the franchise after such a huge period of silence. And even though it's not Half-Life 3 or even Half-Life 2: Episode Three, it's still a great game with a great story and even cooler gameplay. The physics and the almost limitless possibilities of interacting with objects from the world around you are fantastic. HL has always been known for its interesting physics, but here it's even more elaborated. You can interact with almost any thing that comes into your field of vision with your glove. Want to draw a dlск on a window with a felt-tip pen? No problem at all.

[h3]~[/h3] I won't spoiler, but the end of the game hints at the continuation of the franchise, and I hope it will finally be part 3. Because we deserve it. And what we didn't deserve for sure is the silence about Half-Life 3. For me personally, this franchise has become one of my favorite games in the world. Valve managed to create an amazing, memorable story, lively characters and it's a shame that they left us without HL2: Episode 3... It would have looked even more epic in snowy locations. 
Let's go back to the game itself and discuss the minuses, because there are enough pluses here and it is close to the ideal, but nothing is perfect in this world.

[h3]-[/h3] The developers' decision to release the project completely under VR became doubtful. No doubt it's cool and it's the best game in virtual reality, but it would be possible to release a normal version. Because to buy a VR helmet for the just one game is not reasonable. Fortunately there is a solution to this problem. 
Special thanks to the developers of the [url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/half-life-alyx-novr] NoVR mod[/url]!
I think the name and so clear what its essence. Without this mod I would not have played this masterpiece, would not have touched the gorgeous story in a universe that I love very much. They have done a great job, giving us the opportunity to go through the game from the beginning to the end credits full-fledged and almost bug-free. And it all looks as high quality as if it were the original. It is unlikely that you are reading this, but if for some reason yes, then know that you are just the most real beauties! By the way, this mod is regularly updated, finalized and fixed, it's just super cool.

To sum it up: now in my list of favorite games there is also a game about Alyx. It's awesome and may more and more players live this wonderful experience. Such decent games are few and far between nowadays, modern developers are very often shoddy, releasing low-quality and uninteresting games. Or just do not try and release some trash indie projects, which flooded Steam. And among all this junk you can rarely find a hidden gem, and Half-Life: Alyx is just that.

Half-Life: Alyx is ridiculously good. Most VR games I've played focus on just doing one thing particularly well (Blade & Sorcery, Tetris Effect, Beatsaber). HL:A was the first time I've felt truly immersed in a VR game. Once a Combine pointed a gun in my face, I instinctively put my hands up; I flinch when unexpected things happen, I walk slower when I hear an unfamiliar noise, I nod my head along to conversations with fictional characters, I rummage through all the rooms with my hands looking for supplies.

It doesn't feel real, no. But it's very fun, and getting to interact with a virtual environment in such a fluid and dynamic way that couldn't be accomplished in 2D makes this one of the most amazing games I've ever played. Highly, highly recommend.

For Context: I have only dipped my toes into the Half Life series. I've seen clips of game-play online, seen or heard of the editing of Half Life 1, 2 and Episode 2, but never played a valve-created game besides Team Fortress 2 and Left 4 Dead 2. So upon getting my VR headset this Christmas, and seeing I had enough to buy Half-Life Alyx on sale (roughly $30 CAD), I bought it after hearing its reception of being the best that 3D had to offer. I've also played on the highest difficulty provided and now attempting my second play through where I try to complete all my missing achievements.

After completing it today, I am both amazed and sadden that Valve have seemingly stepped away from creating video games.

Game play wise: The intro did a fantastic job of getting me accustom to the world and the gameplay expected from me. Gun-fights were intense, and whenever I would die, I never felt like the game cheated me. Instead, I would always go "Hm, I could've done this better" or "What if I went this way instead." This game fuels creativity from its players, and rewards curious minds who look at ever small nook and cranny for ammo and upgrade cells. Despite the small pool of enemy types, I do believe it was smart in the long-run, as it ensured players would be familiar with each type and create a mental profile on how to action around one, or take note of weapon's weak points to not waste ammo.

Puzzles wise: I feel like this part get a lot of slack from other players, but I never minded doing them. To me, they were a fun reprieved after a  high-octane encounter with enemies. It also helped that doing them never felt useless, as it is always tied to upgrade stations, or additional ammo or health syringes. Even the tripwire puzzles were fun, and added to the intensity of not setting it off mere inches from it.

Thematic Wise: Half Life Alyx gave me a story that made me want to learn more about the Half-Life Universe, and also scared the pissed out of me with its horror elements. It's funny how the tone of this game can make you go from a one-man army bad-ass, taking out groups upon groups of Combine, and also make me paranoid and fanatic whenever fighting head-crabs or traversing pitch-black spaces. I've never been this immerse in a game before, and with the current market of VR titles or flat-screen titles, I don't think there will be another till a very long time.

It's hard to think of flaws that this game have that is entirely its own fault. I could say that being strictly for VR is a downgrade, but I also know that the game's whole identity and appeal will be muddled transitioning to flat-screen game-play. It can work, but it was never built for key and mouse. Although it baffles me how this game have yet to get official DLC besides fan-made content. This game-play style has so much potential, and I would happily play more. But if I have one main criticism for the game, is its price range.

Half-Life is an incredible game, but it cost $78 CAD (Plus Tax) to play normally which I feel is too much. Sure it comes free with Valve's VR headset, but that's over 1000+ and VR is too niche of a medium to pay full price for a game that, while high quality, isn't the type of game you'll continuously play for the rest of your life. Steam already makes Valve billions, so only buy this game when it is on sale, it'll be more favourable and not send your wallet into debt within the VR gaming sphere.

Overall: Half-Life: Alyx showed me why Valve titles get the hype they so rightfully deserves. This title alone has gotten me interested in exploring Valve's older back catalog, and anticipating the latest entry into the series, while will probably not continue the story until another 20 years. This is a MUST-BUY for VR owners, but ONLY when the price is reasonable enough. All I hope is that when VR games move forward, they look at this title for inspirations and build off its foundation. If Valve knows one thing, it's building a strong foundation for others to build off it.

I thoroughly enjoy this game, but I find myself grappling with a sense of monotony, especially when comparing it to my experiences with Medal of Honor. The primary culprit is the relentless presence of Headcrab Zombies as the main adversaries. Unfortunately, their ubiquity has become a source of weariness for me. It feels like every few minutes, I'm confronted with the predictable scenario of a door opening, only to reveal another Headcrab Zombie emerging.

In the expansive Half-Life universe, renowned for its diverse range of formidable foes, it's disheartening to see the gameplay overly focused on dispatching variations of Headcrabs. The repetitiveness of encountering these creatures has dulled the excitement that initially drew me to the game.

Nonetheless, despite this critique, I acknowledge the game's overall brilliance and my enduring love for the Half-Life series. The narrative depth, engaging mechanics, and captivating world-building remain commendable. My only wish is for the franchise to swiftly unveil a new instalment, perhaps delving into unexplored aspects of the narrative. I still eagerly await the release of Episode 3, hoping for a refreshing shift in the enemy dynamics and a return to the diverse challenges that have defined the Half-Life experience for so many fans.

Is it the best gaming experience I’ve ever had?

Yes.

The game design – the puzzles, gameplay and enemy encounters – are pure genius. 

This is in direct contrast to possibly the worst writing I’ve ever had to endure, in any format. Execrable is too mild an adjective. Googling it, I see the writing changed hands a few times, but apparently the original Half Life writers were eventually summoned back with success.

What happened?

Is this their artistic suicide note? 

Wait until you see the deus ex machina ending, which completely erases all the good work of their former selves – if it’s even the old Half Life writers to begin with. 

I personally don’t believe it.   

This was written to clearly appeal to a non-existent ‘moron’ target audience, who’s even a level below your average Marvel junkie, the She-hulk era. 

The voice actors sounded like they couldn’t take any of it seriously. It’s complete thrash. As in, it’s written in the most cynical ‘quippy’ way you could possibly think of – braindead crassness.

This is in direct contrast to the visual narrative – the story told by what you see – which is pretty much VR Mozart: beautiful and harrowing and thought-provoking and mysterious. 

And ‘epic’, of course. The last ‘boss’ fight against a strider is simply glorious, unprecedented adrenaline fuel. 

The various spatial awareness mini-games that only work in VR are the most innovative video game puzzles ever created IMO. Fantastic.

The environmental puzzles range from brilliant to about 2-3 overly obscure additions, such as an obnoxiously subtle support bar you’ll have to raise to get to the next point in the level. It’s not even a spoiler, because you will 100% miss this without a game guide.

Otherwise, these are again the best environmental puzzles (IMO) ever designed. 

The enemies, while brilliantly designed, are too few in variety to sustain the length of the game. Zombies, in particular, are overused. But overall, this is once more the most thrilling ‘pure combat’ video game experience you’ll ever encounter, by a million miles. 

To close off, it’s truly a VR masterpiece – and the pinnacle of what humans can create as a ‘gameplay’ experience. No ‘flat screen’ alternative can hold a candle to what has been achieved here. The gameplay innovation, making exemplary use of VR novelties, is the human imagination at peak inventiveness – absolutely awe-inspiring.

The narrative, meanwhile, seems to be written to appeal to I-don’t-know-who – cynically, an audience of gauche geeks, or something? 
Certainly the creepy ‘I’ll show you my gun when this is all over’ banter between Alyx and whatever-his-name-is is laced with all kinds of cack-handed ‘dirty’ innuendo. 

Lame and moronic – if Valve are to do a HL3, hopefully they sack these idiots and hire someone from CD Projeckt Red to save them.

Half-Life: Alyx - Redefining Virtual Reality Gaming

In the vast landscape of virtual reality, Half-Life: Alyx doesn't just set the bar; it launches it into the stratosphere, marking a watershed moment for VR gaming. Valve's return to the Half-Life universe is nothing short of a magnum opus, seamlessly blending gripping storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and revolutionary VR gameplay.

Immersive Narrative:
Set between the events of Half-Life and Half-Life 2, Alyx Vance's journey against the relentless Combine offers a gripping narrative that expands the Half-Life lore. As humanity's last hope, players navigate a world under siege, where every discovery and scientific endeavor becomes a beacon of resistance against the alien invaders.

Groundbreaking VR Integration:
Valve's commitment to virtual reality is evident in every frame of Alyx. The game is not a VR adaptation; it's a VR masterpiece. From the ground up, the gameplay is designed to leverage the immersive capabilities of VR, offering players deep environmental interactions, intricate puzzle solving, expansive world exploration, and visceral combat that can only be experienced in virtual reality.

Environmental Interaction and Puzzle Solving:
Alyx Vance's world is yours to explore and interact with in unprecedented ways. Lean around corners for that perfect shot, rummage through shelves for essential supplies, manipulate tools to hack alien interfaces - every action is an invitation to be part of the game's living, breathing environment.

Visceral Combat:
The combat in Alyx is nothing short of a revelation. VR's tactile nature translates into an unparalleled sense of presence on the battlefield. Toss a bottle to distract an enemy, rip a Headcrab off your face and hurl it out a window - each encounter is a dynamic, heart-pounding dance with danger.

Revolutionary VR Mechanics:
Alyx redefines what's possible in virtual reality. Its innovative mechanics, from aiming around obstacles to interacting with the world using intuitive gestures, showcase the limitless potential of VR when harnessed by a visionary development team.

A Benchmark for VR Gaming:
Half-Life: Alyx isn't just a game; it's a manifesto. It sets a new standard for what VR games can achieve, raising the bar for storytelling, gameplay, and immersion. As Valve's magnum opus in the VR realm, Alyx cements its place as a cornerstone in the evolution of virtual reality gaming.

In the realm of virtual reality, Half-Life: Alyx isn't just a game changer; it's the game that changes everything. If you've ever doubted the transformative power of VR, Alyx is here to shatter those doubts and immerse you in an experience that transcends the boundaries of gaming as we knew it.

The single greatest experience I have ever had in a video game. Nothing was ever quite able to top Half-Life 2 so figures it would be another Half-Life game to finally do it.

It took me four years to justify purchasing a virtual reality headset [i]just[/i] to play Half-Life: Alyx, and probably due to procrastination this time never came. Luckily, over the festive period I received a Quest 3, and with my immediate delight I knew exactly what game I needed to try first.

I’ve been able to play through the game twice now, the latter whilst holding on to the iconic Gnome Chompski (my final achievement [i]Gnome Vault of My Own[/i]). 

As an immersive experience, I’m absolutely blown away by the numerous moments of wonder, excitement, goosebumps & jump scares scattered throughout the campaign. The world feels so alive. I’ve had literal moments where I’ve stood and stared, with an open mouth, in complete disbelief. These moments range from large-scale events: viewing the Citadel & City 17 for the first time in VR, to moments of small-scale interaction: releasing a used ammo clip for your gun and replacing it with a fresh clip kept in your rucksack, or grabbing a health injector with your gravity gloves, mid-fight, then injecting it into your opposing wrist. All the while, time is of the absolute essence and the enemy stops for no-one. 

As a story venture it’s been a blast. I’ve been captured & rescued in City 17, escaped underground and forged alliances with vortigaunts. I’ve fought the Combine masses, dodged Antlion waves and survived harrowing [i]near-jeff[/i] experiences. I’ve crossed all that this world has to offer and ended up at the helm of the combine supersecret. It’s been an enthralling experience from the get-go. 

As a fan, I run out of superlatives to describe what the series has meant to me. Half-Life: Alyx has continued my most cherished series growing up. As a kid I witnessed Half-Life, Blue Shift and Opposing Force. As a teenager, I witnessed Half-Life 2, with Episode One and Episode Two. As an adult, I witnessed the release of Half-Life: Alyx. No matter what queue of games I have at any given time, the [i]Half-Life[/i] series routinely falls back into the list. I’ve been doing this for the last 20 years on Steam. 

An unreal experience worthy of everybody’s time.
“Perhaps [i]what[/i] I am, is not as important as what I can [i]offer[/i] you.”

I've played a LOT of games. All of the Half-Life games and expansions from day one, and I can confirm that this is the MOST Half-Life game that was ever made.
I played it on an Oculus Quest 2 using a link cable and it's been one of the most incredible gaming experiences I've ever had, if not THE greatest gaming experience I've ever had.
Equal parts horrific and beautiful, the work that has gone into the development of this game is just staggering. Every set piece and location is uniquely real, with purpose and level design in every square inch.
There are places in the game, so nightmarish, that you have to will yourself forward to progress. And vistas so startlingly gorgeous that you will stop in your tracks just to marvel at what is in front of you.
Aside from the insanely well-made environments, the game play is polished to a very high shine.
Plucking a grenade out of the air, tossing it back at the combine soldiers with one hand while simultaneously squeezing off a single round to rupture the valve on a gas tank on the back of a grunt.
Watch the grunt flail around hopelessly while he and the other two explode, then reload and prime your pistol for the next round. I have never felt like such a bad-ass in a game before.
The simple act of reloading your weapons, which would be a single button press in any other game, feels REAL, feels like something important.
The enemy AI is sneaky, forcing you to make full use of your environment: cover, explosives, choke points, kill boxes. Everything comes into play instinctively.
I won't say anything about the story, other than it's way more than I ever expected. 25 hours, just wow.
If this game had been released at a time when VR was fully commercially available to everyone, this would have won every award.
TLDR: If you're thinking of getting VR one day, and you played some of the Half-Life games, or just like games in general: Don't think, just get this. As of 2023, this is the best PC gaming experience you are going to have until the next one comes out.
I'm trying to think of negatives for this game, for balance, but all I can think of is that they could have handled the big reveal a bit better, but it's a minor consideration considering that this game is a complete masterpiece.

Currently playing through with the Meta Quest 3... though it doesn't appear to support the controller-less finger tracking (which is for the best, honestly). It's an exceptional game. If you've been on the fence about getting a VR headset, this is the killer app that makes it worth it.

You can tell it's a Valve game, because despite the jank that comes along with VR, it is exceptionally well polished. Aiming is much harder, so enemies are in small groups and always accompanied by cover. You can get sights (and laser sights) for your guns, which helps quite a bit. Enemy AI is reworked to compliment your teleportation-like movement (which you can change, though I don't recommend this), and the gloves...

Oh my god the gloves. I assume if you've read this far, you're okay with the most minor of spoilers. This game features gloves. Gravity gloves. You can, of course, pick stuff up like you'd expect. But you can also aim your open hand at an object, press a button, and then flick your wrist back to send it flying towards you. Then you have to catch it, which is easy, but oh so satisfying.

I'm new to PC VR, and this is the first non-standalone game I've tried. I had high expectations, given the franchise, Valve's reputation, and the reputation of the game in VR spaces. Without a doubt it looks great and you can tell a ton of work was put into creating the world and the environments. But as a game... it's pretty bad. I'm not going to claim to be the world's greatest gamer, VR or otherwise, but I'd characterize this as "borderline unplayable".  The physics puzzles are fine, the VR interaction is pretty solid, but they leaned too hard into "VR makes people sick" which means you can't run-and-gun and every combat interaction involves standing in one spot and magdumping into bullet sponge zombies. Miss too many shots and you get to die and restart the area. I have more deaths/minute of any game in recent memory because I'm constantly out of ammo and you move so slowly you can't realistically outrun enemies, or areas are locked until enemies are defeated/locks are shot.  I think it's poor game design that a poor-average player is expected to constantly restart the game if they're not hitting >80% of shots. Even if I had infinite ammo and infinite health, just standing there magdumping into a slow walking zombie isn't very fun. On top of that, you're constantly playing "where's ammo" looking around every nook and cranny in each area because you'll need that one mag that's hiding under a bucket if you don't want to die and restart.

Maybe it gets better, but I've looked at guides online and can't discern anything I'm doing wrong. I've played through a ton of standalone VR games and this falls so short of all of them, which blows my mind. Maybe this game just isn't for me. I've had very little fun playing it, so I'm going to put it away and play things I do enjoy.

Summary
HL Alyx is good. The campaign is 15-ish hours long. This game is not worth the normal price that is like 70e. I got the game when it was at 20e, and thats definitely worth it. The campaign is good, with good, simple puzzels and physics. The combat in this game is basic but still fun. You hide behind cover and then shoot. You also walk really slow wich makes this a slow-paced game. You can teleport, which you will be most likely using to hide behind cover faster. HL Alyx has phenomenal graphics, these graphics are the best to this date (in my opinion).

Now to the longer explenation

Campaing/Gameplay
I completed the game with around 16 hours. Its a good campaign. Each level is different and plays out different (going off of memory). There arent really any specific levels i didint enjoy. Maybe the later levels because my game was lagging, due to my PC specs. To put it simply, a normal valve campaign, but. Even when the game shows of new things like new enemy types, controls, physics, puzzels and all that. It all is nothing new. Its things we've seen before. No new physics or mechanics. What i mean by that is that those arent really any revolutionary things. Maybe two things i really think are cool about the game that i havent seen any other VR game do is that Alyx's hands react to what you are touching, not holding and when you pick up something Alyx will pick it up depending on your hands angle. Let me talk about the first thing, if you for an example put your hand on a slope. Youll see that her fingers react and follow the pattern/slope. And the second thing is that when you pick up an object like a bucket Alyx's fingers will correspond how you picked up the bucket. Its hard to explain, best shown visually. But those are  just visual things. They dont change the gameplay. As for the gameplay youll be mostly listening to the dialog, picking up ammo and resin, and just overall exploring your surroundings. Each levels is very well made with its interactivity. Which gives this game feel alive. There are so many things to touch and interact with. Youll probably find yourself pick up something and play with it like throwing it. 

Combat
The combat is lacking but also fun at the same time. What i mean by that is that yes it is fun shooting at enemies. But i just wish it there was more to do in combat. In HL Alyx you use the pistol for long shots, SMG to spray-and-pray/tougher enemies, shotgun for close-range and grenades for elimating enemies that are too close to one another. In my opinion that is not a whole lot of variety. While you do stuff like duck behind cover, youll just be waiting for the enemies to be done shooting. + ducking in any VR shooter is pretty much a basic thing. What im trying to say is that the combat is just hide behind cover and shoot. It is fun but i wish there was more to it. Like more weapons or gadgets like in Boneworks. In Boneworks you can use melee weapons or almost any objects that you can see to kill enemies. You can also box enemies or smash them against a wall to kill them. Also you can only walk and teleport. Which makes this very slow-paced. Which is fine with me. But as mentioned previously. There is really no variety in how you wanna approach a fight. Which is what made the Half life series so good. Ive played Half life, HL opposing force and half life 2 (but in VR). And each game gave you a set of guns. Each gun was like a tool. And you use different tools for different kinds of problems. But not in this game. It is very apparent that in this game the combat was not a primary thing. There is a mod that adds running to this game but it just ruins the flow, also the fact that teleporting is faster.

Graphics
The graphics are the BEST i have EVER SEEN. My PC couldnt handle the later levels soo i had to lower the graphics down to low in the settings. And yet it looked phenomenal. Truly the greatest looking VR game to  date. It also runs pretty smooth. I also had to turn of any background things like spotify, operaGX, steam and soo on, soo that my game wouldnt lag (My PC is a mid-spec or whatever you call it). Overall the graphics were REALLY GOOD. Even when i lowered them the the lowest setting i could it ran pretty smooth. Only the later levels were laggy.

Mods that i recommend:
"Flashlight Toggle Button"
"Unpin Ragdolls [ALL MAPS UPDATED]"
"Dismemberment" - if you like gore
"Burtal Blood" - if you like gore

Still recommend this if you want a game that looks pretty, has a basic combat system and made by a very successful and popular company.

[h3]This game is still very enjoyable in a small VR play space, and is (mostly) great if you're mobility impaired[/h3]
I have a small room and barely enough space to swing my arms around, and an inability to do a complete turn with my body without hitting stuff. I almost never had any problems playing the game like this. Both teleport-style movement and continuous movement controls are precise and easy to use, allowing me to position exactly where I wanted. 

If you have a mobility impairment, be aware there is one point late in the game where I had to physically lie on the floor of my play space and physically crawl forward approximately 2 metres. I couldn't find a way to proceed without doing so, but I may have failed to notice an alternative traversal path, and there are also many accessibility options available that I didn't enable, so they may provide a way to bypass it. Furthermore, there are some areas of the game where it is not required but is very helpful to get lower in your play space to hunker down behind low cover to avoid gunfire. Some objects which you are required to interact with to proceed require you to touch both of your hands to the floor of your play space. Again, there may be accessibility options for this that I am unaware of. The vast majority of the game should be comfortable to play seated as long as you have plenty of room to swing your arms around, and you'd probably get the best experience in a swivel chair.
For the hearing impaired, subtitles are available throughout.

[h3]How scary is this game? Is it appropriate for children?[/h3]
This game requires you to go through many prolonged sections that are designed to be frightening, such as pitch black rooms containing monsters and disturbing imagery such as decaying human corpses that you are required to touch and move close to. Regarding jumpscares, your mileage may vary: I never experienced any scripted jumpscares throughout the game, but the dynamic behaviours of some fast-moving monstrous enemies may cause them to surprise you under frightening circumstances. Some enemies you find in pitch black areas attempt to jump towards your face. One mandatory section of the game includes a large visually-disturbing monster which cannot be killed and stalks you through claustrophobic but well-lit rooms. Although these experiences and visuals may be considerably frightening to some players, the game maintains a whimsical and upbeat narrative tone throughout, which can help to defuse some of the tension. This game does contain frequent gory imagery, but only in the form of human remains of people who died long before you arrive. This includes rotting corpses, dead bodies missing eyeballs, and viscera regurgitated by monsters who had previously eaten people.

[h3]This game is very robust and well optimized[/h3]
I have played through the whole game and I never encountered any significant bugs or any performance problems in any area of the game. You can choose from 4 graphics presets (low/medium/high/ultra) and then the game dynamically scales a variety of graphics settings behind the scenes to try and maintain at least 90hz framerate: for example shadow draw distance, texture fidelity and render resolution. They do clever things to hide the transitions when they do this dynamic scaling, so it was only very occasionally that I noticed a shadow pop-in or out. 
I played with an AMD 5700XT graphics card and an AMD 2700 CPU, using a Meta Quest 2 headset connected by a link cable. With this I played on High preset and the framerate was so good throughout the whole game that I never experienced any perceptible motion stuttering or peripheral pop-in. 
How good it looks in the trailers is how good it looked for me through the whole game.
There's a free VR performance test tool you can get in the steam store. The performance you get there is a good representation of the performance you'll get playing this game on the Medium graphics preset.

The physics are very robust, and it's very satisfying and intuitive to touch and handle physics affected objects throughout the game. The game also goes to great lengths to reward creative lateral thinking by the player in how you touch and hold objects in your environment to help you overcome problems. The game trailer includes an example where the player picks up a chair and uses it to knock a small jumping enemy through a window. This is just one of over a dozen creative things I tried which the game rewarded me for, which put a big smile on my face.

Prepare to have your reality shattered and your expectations elevated, as Valve's magnum opus, "Half-Life: Alyx," catapults the gaming world into uncharted territory. This VR masterpiece isn't just a game; it's a transcendent experience that redefines what's possible in the realm of virtual reality.

From the moment you don the headset, you are thrust into the decaying, dystopian world of City 17, a setting so immersive that you can almost feel the grit under your fingers. The attention to detail is staggering, with every nook and cranny exuding the kind of realism that blurs the line between fiction and reality. Valve has not just raised the bar; they've redefined it.

The narrative is a brilliant continuation of the Half-Life saga, seamlessly weaving the story between the events of Half-Life 1 and 2. As Alyx Vance, you're not just a spectator; you're an active participant in a gripping tale of survival, intrigue, and the relentless pursuit of answers. The pacing is impeccable, with moments of heart-pounding intensity and quiet, contemplative exploration that showcase the versatility of the VR medium.

The star of the show, however, is the gameplay. Valve has harnessed the power of VR to deliver an unparalleled level of interactivity. From physically manipulating objects to solving puzzles that require both wit and dexterity, every action feels natural and intuitive. The gravity gloves, a stroke of genius, add a layer of immersion that has to be experienced to be fully appreciated. Combat is a visceral dance of strategy and reflexes, making you feel like a true survivor in the face of relentless Combine forces.

The audio design is another triumph, creating an atmospheric soundscape that heightens the tension and draws you deeper into the world. The eerie echoes of distant enemies, the haunting ambient noises, and the iconic sounds of the Combine machinery contribute to an audio experience that is as chilling as it is captivating.

Graphically, "Half-Life: Alyx" is a visual spectacle that showcases the true potential of VR. The attention to detail in the environments, the realistic character models, and the seamless transitions between different locations are a testament to Valve's commitment to pushing the boundaries of technology.

While the requirement for a VR setup might be a barrier for some, "Half-Life: Alyx" stands as a compelling reason to invest in the technology. It's not just a game; it's a landmark achievement that sets a new standard for what VR can and should be. Valve has not only revived a beloved franchise but has also charted a course for the future of immersive gaming.

In conclusion, "Half-Life: Alyx" is a triumph on every front. It's a testament to the potential of virtual reality, a love letter to fans of the Half-Life series, and a milestone in gaming history. Valve has not just delivered a game; they've crafted an experience that will be remembered as a defining moment in the evolution of interactive entertainment. "Half-Life: Alyx" is nothing short of a virtual masterpiece.
