For a long time I was wondering if it was worth purchasing a VR headset just to play this game. 3 years to be exact. Finally this summer I decided it was time, and, also thanks to the dirt cheap Quest 2, I eased myself into the VR world.

A friend recommended playing something else first, in order not to spoil the “G.O.A.T.” right away, and so I did. I started with other games, trying to overcome the sickness meanwhile. Luckily I got used pretty fast and I can now play as much vr as I want without feeling any fatigue or sickness.

After a few months I felt the time had come, so I installed Alyx.

I had purposefully avoided watching anything about the game beforehand, in order to prevent spoilers, so I went in totally blind.

For starters I will say: this is not Half Life 3! Nor it wants to be. There is no crowbar and the main character (Alyx) is fully voiced, so it definitely isn't a mainline Half-Life game. Someone defined this game’s genre more like a survival horror than fps. The first Half-Life was scary too back in 1998 and it also set a new standard for its genre, and the same did Alyx in 2020, in my opinion.

That said, in the game we will control Alyx Vance, daughter of Eli Vance, 5 years before the events of Half-Life 2. Eli gets arrested and abducted by the combine and we will have to track him down and rescue him. This will bring us on a journey through the city 17 quarantine zone. All the levels are quite varied and have distinct themes. Graphics are pretty good, some of the prettiest I’ve seen among VR titles. Also every location is really well crafted, with great attention to detail and little secrets scattered around. To be honest, I would have expected nothing less by Valve, and I wasn’t disappointed.

The gameplay includes all the aspects of the first two games: shooting, puzzle solving, physics, of course really well integrated with the VR technology. Interactions with the environment feel mostly natural and intuitive. 

Of course for the sake of simplicity and in order to avoid over-burdening first time players, some aspects of the game are dialed down in comparison to the older titles. The game is slower in general, combats are easier and there are fewer enemies and guns (even though they are all enjoyable). Understandably, Valve wanted to create an enjoyable first VR game for those who are new to the technology, and I personally don’t see anything wrong with that. 

Indeed, the experience is really immersive. Since the game opens, with a strider walking the streets while we watch it from the balcony of our house, I felt sucked into the atmosphere of City 17, with the constant guerrilla warfare between the Combine and the Resistance reminding me somewhat of the partisans fighting the nazis during WWII. 

Seeing all of that from an up close and personal perspective for the first time was a unique feeling for me. It might be obvious but VR lets you get immersed in the games much more than a flat monitor. Also, 16 years have passed since the release of Half-Life 2, and the graphical improvements are apparent. I multiple times found myself getting close to the enemy corpses, picking them up or moving them around in order to observe them and appreciate the level of detail and care they were made with. Combine are big, especially the chargers, with their heavy armor, and they feel really imposing.
There is a more survival horror oriented section in the game, when you meet “Jeff”, which was pretty intense [spoiler]especially when you end up locked in the elevator with them[/spoiler] and also brought up some memories of other titles (for example the berserker section in the first Gears of War) or some Alien movie vibes.  

About the plot, I don’t want to spoil more than I already wrote, so I’ll just say I liked it and it was on the same level of the other mainline games (if we want to consider this a spin-off), both writing and storytelling wise. 

Sound has the same level of detail and polish as the rest of the game, being able to convey every necessary gameplay hint (spacial sound is a must for VR). Thankfully all the classic sound effects are there, and I felt right at home with the health stations (unfortunately no HEV suit and no HEV chargers are in the game).

Music, on the other hand, alongside the classic HL2’s “Hazardous Environments”, offers some high-impact tracks, perfect to convey the various emotions and situations we find during the playthrough.

I played this game with a Quest 2 and a pretty beefy PC: 5800X3D and 6950 XT. I was able to play with everything maxed and even though I didn’t check my framerate often, I never felt the need to decrease my graphics settings since everything was really smooth. Funnily enough every time I launched Alyx, I got a pop-up message in the main menu warning me that with my setup I might have gotten sub-par performance with those settings. It wasn’t the case, after all.

In conclusion, I really loved this experience. I know some people expected a more “Half-Lifey” title and were turned off by the slow pace of the game, but I personally think this, being somewhat a spin-off, doesn’t necessarily need to be in line with the mainline titles. I enjoyed it for what it is, and I will surely try out the HL2 VR mod eventually, and decide whether I prefer that over Alyx. But even if that was the case, I’d still firmly recommend this one. 
Hopefully VR will get more accessible in the future so that a wider audience can adopt it and the medium can keep evolving and we can have some more new gems like this one.

I'm devastated that i've finished this game. I struggle to find good VR games since I was blown away by Boneworks, and this is one of the first games to do it all again. Not only does it have a good story, expands on characters we know and love, and have beautiful environments, it encases you in all of it with an extremely immersive atmosphere and some of the best VR gameplay on top. The gunplay is so fun, and the upgrades you get make it even better.

And tell me how on Earth they made it so fun to simply pick up objects?? The gravity gloves were always so fun to use. The physics engine in this great (albeit not quite as good as Boneworks', imo) and the details like the liquid inside the bottles moving and just being able to smash the supply crates and pick up ammo. All the simple tasks are made fun, and they never got boring for me.

Being able to fight headcrabs and whatnot was amazing, but one thing I didn't expect was my first encounter with the Combine. My god, seeing the oppressive, gene-modified soldiers right in front of me was terrifying, in the best way possible. It's not even that they're hard to fight especially, moreso that the atmosphere of the game makes their appearance just fabulous.

Man, I could go on and on about this game, even more than I have. I just want more of it, although I am glad they ended it where they did! It took me 12 hours to beat, which is extraordinary for a VR game. I guess i'll look into the workshop items and stuff... wow.

I played with the no VR mod, and this is still a phenomenal game. Perfect pacing, amazing shootouts with great arenas, and some creative parts that I imagine would be better in VR. I'll definitely play again with VR in the future.

NOTE: Works fine with a Quest 2 headset and controllers.

A must-play for Half-Life fans, and those interested in what VR is capable of.

Recaptures the HL2 atmosphere perfectly.  Environments, sounds, and enemy designs will be instantly nostalgic to series veterans.  A great romp thru a post-apocalyptic eastern Europe city, with plenty of Combine installations and alien-warped weirdness to pick your way thru.  Dunno if they MEANT to make it scarier than its predecessors, but it's definitely a tense experience, especially since your physical clumsiness will be amplified by hand controls.  Shooting here will make you appreciate how much easier it is to aim with a mouse.

Brilliant level design, with tons of puzzles and interactables to make the most of your hand controllers.  It's playable seated, but standing VR does help with working your way thru physics objects (and with responding to enemies).  If seated, I recommend a stool for freedom of arm movement- you'll definitely want it...

Some of the voice actors have changed, which I have mixed feelings about- they're not bad, just... different (maybe just cuz I've played the series a few times, and am noticing the differences too much).  Not the biggest fan of Russell, but he's alright.  Some parts at the end rely a bit too much on the crappy throw controls- grenades were my least favorite weapons here...

Overall, an amazing experience, and a great addition to one of the best series in gaming.

Oh, and Gabe?  HL3 plz.

Half-Life: Alyx is a groundbreaking masterpiece that redefines the possibilities of virtual reality gaming. As a longtime fan of the Half-Life series, I was eagerly anticipating Alyx, and it exceeded all my expectations. The level of immersion achieved in this game is unparalleled, thanks to the stunning graphics, meticulous attention to detail, and innovative use of VR technology.

The game's narrative is captivating, seamlessly integrating into the broader Half-Life universe while introducing new characters and plot twists that kept me on the edge of my seat. Alyx Vance takes center stage as a strong and compelling protagonist, and her journey through the dystopian City 17 is both thrilling and emotionally resonant.

The gameplay mechanics are nothing short of revolutionary. The intuitive VR controls make interactions with the environment feel natural, and the physics-based puzzles and combat add a layer of realism that I've never experienced before in a game. The sense of presence and scale in virtual reality is breathtaking, and every moment feels like a true adventure.

The attention to detail in the game world is remarkable, from the atmospheric environments to the lifelike animations of both characters and creatures. The sound design further enhances the immersive experience, with every creak, echo, and distant sound contributing to the overall atmosphere.

Half-Life: Alyx is not just a great VR game; it's a testament to the potential of virtual reality as a storytelling medium. Valve has once again demonstrated their commitment to pushing the boundaries of gaming, delivering an unforgettable experience that sets a new standard for what is possible in the world of virtual reality. If you have a VR headset, Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute must-play that showcases the future of gaming.

No because the physics and graphics alone would make this an amazing game, but the level design, mechanics, gunplay, and enemy design (except those horrid electric dogs) take the game up so many notches. The gravity gloves are an ingenious way to integrate a long grab seamlessly and naturally. After long sessions, I would take my headset off and try to gravity glove grab my water bottle from across the room. Enemies are fun to fight, especially the big combine dudes with the machine guns, since you have to be very careful when fighting them. I also loved how you could be fighting, and they would have a gas tank or grenade strapped to them that you could exploit for explosive kills. Another example is a section near the halfway point of the game, called Jeff. Not to spoil but the Jeff section is so interesting, as he plays differently than any other section of the game. The atmosphere was so tense, and it feels like hes right in the room with you. The graphics, both close-by models, as well as vistas and backgrounds, were beautiful. I played on the highest graphics settings and this was probably the most graphically beautiful games I've ever played. Segments outside were my favorite, because you got to see the beautifully rendered backdrops. For flaws, my biggest is the major lack of shotgun ammo. There was such a low amount of shotgun shells that I probably acquired around 80 shells in the whole game compared to the 1500 or so pistol bullets or 4000 or so rifle bullets. Its quite disappointing as the shotgun is probably the most fun weapon in the game, barring the ending sequence. Amazing game, I got it on sale but would happily have payed full price.

Valve's foray into virtual reality with "Half-Life: Alyx" has not only shattered expectations but has set a new standard for immersive gaming experiences in the VR realm. From the moment you don the headset, you're transported into the dystopian world of City 17, and the result is nothing short of breathtaking.

The game's narrative, set between the events of Half-Life and Half-Life 2, revolves around Alyx Vance, a character known to fans of the series. The storytelling is expertly crafted, with a compelling mix of suspense, intrigue, and that signature Half-Life mystique. The VR medium allows for an unprecedented level of immersion, as players physically interact with the environment, uncovering the secrets of the Combine and the enigmatic G-Man.

The visuals in "Half-Life: Alyx" are nothing short of stunning. The Source 2 engine is leveraged to its fullest, bringing City 17 to life with a level of detail that's truly immersive. The attention to environmental design and the intricacies of VR interactions create a world that feels tangible and lived-in. From the eerie corridors of abandoned buildings to the vastness of outdoor environments, each setting is a testament to Valve's commitment to pushing the boundaries of virtual reality graphics.

Gameplay mechanics are where "Half-Life: Alyx" truly shines. The intuitive VR controls, coupled with the gravity gloves, redefine how we engage with the virtual world. Picking up objects, solving puzzles, and engaging in combat feel remarkably natural. The blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense gunfights creates a dynamic and engaging experience that keeps players on their toes throughout the game's duration.

Combat is a highlight, with a diverse array of weapons and enemies that demand strategic thinking. The VR platform allows for an unprecedented level of control and precision, making each firefight a visceral and adrenaline-pumping experience. The gravity gloves add an extra layer of strategy, enabling players to catch, inspect, and use objects in creative ways.

Sound design is a critical component of the Half-Life experience, and "Alyx" doesn't disappoint. The atmospheric soundtrack and ambient noises contribute to the tension and immersion, enhancing the overall sense of presence in the virtual world. The attention to detail in audio cues, from distant echoes to the subtle hum of Combine machinery, further deepens the player's connection to the environment.

While "Half-Life: Alyx" sets a new standard for virtual reality gaming, it does come with the caveat of requiring high-end VR hardware. The investment in a compatible headset and controllers may be a barrier for some players, but for those who make the leap, the payoff is extraordinary.

In conclusion, "Half-Life: Alyx" isn't just a game; it's a landmark achievement in virtual reality storytelling and gameplay. Valve has successfully translated the essence of the Half-Life universe into a medium that feels tailor-made for its narrative and mechanics. From the gripping story to the unparalleled level of immersion, "Half-Life: Alyx" is a must-play for anyone seeking a truly transformative virtual reality gaming experience. Valve has not just raised the bar; they've set a new standard for what's possible in the world of VR gaming.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I played the original half-life at 10 when it came out and have been hooked ever since. Started on the WON servers and been on Steam since day 1. This is one of those games that always alluded me because of it being VR. I even purchased it a few months ago after hearing the 2D mod was getting really good. Realized recently that having an ROG Ally + 6850M XT dock I could probably run VR to some extent, I got weirdly giddy at the idea that I would finally get to play this game. Picked up an HTC Vive OG setup for cheap and first time getting it up and running I played 2 hours straight before I realized I had probably been playing for a while. It's like nothing I ever expected. Prior to this the closest I came for VR was an old GearVR and that was just awful. Used to give me headaches and make me feel sick. 3D TVs never bothered me so I just assumed it was something about VR that bugged me that may be different. I am happy to report that was not it, no headaches and no dizzy episodes with this setup (except for when I loaded a different game I thought had teleport movement and it did not and I was not prepared, went flying across the area I spawned in and then just about wanted to hurl lol, i'm slowly getting used to moving that way.) 

The hardest part of VR for me, is to remember that I can physically move and hide from enemies and that I can actually duck behind things and that I can dodge headcrabs and spin 180 and blow them away. I keep wanting to stand still and just turn and shoot. 

My only complaint and it is very minor, is a little more than midway through you meet a specific creature from HL2 and I had one pin me up against a wall and that turned pure stupid. When you try and move through something solid the screen goes orange and blinding orange. So I basically got pinned, ended up blinding orange and even walking forward wouldn't stop that. So I'm blinded orange, pinned and can't do anything. Eventually I guess I sort of glitched out and i could move away and then shoot it, but that was a few minutes of pure annoyance. Considering how amazing the rest of the game has been thus far, it's not remotely ruined my experience and it would not prevent me from playing the campaign again. Only half way through or so and already ready to replay it again and already have a handful of custom maps downloaded and ready to go!

Major props to anyone from the WON days who remembers playing king of the couch, going to monkey island or visiting the hippie room. I sure miss those days.

There is a runtime bug that keeps this game from running. I'm not the only one who's experienced it, but I can't find a solution that works. 

Most times when I launch Alyx, I get an error that says "Timed out waiting for response from mongoose. Steam VR needs to restart." I say "most times," because sometimes it doesn't, and I can't figure out why. This is the only Steam VR game that has this issue.

Luckily, I've been able to play through the game in those sessions where the runtime error doesn't occur (hence the 16 hours,) and I can say that it's one of the best games I've play, VR and otherwise. If it weren't for the bug, I would totally recommend this.

From what I can tell, most people don't encounter the error at all, and most of those who do can fix it via a couple methods (which didn't work for me,) so if you want to take the gamble, your chances are pretty good.

[h1]I was eagerly waiting for Half-Life 2.[/h1]
And it hit me right in the feels with its gripping narrative and the tech engine's capabilities, not to mention the game designers' wizardry. Then came the two epic episodes with an ending that just left me itching to know what happens next.

[h1]And bam, here comes ALYX![/h1]
Breaking the boundaries of player-game interaction, delivering a totally fresh gaming experience. Once again, an awesome storyline with a killer ending that's got me itching and hoping for Gabe's not-so-favorite number, Half-Life 3. 

[i]“The right man in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world.”[/i] — G-Man
half-life is half-life

[h1] Alyx is to date, the most complete, truly AAA VR game. [/h1]

Physics are the best ever in a game. Doors, bottles, grenades and chairs, all have weight to them, and you can almost feel it, they behave exactly as real world objects would. It is amazing that a game can replicate physics as well as Alyx can.

Music and sounds are also spot on, but it is the visuals and mechanics that truly sell the game for me.
This is still the best looking video game I have ever seen, and that even when played in low to medium graphics quality. The level design perfectly takes advantage of all the visual fidelity the game can offer, everything is alive and reactive to touch, creatures crawl beneath your feet and the walls breath and try to bite you, and it is all so real you simply cannot feel not immersed. 

As far as the plot and gameplay go, it is pretty good. The puzzles are fun to solve and the terrain is always interesting to traverse. Levels in the dark are absolutely terrifying and messing with combine tech is always a welcome challenge. The gunplay is brutal and punishing, grenades feel truly dangerous, if it weren't for those fucking flying bay-blades and the combine feeling a little too spongy for me I would say combat is pretty much perfect, but that's coming from someone who has yet to play the previous Half Life games.

The performance in very open (like some levels in chapters 3 and 6) and vast environments is pretty bad and immersion breaking, but since most of the game takes place in smaller environments I wouldn't consider it a deal breaker. 

One thing that is pretty annoying and pretty much the only reason that I don't have multiple hundreds of hours in this game is just how long the loading screens are, both to first load the game and between levels and deaths. If you want to play this game, you basically have to install it on an SSD, otherwise you will keep experiencing 4+ minutes loading screens every time die or you advance a level. 

All around, even with those problems, the game is still one of my favorites of all time and I still plan to enjoy it for many more tens of hours. I haven't touched the Mods in this review because I haven't tried those many of them out, but from the small experiences I had, it is safe to say they add lots of content and are pretty good.

9/10 because of the loading screens and the flying bay blades.

Positives: Still the best VR game, even after 3 years. Gaben must have entered a pact with the devil and gotten some black magic in return to make the game look this good while not being ridiculously difficult to run. Most VR games, even the ones that look good, get somthing wrong with anti-aliasing and you get jagged lines/flickering on distant objects. Alyx has none of that. Everything is smooth in all distances. Lighting is really good, giving every moment and view almost cinematic feel. Dark places are pitch black. At times it looks eerily realistic. Physics on objects are top notch. There is a lot of details, that didn't need to be there, but help the immersion a lot. Story is okay, ending is so so, but it honestly doesn't matter that much. It's secondary to fooling around with grav gloves and exploring the environment.

Now a negative: the enemies are dumb and spongy, that makes the combat kinda boring over time. It's a problem a lot of games have. It's not that bad here but I wish that game studios would scale difficulty by making combat more fast paced and punishing/revarding, rather than making enemies eat more bullets.

[h1]A landmark in video gaming[/h1] 
VR games have been around for quite a number of years, but they've only really been pricey novelties, merely stoking the imagination for what AAA VR games might be like one day. 

And then comes Half Life: Alyx in 2020, to show everyone that the future has arrived.

[h1]Holy sh*t[/h1]
Were the first words that came out of my mouth when I experienced the world for the first time. The visuals were [b]incredible[/b] and utterly jaw dropping to look at. Clearly, Valve wanted to blow players away right off the bat.

And then I look to my side and I see a radio. [i]"Ah, let me just play around and see if I can turn the knob and extend the antenna- Holy sh*t I can actually do that?"[/i] 

As silly as that sounds, it was amazing to me just how much of the world could actually be interacted with. Even random things that don't add anything to primary gameplay like picking up markers and writing on glass was just incredible to me. I'd played VR games before, but never had I experienced this level of immersion and attention to detail. And all that was just in the first few minutes of playing the game! 

[h1]Progression and pacing[/h1]
Progression is done masterfully. The game starts off relatively slow, letting you walk around to get a feel of the controls while admiring the world around you, before introducing you to the tension and dread of walking through the dank and dark alien-infested underground, and then on to the adrenaline pumping gunfights. 

In short... this game is a ton of fun, from beginning to end.

[h1]Accessibility[/h1]
As someone who gets motion sickness from certain games and with the effects magnified by VR, I really appreciated the teleport movement and snap turning options. It was because of this that I never once experienced any sort of "VR sickness" while playing this game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Half-Life: Alyx is everything the ideal VR game should be: immersive, captivating to look at, and most importantly, fun!

"This game is a Half-Life." How many times have I repeated this phrase to myself?
Wait, Is this game really a Half-Life?
Here's my review of the game as a veteran of the Half-Life franchise (I first finished the first installment in 2003, I finished all the games on PC and consoles a lot of times).
/!\ Warning, massive spoilers.

The 13 long years of waiting for HL2:EP3 or HL3 ends with the release of a so-called prequel in VR that no one asked for.
We start with an affront to the fans, how could this end well?

Here are the few positive points that I could identify:

The game has (kinda) beautiful graphics, 
thanks to the Source 2 engine and a pleasant physics engine.
The puzzles are well thought out although too numerous and redundant.
The weapon improvement system via "resin" is nice.
The Gravity Gloves as useful and versatile as the Gravity Gun.
The characters are charismatic, and can have a serious or humorous tone.
The music composed by Mike Morasky is appreciable, very electro and industrial, but is not as great as those of HL1 and HL2.
The sounds are very interesting, intriging, engaging and contribute to immersion.
City 17's Half-Life Alyx version is very classic, detailed, and great to look at and to explore.

But the list of negatives is quite heavy:

- Armament:
Ammo is too scarce so every bullet counts.
The enemies are too resistant compared to the weapons we have.
Only 3 weapons! I hadn't seen this since SiN Episodes: Emergence!
Some Combine Soldiers have weapons that cannot be picked up (probably because they are two-handed).

- Script
The story is too vague and has little connection to the rest of the series.
It really seems like the devs only had a vague knowledge of the lore.
Very few elements of HL2 Beta are recycled when there really is plenty to do.
The paranormal / gore side is way too exacerbated...
Where is Dog? He is supposed to protect Alyx since her childhood...
Where is Breen? Where is all the propaganda?

- Bestiary
If the bestiary is quite varied, but how to legitimize its disappearance before the events of Half-Life 2?
We had the same problem with the Race-X in Opposing Force long before...
The new enemies are not fun to fight for several reasons.
The Armored Headcrab is armored on top and only its ventral part is vulnerable.
The different Combine Heavy Soldiers are very resistant and their weapons hurt too much, even from afar. Like I said, we can't take their guns. They are similar to the Heavy Replicas from F.E.A.R. ...
The Antlion Soldiers are armored, they have to be dismembered so that you can shoot into their abdomen, causing them to explode!
Ditto for the Antlion Workers, except they spit a painful blue acid that coats the screen...
The worst of the worst from Half-Life Alyx's bestiary:
The Lightning Dog (Reviver): A kind of electric Headcrab that, in addition to electrocuting you and being resistant, can take control of corpses like the Remnant from F.E.A.R. 2 and land powerful attacks.
"Jeff": A unique, blind, but not deaf zombie. I have no words, how to say... Why does such an abomination exist in the Half-Life universe? Who could validate this stuff?

- Scenery
If the city, on the surface is pleasant, it is not the same for the undergrounds, moreover too numerous. You will become claustrophobic.
The interiors are massively covered with a kind of biomass, dirty as possible, sometimes explosive. There too, we are closer to F.E.A.R. 2 for example.
The last chapter is closer to Portal 2. What is the visual affiliation with Half-Life 2?

- Dubbing
The game is only dubbed in English! Seriously! After dubbing the old Half-Life games in loads of languages!
However, it is subtitled in a few languages, even if it's easy to understand in the original version.

- Bugs:
I found myself several times and easily outside the map not knowing where to go...
We regularly find ourselves blocked everywhere for no reason.

This review is based off this game being $60 dollars: This is not a $60 dollar game.
Would I have paid $20 or $30 for this? Yes! Would I have paid $40? I'd have thought it over, and maybe waited for a sale, unless I was super bored. But for $60 dollars, I expected a lot more from this game - and it just didn't deliver.
Average game length is 12-13 hours, with around 20 if you explore every nook and cranny. Breaking down the math means roughly $3/hour. Compared to other "shooter" games, this is par for the course, but I was expecting a lot more time because it takes longer to do things in VR than it does in a typical run-and-gun.
Now I may just be splitting hairs. The game looks and plays quite well. I used a Quest 3 with Steam Link, cranked all the settings in Steam Link for maximum graphical fidelity. My rig has a Zotac Amp Extreme 2080 Ti; it is a beast of a 2080 Ti card. I noticed some hiccups on occasion but really no complaints, everything was smooth 99% of the time. Honestly, I was impressed.
I just wish it were longer, the bang didn't feel worth it for the buck - but if you DO spot this on sale, I would suggest grabbing it.
Just make sure your rig and your VR headset will be able to keep up!

Half-Life: Alyx, the long-awaited return to the iconic Half-Life universe by Valve, not only lives up to the immense expectations set by its predecessors but boldly ventures into uncharted territory by embracing virtual reality (VR) with unprecedented finesse. This game is nothing short of a groundbreaking achievement, showcasing the potential of VR as a transformative platform for gaming.

The narrative of Half-Life: Alyx is a gripping prequel to the events of Half-Life 2, following Alyx Vance as she fights to save her father from the Combine forces in the dystopian City 17. The storytelling is masterfully crafted, immersing players in the rich narrative tapestry of the Half-Life universe. The characters are engaging, the pacing is flawless, and the attention to detail in the world-building is awe-inspiring.

The introduction of VR adds an entirely new dimension to the Half-Life experience. The immersion achieved by Alyx is unparalleled, making players feel truly present in the game's meticulously detailed environments. From the awe-inspiring City 17 skyline to the eerie corridors of abandoned buildings, every location is a testament to Valve's commitment to pushing the boundaries of what is possible in virtual reality.

Gameplay mechanics in Half-Life: Alyx are a revelation. The intuitive controls, coupled with the intricacies of VR, provide a level of interactivity that goes beyond traditional gaming. From manipulating objects in the environment to solving puzzles and engaging in intense gunfights, every action feels natural and responsive. The gravity gloves, a new addition to Alyx's arsenal, are a stroke of genius, allowing for seamless interaction with the world and enhancing the overall sense of presence.

The visuals in Half-Life: Alyx are breathtaking. The Source 2 engine showcases the power of VR, delivering realistic textures, lighting, and physics that contribute to the immersion. The attention to detail in both character models and environmental design is nothing short of remarkable, creating a world that feels alive and dynamic.

The audio design is equally impressive, with a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack and meticulous attention to spatial audio cues. The soundscapes of City 17 are as integral to the experience as the visuals, enhancing the sense of tension and urgency throughout the game.

While the VR requirement might be a barrier for some players, Half-Life: Alyx stands as a testament to the potential of virtual reality in gaming. It's not just a game; it's an experience that redefines what we thought possible in interactive entertainment. Half-Life: Alyx is not only a must-play for Half-Life fans but a milestone in the evolution of gaming as a whole. Valve has not only revived a beloved franchise but has set a new standard for immersive storytelling and gameplay in the realm of virtual reality.

Have you ever watched a zombie movie and a character is facing hordes and is too slow at reloading and ultimately dies - and you think 'that would never happen to me, it's so easy reloading quickly"? Well this game made me realise that it is, in fact, not.

This has to be one of the best games I've played on VR.   So immersive and really atmospheric.  Probably the first AAA traditional style game - graphics are really high quality and runs very smoothly on my setup.  

Highlights include fighting it out with soldiers, using cover and leaning out for real.   Fending off a head crap attack.  Searching in cabinets and boxes to find items.  The city scenery is really impressive. The control system and accuracy seems pretty decent with my rift although I am using 4 sensors.
 
I have had a number of crashes though - often when I think scenery or object boundaries are exceeded, as if it's not sure how to handle it.  Screen goes back on headset and monitor and when picture returns steam vr states it needs to restart.    Restarting the game and within a few seconds of trying the same thing it crashes again.  Often requires a pc restart.

Using a rift means that the oculus software is also loaded, which sometimes causes headaches if you hit the wrong button.  May have a better experience using the Vive or similar.

Highly recommended, even with the issues mentioned.

Update: not too long after posting the review I started getting a lot crashes back to desktop.  Appears that the radeon driver crashed, then the various vr apps.  Start again and it crashes after only a minute or too.  Getting unplayable.   Have installed latest drivers (supposedly with alyx support) - only difference is when it crashes it actually restarts my pc.  

When restarting the game I've been out of bounds a few times too, walking above ceilings, other sides of walls etc - and had to load an earlier save.

Have stress tested my pc with memtest, 3dmark stress test and others - and been fine.  Have tried numerous versions of the display drivers.  Have also installed a dedicated usb3 card encase it was a headset power issue - still crashing.  

Nothing overclocked, all stock, 64GB memory - and everything else I play has been fine.  At a loss here, and don't have an nvidia card to try - shame, as I was really enjoying the game up until now.  It's just frustrating now.

Update 2 - long overdue.  After a few AMD driver updates it became very stable and far more enjoyable as a result.  Highly recommended.  Recently purchased a Quest 3 so will be playing through again with it.

So couple of days ago I have finished this game and I gotta say its pretty good. I played it personally with NOVR because I dont have vr headset and I dont have a interest in buying it, of course the real and possibly better experience is to play it with vr since youre not gonna have some of those issues that come with NOVR mod. Still its not bad I had some fun with it and couple of annoying parts that slightly bugged me.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ The graphics look really good.
+ The sound design is also pretty good.
+ The NOVR gameplay is similiar to Half Life 2 except its slower and encourages more exploration if you wanna find scarce ammo, resin and health
+ Its suprisingly fun
+ Story is alright but....

[b]Cons:[/b]
- NOVR mod is still kinda janky, you often get stuck on props, rails and all kinds of junk. Sometimes you get softlocked forcing you to use noclip, aiming with pistol and smg is janky because it can stay zoomed in if you run out of ammo, the range when you throw grenade is short + its missing some weapon upgrades, mini games and other ,,vr'' interactions.

- There are some weird changes such as: You cant normally kill antlions, you have to shoot off their legs than their abdomen also they are slow compared to Half Life 2, the antlion workers for some reason looks different compared to Half Life 2 episode 2. For whatever the f**k reason there are no fast headcrabs, fast zombies and poison zombies, barnacles are not dying when they eat poison headcrab, different voice actress for Alyx.

- There are some retconned things in the story such as the infamous Russell which we dont know if hes still alive after Alyx storyline or not, different looking combines except civil protection, combine weapons being only usable with dna or other transhuman modifications, the zoo area kinda confused me since its couple of years since the combine occupies the earth (the blood on the tiger skull looked fresh imo, zombified zoo keepers can be seen in the area somehow surviving the place infested with the combine and antlions) ...etc

- The last 2 chapters where I was fighting the combines and especially strider was tough and really frustrating.

So do I reccomend this game ? Is it a meme or is actually worth ? Vr or NOVR ? Id say yes, I belive that its still worth it. I think its still a pretty damn good game and if I was a vr gamer I would consider it a proper vr game and not gloryfied tech demo. While its not the best Half Life game its still better than Blue Shift and maybe better than Half Life 2 episode 1 but Im still not sure about that.

Amazing Installment in the Half Life universe even without VR.

I have been a long time HL series fan. I currently can't justify to myself for getting a VR set so I was pained to learn that HL: Alyx was going to be VR only especially with rumors of its ending actually continuing the end of HL2:EP2. However thanks to all of the work done by those at Half Life: Alyx NoVR Mod I was able to play through the latest installment and I was absolutely blown away by the experience. The mod was relatively easy to get setup. While things were a little clunky at times such as being restricted to one hand for actions, some bugs due to work arounds, and platforming being a challenge I was able to play through the entire game start to finish without getting stuck due to technical issues. I will admit I could understand that if you have a VR headset definitely to play it that way as the experience would be mind blowningly good. I thought that they did a good job of making it feel also like survival with a bit of horror thrown in.

The Story: The story of Half Life: Alyx is really well done, though raises some questions that never get answered. It was great getting to explore a more detailed area of C17 while learning more about Alyx before the events of HL2. All of the areas and new characters felt like they tied well into the world. My only issues with story and world building is wondering what happened to them as there is no mention of them nor the more advanced technology going away before HL2 begins. Where are my heavy combine soldiers in HL2? What happened to other characters that were involved in the plot since they are never mentioned in HL2? For the world it was fun to see Valve trying more organics in the world as I think they made it interesting and thought provoking. 

Graphics: I think that Valve did an amazing job with making the graphics both looking more refined to modern standards of 2020 while keeping the styles that the HL2 games where using. Everything felt like it had a place. Again this is where Valve having more organics in the environment really shows. Also the game seemed really optimized that even on my weird setup I was able to play on ultra at 1080p with never a hitch in graphics though I did have mild skybox artifacting but I blame it on my GPU. 

Gameplay: Methodical is the word that I would use to describe it. If you are used to the other HL games it definitely feels slow at first as the world is more confined to reduce movement needed in VR. This is encuraged by making you look through everything, I mean everything for health and ammo. You will be finding single shotgun shells hidden in drawers as there no longer are nice big boxes of shotgun shells. Though I will admit that they made the exploration feel interesting and not like a chore. It is amazing how much interaction that there is in the world so it feels weird when something can't be opened or picked up. The one thing that I found a little off / frustrating having played as the man with a PHd in firearms is that all of the enemies are tougher while at the same time you aren't as well equipped so it makes encounters more of a slog especially with restricted movement. A lot of the encounters with combine in the end involved me hiding behind something while one shot at a time widdling away at their health. Also there were points that required multiple reloads of the game. 

Overall: If you have a VR headset and you don't own HL: Alyx then you should. If you don't have a VR headset and are willing to put up with a few minor issues then I would definitely recommend Half Life: Alyx especially if you have enjoyed all other Half Life games.

English:

Homemade Landjäger Sausage

Ingredients:
- 500 g beef
- 500 g pork
- 20 g curing salt (nitrite curing salt)
- 5 g coarse ground pepper
- 5 g sweet paprika
- 3 g garlic powder
- 2 g ginger powder
- 2 g dried marjoram
- 1 g ground coriander
- 1 g grated nutmeg
- 1 g ground cardamom
- Pork casings for stuffing
- Kitchen twine

Instructions:
1. Cut the beef and pork into small pieces and pass them through a meat grinder with a coarse plate.
2. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add all the spices (curing salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, ginger powder, marjoram, coriander, nutmeg, and cardamom). Mix well until the spices are evenly distributed.
3. Cover the meat mixture and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours to allow the flavors to develop.
4. Thoroughly clean the pork casings and soak them in cold water to soften.
5. Remove the meat mixture from the refrigerator and knead it again to ensure proper blending.
6. Stuff the meat mixture into the prepared pork casings, ensuring there are no air pockets and that the casings are evenly filled.
7. Cut the filled casings into approximately 10 cm long pieces and tie the ends with kitchen twine.
8. Hang the Landjäger sausages in a cool place to dry for about 2-3 weeks. The ideal temperature is around 15-18 degrees Celsius.
9. After the drying period, the Landjäger sausages are ready to be consumed. They can be enjoyed raw or lightly pan-fried.

Note: When making sausage, it is important to maintain proper hygiene. Ensure all utensils are thoroughly cleaned, and use fresh meat. It is also recommended to familiarize yourself with basic sausage-making principles and consider employing specific sausage-making techniques.



German:

Selbstgemachte Landjäger Wurst

Zutaten:
- 500 g Rindfleisch
- 500 g Schweinefleisch
- 20 g Nitritpökelsalz
- 5 g Pfeffer, grob gemahlen
- 5 g Paprika, edelsüß
- 3 g Knoblauchpulver
- 2 g Ingwerpulver
- 2 g Majoran, getrocknet
- 1 g Koriander, gemahlen
- 1 g Muskatnuss, gerieben
- 1 g Kardamom, gemahlen
- Schweinedärme zum Abfüllen
- Küchengarn

Zubereitung:
1. Das Rind- und Schweinefleisch in kleine Stücke schneiden und anschließend durch den Fleischwolf mit grober Scheibe drehen.
2. Das gewolfte Fleisch in eine große Schüssel geben und alle Gewürze (Nitritpökelsalz, Pfeffer, Paprika, Knoblauchpulver, Ingwerpulver, Majoran, Koriander, Muskatnuss und Kardamom) hinzufügen. Gut vermengen, bis die Gewürze gleichmäßig verteilt sind.
3. Die Fleischmasse abgedeckt für mindestens 24 Stunden im Kühlschrank ruhen lassen, damit sich die Aromen entfalten können.
4. Die Schweinedärme gründlich reinigen und in kaltem Wasser einweichen, um sie geschmeidig zu machen.
5. Die Fleischmasse aus dem Kühlschrank nehmen und erneut gut durchkneten.
6. Nun den Fleischteig in die vorbereiteten Schweinedärme füllen. Dabei darauf achten, dass keine Luftblasen entstehen und der Darm gut gefüllt ist.
7. Die gefüllten Därme in etwa 10 cm lange Stücke schneiden und die Enden mit Küchengarn verschließen.
8. Die Landjäger für ca. 2-3 Wochen an einem kühlen Ort zum Trocknen aufhängen. Die ideale Temperatur liegt bei etwa 15-18 Grad Celsius.
9. Nach der Trocknungszeit sind die Landjäger bereit zum Verzehr. Sie können roh gegessen werden oder kurz in einer Pfanne gebraten werden.

Hinweis: Bei der Herstellung von Wurst ist es wichtig, auf hygienische Standards zu achten. Sämtliche Utensilien sollten gründlich gereinigt und das Fleisch frisch sein. Es empfiehlt sich außerdem, sich mit den Grundlagen der Wurstherstellung vertraut zu machen und gegebenenfalls auf spezielle Wurstherstellungstechniken zurückzugreifen.


Chinese:

自制兰德亚格香肠

材料：
- 500克牛肉
- 500克猪肉
- 20克食盐（亚硝酸盐食盐）
- 5克粗磨黑胡椒
- 5克甜辣椒粉
- 3克大蒜粉
- 2克姜粉
- 2克干马郁兰
- 1克芫荽粉
- 1克磨碎肉豆蔻
- 1克磨碎草果
- 猪肠衣（用于填充）
- 厨房绳

制作方法：
1. 将牛肉和猪肉切成小块，然后通过带有粗孔板的绞肉机绞碎。
2. 将绞碎的肉放入一个大碗中，加入所有的香料（食盐、黑胡椒、甜辣椒粉、大蒜粉、姜粉、马郁兰、芫荽粉、肉豆蔻和草果）。充分搅拌，使香料均匀分布。
3. 盖上碗，放入冰箱中静置至少24小时，使香味融合。
4. 彻底清洁猪肠衣，并将其浸泡在冷水中软化。
5. 从冰箱中取出肉馅，再次揉捏均匀。
6. 将肉馅填入准备好的猪肠衣中，确保没有气泡并且填充均匀。
7. 将填充好的猪肠衣切成约10厘米长的小段，用厨房绳扎紧两端。
8. 将兰德亚格香肠挂在凉爽的地方晾干约2-3周，理想温度为摄氏15-18度。
9. 干燥期结束后，兰德亚格香肠即可食用。可以生食或轻微煎炒。

注意：制作香肠时，保持良好的卫生非常重要。确保所有器具彻底清洁，并使用新鲜的肉类。还建议熟悉基本的制香肠原则，并考虑采用特定的制香肠技巧。

Half-Life: Alyx. If you feel like you wanted to play half-life but something new, different, and more immersive... This game is all of those things. It features less guns then you'd experienced in the earlier half-life games, but the guns are pretty decent and allow for some creatively challenging gameplay.

Ammo management and generally good skill in combat left me usually reasonably flush with ammunition but the gun reloading and general handling is very good. Might annoy you if you're feel unwilling to deal with cover... as you are squishy, being Alyx instead of Gordon.

Story was pretty solid and sets up for a sequel, perhaps more of the same or more VR experiences. Either way, I enjoyed it and look forward to more.

Will say I had a few crashes while playing, but the saves usually had me right where I crashed, so... not that bad an experience at all. Might just be my inferior graphics card set-up anyway. Hope you enjoy~

I don't recommend this game, but for some reason it is very overrated.

Graphics: Graphics are decent. They aren't overly good or anything but they very much hold up to standard. There are some things that you won't find in most vr games like the liquid inside bottles (not really liquid, just a trick Valve uses but nonetheless impressive). I didn't notice any graphic breaking bugs in the game either. You can grab headcrabs so I guess that's cool. Characters in the game are also well made and hold up to standard.

Gunplay: The only weapons you will use are SMG's, pistols, and a shotgun. They all feel unique in their way but you still get that feeling as if you are shooting every gun as a pistol. You can't punch enemies or grab them until they are dead. Very disappointing actually, I expected there to be more gore in the game but was greatly disappointed with what it had to offer. 

Movement: The movement mechanic is very simple, you can't climb a ladder for fuck's sake, you can teleport to the top or bottom though. Very disappointing. There is nothing more to add about the movement, you don't use your arms for anything but shooting.

Story: The story is cool, I won't spoiler it but it is indeed made well and the game features a variety of interesting puzzles and new unique characters you will meet.

Rating: Overall I give this game 6/10 , not much to add.

just like a lot of people, i waited long years for this one. always suspected its gonna be VR when it comes, but i never expected what they really did after all.

the storytelling and immersion in this game are surreal. its absurd how real the experience feels all aspects combined.
the touch and feel of it is just out of this world. so are the physics. and both artistically and graphically i think that no VR game comes even close as of late 2023. overall this is propably one of the best games i have ever played in general. the feel of its environmental storytelling is beyond words. even though this is primarily a linear game, the once in a while replay value hits hard. you can toy around with the mechanics and physics for ages. or just walk around looking at the world taking everything in piece by piece. or just experimenting with different combat moves and strategies in its sandbox-y shooter environment with lovely puzzles. what i appreciate most is that it does something much smarter than just continuing the cliff hanger we got in EP2. now i try to write my reviews as spoiler free as possible. im the kinda guy who barely watches trailers and likes to go in for surprises more often than not. but what i can tell you while being non specific is that this game does something much more interesting and puzzling with the narrative than just continue where we left of. at first it seems like a not so related prequel to half life 2 but later on the connection gets seriously intense to say the least. some of its own ends are closed here but i absolutely cannot wait to find out what happens next. also make sure you DO play at the very least half life 2 and episodes 1 and 2 before you go into HL ALYX. ideally also half life 1. they are incredible games that all play like they came out yesterday so if you somehow still didnt play them, knock youurself out.
cheers.

thank you valve for your dedication to this amazing franchise and always keeping up with your incredibly high quality standards. your games continue to entice and inspire and i believe this release shows that it can be worth it to be patient and wait in ease for something really great.

Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of a triumph in the realm of virtual reality gaming. Developed by Valve Corporation, this installment in the iconic Half-Life series has set a new standard for immersive gameplay and storytelling within the VR landscape.

Graphics and Immersion: 5/5
The visual fidelity of Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of breathtaking. From the intricate details of the environment to the lifelike character animations, every aspect of the game is designed to draw players into the dystopian world of City 17. The Source 2 engine truly shines, delivering an unparalleled level of realism that enhances the overall immersion.

Gameplay: 4.5/5
The gameplay mechanics of Half-Life: Alyx are a testament to the potential of VR gaming. The intuitive controls, precise interactions, and realistic physics create an experience that feels both natural and responsive. The game cleverly integrates VR features, requiring players to physically reach for items, solve puzzles, and engage in combat with a level of tactility that traditional gaming can't match.

Story and Atmosphere: 4.5/5
True to the legacy of the Half-Life series, Alyx doesn't disappoint in terms of narrative depth and atmosphere. The storytelling is engaging, weaving seamlessly into the existing lore while introducing new characters and plot twists. The oppressive ambiance of City 17 is palpable, and the game succeeds in maintaining a sense of tension throughout the entire experience.

Sound Design: 5/5
The audio in Half-Life: Alyx is a standout feature, contributing significantly to the overall atmosphere. From the haunting echoes of distant Combine chatter to the subtle creaking of dilapidated buildings, every sound is meticulously crafted. The use of 3D audio technology further enhances the sense of space and directionality, adding another layer to the immersive experience.

VR Innovation: 5/5
Half-Life: Alyx pushes the boundaries of what VR can achieve. It not only demonstrates the potential for narrative-driven VR games but also serves as a showcase for innovative design and interaction possibilities within the medium. The game sets a new standard for VR titles and has undoubtedly paved the way for future developments in the industry.

Half-Life: Alyx is a tour de force in virtual reality gaming. It successfully marries the rich storytelling of the Half-Life universe with the immersive capabilities of VR technology. While the need for VR hardware might limit accessibility for some, those with the means to experience it will find themselves transported into one of the most compelling and memorable gaming experiences of recent years. Valve has not only revived a beloved franchise but has also redefined the expectations for what is possible in the realm of virtual reality gaming.

Not gonna lie: first time when I played this game, I understood what Half-Life and other projects mean for Valve. 

It means to them technological revolution at all means. 
Remember HL1 when it first released? Lots of voices around the world told the same thing: it's a revolution!
What about HL2? They introduced Source engine with the best physics possible at the moment. 

The game is not that much about the plot, although the storytelling is amazing...

Simply switching to Source 2 and delivering standard PC experience wouldn't revolutionize gaming. 
But using other delivery methods with fully-immersive environment and one of the best graphic possibilities - that's the revolution and the push to the world of widely known PCVR gaming.

Valve, in general, is a company that opens the door to the future of diversified gaming. When they delivered Steam to us, great physics, Steam controller (although it's a failure from business point, the controller is great), Index helmet, Deck. 

I think with their passion to the revolution and novation, they will be the first ones who will make full support of Neuralink in Dota...

First and foremost, I think this is the most polished VR game ever made. It's not a cut-down experience made to work with VR, it's a full-fledged VR game. Unfortunately, so many years in, that's still the case. There are some issues with weapon handling that could be improved, but a lot of that comes down to bulky and inaccurate controllers.

As for the negatives, I'm not a fan of ammo-scarcity in games, and this game has a TON of it. Weapons don't seem to have enough power to taken anything down without hitting very small hit boxes (again, bulky and inaccurate controllers), so I find myself using a lot more ammo than I would otherwise. And when you do find ammo, it's one mag here, two shotgun shells there, etc. Occasionally, you'll find an ammo box, but that usually means you're about to fight a bunch of enemies, so you'll be out again soon.

The biggest issue I have is with performance. Every so often after the game loads I'll drop down to 10fps, and nothing seems to get it to go back to normal. I'll have to completely shut everything down and start it back up again. Also, even worse, sometimes the game will completely lock up my entire computer to the extent that I have to hard reset. It's the only VR game I have this issue with, and it's a very serious issue. I don't want to have to worry about data corruption every time I run a game.

Half LIfe Alyx is a rare and true AAA title for VR. It may lack multiplayer. And for me imposes way to many restrictions on movement and no jumping, no sprinting. (these things are loved by hard core VR users) I get that some people can't take it, but it feel like I am playing with my feet in sand with even the most free locomotion settings. Many of us VR players want normal jump and sprint. And I personally refuse to ever use teleport in a game. It was almost a deal breaker in this game, since it ruins any fun that can be had in the paltforming sections. I mean you just point and click, really? How is that even fun? IMO Hard mode should force you to use full locomotion with no teleport and real jump. That is what hard core VR people like me want.

That being said this game is a rare gem in VR. Graphics that blew me away every time I put back on the headset. Levels so rich with detail and more physical interactivity that you can find in almost any game. Other than maybe Boneworks. I wish the physics could be used more in combat. You can't hit head crabs with bricks or boards with any real effect other than maybe moving them a little. But there is no denying that this is currently the TOP AAA VR game for PC. Any lover of VR will have a complete blast playing this game. And will be ready to buy #2, 3, 4 of this quailty of immersive VR game. Great job Value !! (note: valve plz less forced "comfort" options. Hard core VR players hate TP and just want to jump and sprint, also you can even have the enemies actually attack us/throw us/lift us up, we want that stuff in VR :)

Half-Life: Alyx Review: Out of Ammo, But Not Out of Fun!

Ladies and gentlemen, dust off your VR headsets and prepare for a trip to the not-so-distant future where ammo is apparently more precious than toilet paper in a pandemic! Introducing Half-Life: Alyx, the game where you constantly feel like you're on a desperate scavenger hunt for bullets. And no, it's not Half-Life 3, so let's just get that out of the way before someone starts a rumor!

In this thrilling VR escapade, you'll be facing off against adversaries, only to look down and realize: "Wait, where did all my ammo go?!" You defeat them, only to run low again. And then you move on, triumphantly... and yep, you guessed it, you're out of ammo. Again. Makes you wonder if the game secretly doubled as a rationing lesson. (I swear I wasn't trying to shoot stars out of the sky, but a gamer can dream, right?)

But don't let the sporadic scarcity of bullets fool you. The graphics? Immaculate. The gameplay? Seamless. The feeling of desperately searching for ammo while an alien is chasing you? Priceless. Or should I say... bulletless?

If you've ever wanted to experience what it's like to be both awed and mildly irritated at the same time, then Half-Life: Alyx is the game for you. The VR mechanics are spot on, and aside from occasionally wanting to scream, "WHERE IS THE AMMO?!", you're in for an authentic and enthralling Half-Life adventure. Dive in, but maybe keep a backup slingshot handy, just in case. 😉

This game is fantastic, one of, if not, the best VR shooter, Hell, VR game ever made. Graphics are incredible with the fancy Source 2 engine, displaying highly detailed character models with impressive facial animation. Physics have been improved greatly, being able to fully show the realistic weight of certain objects. And while certain beloved characters such as Barney and Kleiner don't make a return, we're introduced to a British chap named Russel, who's still as enjoyable as those we've seen in Half Life 2. Plus, and this isn't a spoiler, but it expands on the story despite being a prequel :)
My only gripes with the game is that it's incredibly laggy on slightly lower-end systems, and you'd need the Valve Index to truly experience this game to it's fullest. And while it does make sense to have it be geared for extremely high-end systems and build the game off of the headset your company made, it's frustrating to have to know what graphics card you need to run the game on just the lowest settings and not be bombarded with lagspikes. I use a GTX 1070 on 32 gigs of ram with the Oculus Rift S and can barely get an extremely clear, smooth image.
But despite those, I love this game. It's one of the last games to fully revolutionize gaming as we've reached our limit at this point. Can't wait to see what Half Life 3 will have to offer once we get to that point. Valve isn't very well-known for making games in a small timeframe, but that just shows their dedication. We had almost a whole decade of nothing but updates for Team Fortress 2 and CS:GO. And seeing how they treated TF2 after Jungle Inferno, it's best to assume we have a lot to look forward to in the rest of this decade.

Still by far the best VR game released (at least that I have played) and truly the benchmark for what makes a good VR implementation. The graphics are amazing, the movement options are great, and you can pickup or interact with almost everything. You can even see the liquid in bottles and it behaves as you'd expect, and if you throw a bottle it will smash. These all seem like silly things to comment on, but it's so far ahead of what most other games will do and really lends to the immersion.

Most importantly, this is an actual AAA VR game with a good story and reasonable play time (for once, a game that isn't just a glorified tech demo). On top of that, they have a built in workshop that allow you to play loads of user created mods, some of which are whole games unto themselves! If you have a VR headset and haven't played this yet, what are you waiting for????

Honestly this is one of the greatest VR games I have ever played, it's well worth the $60.

I played on a Quest 2 through cable on the lowest settings, and despite one glitch appearing (When the combine are driving you in the back of their truck, it loaded as an error for a couple of seconds) it ran BRILLIANTLY. 

There's one fixed movement speed to avoid motion sickness, but also an ability to dash around if you need to quickly get somewhere. Climbing up things is smooth, if you ever let go of a ladder it just teleports you to the top. All of the guns are one handed, which is a change I really appreciate, but I can't think of a reason why, I just like it.

It's also one of the best looking games I've played in years. The environment looks real, like these places aren't well kept, only used by the combine who just cares about keeping the humans in check.

Overall, 10/10 game. If you have a VR headset, buy this game. It will make you a fan of the half-life series (at least it did for me.)

Once again Half Life has gone and done something amazing.  Somehow, Alyx has succeeded in nearly every aspect I've ever wanted from a VR FPS.  The combat is clean and the guns feel crisp.  The environments are well designed and enjoyable to play.  It would feel great even in 2D.  But as a VR game it really showcases the Half Life series ability to up the game in insane ways.  Source physics have become almost sane, and somehow this game has some of the best graphics in VR while still being able to run on fairly light hardware.  My only large complaint is the lack of melee, but considering how much VR melee combat tends to feel like swinging noodles around in syrup, I think loosing it is overall the right choice.

[i] Weeks will pass, but the feeling of holding tight to the dear gnome will remain... [/i]

[h3] Introduction [/h3]
To this day, hands down the best PCVR experience the money can buy. Even if you are not familiar with the Half-Life franchise, give it a chance; you will unlikely be disappointed. If you care deeply about the performance aspect and worry if your setup can handle it - the game is highly optimized and rarely causes any frame drops. After all, a refund is always a possibility. The trailer will never do it for you in the same way the game could.

[h3] Story & World Building [/h3]
All the details within make this world feel truly alive, unlike any other VR environment that looks fake at a glance. The pure quality of assets used and clever level design together play a great role in immersing you as a player. The narrative is delivered seamlessly; you are always present in the world, and it actually responds to your actions. Intensive scenes are executed perfectly, and the VR itself adds much more depth than you can ever imagine.

[h3] Compatibility Concerns [/h3]
Being originally designed to showcase the true spectrum of VR interactions Index is capable of, the game holds well when it comes to other headsets and conrollers. Unique features like squeezing the palm of your hand while holding an object were simply rebinded to an action button within your reach. It means that regardless of your current VR setup, the game will adapt and provide as much content as it can without leaving some of it behind.

[h3] Conclusion & Final Notes [/h3]
The magnitude of hard work and dedication that the Valve team put in when making this game can never be expressed enough. It is a unique, mesmerizing, and engaging experience that will last you hours upon hours and will still be able to surprise you, catch you off guard. Words don't do justice at this point, and if you made it this far - treat yourself and explore the world of Half-Life: Alyx to its fullest.

Worth the wait for the most part. A stunning return to one of my favourite universes. Some truly god-like design and world building; driven by a fun engaging cast. Seriously the voice work here is fantastic. It even expands on ideas that never really got explored in HL2. 

Do know going in, it plays a lot more like a survival horror game crossed with a walking sim than the rest of Half Life; and the combine soldiers; while having a superb visual rework are kind of dumb as bricks.  

It does admittingly play it a little safe at points; the monster variety is good but limited; There's only 4 weapons, pacing is excellent but and it could be gone for a few more hours IMO.  

The No-VR mod is damn good for what it it's; yes, it is very janky and crashes at points, but the pure half-life experience is faithfully maintained. Immense credit to the Mod developers for giving many who cannot financially or medically afford to buy what is still just a piece of gimmick tech a chance to experience this game. It’s also super easy to install. 

Highly Recommend

--- NO-VR-MOD review (Work in progress)

I've played like 2/3rds of Alyx on a friends HTC Vive (IIRC), so I know what Alyx is like in VR and It was great!!
But I cannot last longer for like 1 hour at  a time,  because the headset gets too stressful for my neck and it's mentally so much more demanding for me  than 'flatscreen'-games.

---NON-VR-PERFORMANCE
 -- WINDOWS

Then the No-VR-Mod came along (currently V0.9 installer). Under Windows 10 it works great on my RX 7600. The game is playable at HIGH and ULTRA setings at stable 60Hz (probably more but my TFT does not support more FPS).
The Mod turns Alyx in a most seemless NON-VR FPS game. Only issues I had were some minor input-recognition issues on game elements specifically designed for 3D manipulation. 

 -- LINUX
 - PROTON (non-native Linux version)
Under Linux (Ubuntu 23.04) manual installation of the MOD worked only partially for me (no 'Mouse Pointer'/  strange Pointer offset), so I just copied the game files from Windows over into my Linux Steam-library and it worked as expected.
But the performance under Linux is not so good, even with Vulkan. On WIndows 10 I got no problems running with HIGH Performance settings, under Linux I get some unstable 40 to 60 FPS in LOW settings and some more minor loading hiccups (no pop-ins).

- NATIVE LINUX VERSION
I don"t get the menu at the start of the game, so - no show I am afraid.

--- CONCLUSION
So, for all you without Headsets: You can safely enjoy Alyx in non-VR. It's still downright awesome.
Just download the installer and off you go!

A game that I can very clearly see the reasons literally everyone recommended it to me as the first VR game I try.

The game had a lot of fun, really interesting reactions with objects in-game reacting to the world as you'd expect them to. Feeding the little alien rat and drawing phalluses on the whiteboard were pretty much my first indications that I was going to have a good time. Although this type of object reaction doesn't exist in the same amount of detail as the first 2 hours of the game, the times where it continued this trend were truly goofy.

The gunplay was really cool. Though it took a while to get used to as a first VR game, and I learned very early on that saves are your friend for when things go wrong (not very often I have to say this with shooters tbh). Each gun has its own upgrades and styles of reloading that you had to physically reload. It had a perfect balance of immersion and gameplay feel in those aspects. It felt like my ammo was considerably lower at the start of the game, but was then in abundance toward the end. Or maybe I just got better at the game honestly.

Not really into the whole Half-Life lore, the only game I really played extensively was HL-1. But even despite that, Rhys Darby in my ear as Russel made the whole thing a little more lighthearted juxtaposed against the entire world being taken over by the combine. The twist ending was also really good, and made even someone who doesn't care about the lore soyface at their little ending twist. Valve is very good at setting up cliffhanger endings and then never releasing a game afterwards, and they do that really well here too.

All in all though definitely recommend it, as a VR vet or someone who hasn't played VR before in their life. Game is well optimised, had little to no framerate issues, and one of the few games I tried in VR that didn't make me feel like throwing up.

Simply the best VR game ever made. I knew before I played it that it had that reputation. It didn't disappoint. The only thing that is extremely upsetting is that there aren't more games of this calibur. It was well worth the investment IMO. I wanted to play this, I had a very outdated computer. The level of detail is so impressive. I spent many hours just looking around and appreciating the tiny details. I small can of bug spray, when you hold it to your face and read the tiny print, you can see the ingridients and warnings etc. Everything a real can would have.
The single most impressive thing is the physics. I put a spoon into a teacup. it stood up. i put another one on the other side and it also stood up. then i put both spoons on the same side and the cup tipped over. it sounds like an irrelevant thing, but it says so much about the realism in the physics. The gun fights are so fun. Ducking down and laying on my living room floor to hide behind obstacles in the game was very OP and very satisfying.

Although this game isn't exactly new any more, and although VR tech has progressed since the time it was released, and although it may be not quite long enough, and although it may be a bit strange as a Half-Life game... Alyx is quite simply the best VR and immersive FPS and/or RPG experience of the last ten years. Playing this game brings the excitement of playing your first RPG right back to you through the lens of VR and an impressively realistic world. It may not be perfect, but its shortcomings are insignificant when compared to the holes in most other VR titles, and the dialogue, graphics, and slow but heart-racing gameplay make up for the rest.

Alyx is a risk worth taking, and only leaves you wanting more VR content - anything really - produced by professional teams. Right now a lot of VR content consists of either buggy WIPs drawn out for Patreon money or user content-based sandboxes, so let us just hope that Valve and other AAA studios decide to move away from regenerated copy-paste status quo profit bait and into more interesting, immersive experiences like this.

“Half-Life: Alyx” is a triumph in virtual reality gaming. The game takes the beloved Half-Life franchise to new heights with its immersive gameplay and stunning visuals. From the moment you put on your VR headset, you’re transported into a world that’s both familiar and new.

The game’s protagonist, Alyx Vance, is a compelling character whose journey you follow with bated breath. The narrative is engaging and keeps you on the edge of your seat. The developers have done an excellent job of integrating the story with the gameplay, making for a seamless experience.

The gameplay itself is a standout feature. The mechanics are intuitive and make full use of the VR platform. Whether it’s solving puzzles or engaging in combat, every action feels natural and immersive.

The graphics are nothing short of breathtaking. The level of detail in the environments is astounding, making City 17 feel alive and lived-in. The sound design complements the visuals perfectly, further enhancing the immersion.

In conclusion, “Half-Life: Alyx” is a must-play for any VR enthusiast. It sets a new standard for what’s possible in VR gaming and leaves you eagerly anticipating what’s next from Valve. A truly remarkable experience.

Half Life is my all time favorite IP and series, and I'm happy to say I enjoyed Half Life: Alyx. I didn't agree with every creative decision that Valve took with this game, but overall I'm super happy to see Half Life return and I can't wait for newer games in the series.
The gameplay was amazing. All of it is incredibly fun and has Valve's characteristic high level of quality when it comes to level design, puzzles, enemy design. Having to actually manually reload guns and throw grenades adds a unique feel to the game that makes even headcrabs and zombies a legitimate challenge. The Combine especially are a much bigger challenge and have some of the most realistic behavior and tactics I've seen - they really feel like you're fighting actual soldiers. Jeff was a fantastic horror segment, truly a proud successor to Ravenholm. I just love the whole "fungal zombies" idea, so getting some of that in Half Life is just *chef's kiss.*
The story overall was great, it fit well into the HL storyline. As for the ending, [spoiler]at first I was a bit upset about Gman just changing the established timeline so Eli survives, I'm honestly not a fan of that trope. But honestly, the ending doesn't really show anything the Gman hasn't already been shown or implied to be capable of. [/spoiler]
The atmosphere and creative design is where I have a few issues. Everything seems a lot flashier and over-engineered than in previous Half Life games: examples like how the Manhacks glow, all the little bitty moving parts in the Combine charging stations, how a lot of characters have more over the top, exaggerated mannerisms, little stuff like that. Almost feels a bit more like Dishonored - it's not a bad aesthetic at all but I think in the future Valve should steer more towards the Half Life 2 monolithic aespects of the Combine. Not all of it is bad of course; at first I didn't like the new Combine designs but they've really grown on me. Also the humor, to be honest I think some of the humor was overdone, especially for a universe as dark as Half Life. Again, this is all nitpicking, the game still has tons of great charm and excellent little details that I truly appreciate. I think one thing that sort of threw me off was the Source 2 engine; I'm so used to Source 1 that the game almost looked not surreal enough for me lmao - this is just something I'll need to get used to, not a fault of the game at all, and the game is absolutely GORGEOUS, especially at dawn, this game is stunningly beautiful.
The soundtrack, to be honest, I was disappointed by. There were some great tracks, the track for the final Strider battle and the ending credits music were fantastic and fit perfectly. But other than that, the soundtrack was pretty generic, it seemed like something more out of Doom and Hollywood than Half Life 2's pretty distinctive sound.
Overall, I give Half Life: Alyx an 80/100. I'm so, so happy that we got a new Half Life game after all these years, and I can't wait to see what the future of my favorite franchise holds. It's clear that regardless of some aspects of HLA I didn't really like, there's a ton of love and hard work in this game and I appreciate every bit of it. Hopefully a standard PC port comes soon so everybody gets a chance to play this game.
