Despite the hype and the tremendous amount of expectations valve had to deal with at the release of Half-Life Alyx, I'm amazed to say this game lives up to it all. 

An absolute achievement in VR gaming and VR storytelling and a landmark few have come close to surpassing even 3 years later. The combat, the enemies and the environments are all superb. Combat is not as fast as the two previous entries in the series but it makes up for that with much more tactical and methodical gameplay, where every shot matters and positioning is key. 

It's not a perfect experience though, and all my issues come from the fact Valve were afraid not to scare any newcomers off of VR. We lack sprinting, instead of that we can teleport for faster movement, which surprisingly works well. The teleport ability also replaces jumping, but that does not work nearly as nicely as it did for sprinting. 

The arsenal is also very limited as we have only 3 weapons this time. And again in fear of scaring off newcomers we don't have any two handed weapons and no melee combat. None of these issues are deal-breakers since the game is build around all this in mind. The ability to upgrade guns also goes a long way to make up for the limited arsenal.
I do wish they updated the game to add more movement options now that the game has been out for a few years. 

The only real problem with Half-Life Alyx is valve's insistence on not releasing a proper SDK for the game to allow modders to go wild. As we speak there are quite a few good mods and maps, but we won't be seeing a real explosion in modding until something is done about an SDK or better modding tools. 

Anyway in summary Half-Life Alyx may have issues, some in game and some out of it, but it is still unrivaled in the VR space, and absolute 10/10 experience and a must play spinoff/sequel to the Half-Life series.

Best VR experience so far, just amazing. Mechanics are intuitive, easy to learn and properly utilized in the game. You really get your moneys worth, action, story, puzzles, secrets, easter eggs, this thing has everything.

The workshop content is another chapter entirely, I highly recommend testing them after you've completed the core game.

Worth every penny if your rig can handle the performance requirements.

half life alyx is a game that ive known of its existence for quite a while, but ive never really thought about playing it because ive never played any other half life games. but then one day i was looking for VR games to play on steam and i remembered i got alyx for free when i bought my valve index. so i thought "eh, i'll give a try at least"
and i am so glad i did, because this game blew my expectations out of the water. its a really well made linear VR shooter where you traverse through the game, fighting a variety of enemies as you progress, as well as occasionally solving the odd puzzle. one of the things i like about the game was how theres a ton of things you can interact with throughout the game world. theres junk on shelves your can mess with, paintings on walls you can move around and take off the walls, knobs on sinks and tubs you can twist, ECT. sure none of these things are essential to the gameplay, but they really help with the immersion and makes it feel more like a real world. i wish more vr games did this. the game has a large variety of environments you encounter throughout your playthrough. from futuristic alien buildings, to dark dingy sewers, to overgrown abandoned houses, and more. the game has an impressive runtime, having the average casual playthrough being around 10-12 hours, which probably still isnt enough for me to consider it worth its price tag, but i got it for free so screw it.
the game also has these "gravity gloves" which are really intuitive from a VR standpoint. now most vr games can be a bit of a pain to have to bend over or crouch down to pick up everything, some games fix this by letting you "force grab" objects from a certain distance, but the gravity gloves not only solved this problem, they made it fun. you can latch onto any object from pretty much any distance, and flick your wrist to fling it right into your hand. this is done in a way that feels very natural, and enjoyable to do.
combat is pretty well done. theres a variety of enemies that you encounter, but they all require different tactics to fight. some enemies can be killed instantly if you shoot them in a very specific spot, some require to be shot in certain parts in a certain order to kill, and some you can feed explosives to for an explosive death. you have 3 weapons, a pistol, shotgun, and smg. theyre all very well balanced and you never feel like you overuse one, or one gets left out. youre also given grenades, health injectors, and explosive barrels you can shoot.
the story is pretty well done, even as someone who has never played half life before i could still understand the story perfectly fine. i think they wanted to make the game newcomer-friendly so even though they relied on pre-existing story beats from the previous games, but they still explained it for players who dont know or remember it. it had some colorful characters, both likeable and comedic, and the storyline has twists and turns that keeps you wanting to know what will happen next
overall its a great game to play if you have a VR headset. if you got it with your valve index give it a try, but if not maybe wait for a sale if youre going to buy

I purchased this (Half-Life: Alyx  for $1000 and got the Valve Index VR headset/ base stations and hand controls free.  ARE YOU KIDDING ME?  NOTHING is "FREE".

Now that I got that off my chest...hahaha.  

I'm sort of new to gaming and loved it passively throughout my life.  Always wondered about VR and finally jumped in the game and loving it.  

Many gamers I'm sure have tough skins and very seasoned to take everything gaming has to offer.

Well, I tell ya, I was totally unpressed on this Half-Life: Alyx "game".  One thing that got me on this title was that fact it was solely made for VR.  How can that be?  Well, once I set up my system and was ready to go, I fell right into playing this game with both feet in the water and never turning back.  Albeit, I do take many breaks...haha.

You can almost smell the air as you're playing.  You can almost feel the presence of "whatever is lurking".  For me, being weak at heart..HAHA....it's hair raising even to the point at times I have to take off the headset, tell myself it's only a game, put the headset back on and only find myself taking it off again!  The sound track is enough for me to pull off the headset.  HAHAHAHAHAA

This game is an adventure loaded with horror as well as “break time” where you can explore the area if you want.  Even after “killing” your threat(s), there is time to explore and oh man, the DETAIL.  I found myself rearranging the boxes on shelves at times...HAAAAAA

Running your fingers over the screened windows and along the old cast iron heaters brings even more life and realisim to this game as there are details way beyond I could even imagine.  There were/are times where I forget where I am and actually wave the dust from the front of my face only to realized it's all VR.  HOLY COW! Talk about DETAIL!

The lighting is superbly done to where even in low lighted areas, you can see a light source which subtly illuminate surrounding objects even at the correct angles.  In the trains,  similar lighting is so realistic. 

Only thing I found so far, is the writers/programmers could have made a similar lighting effect for Alyx.  She has no shadow whatsoever.

I finally found this as I wondered around in the plaza to the Northern Star.  The "sun" was casting shadows all over the place, so Alyx turns around, looks down, and "NO SHADOW".    Not a deal breaker by all means, but it would have added an extra layer of realism.  

Even Friends were amazed at the relistice and detailed graphics within the game.  During my “downtime” within a segment, inside or out, I would take them on a “tour” of that portion on the game.  I had to hold their hands while the spun around...Hahaha

Overall, if you like this kind of game...THIS is the game.  (like I should know what other games do...hahaha).  I found the comments about the game to be true and spot on.  Even though I have nothing to compare this game to, I would comfortably say, this is the BEST so far. 


This game was already 3 years old at the time I started playing it, I would only imagine VR will be the way to go for certain things of course.  Can't wait to finish this one and start it all over as well as delve into other titles and genres.  

Thanks for reading.
Cheers.

(REVIEW IS SPOILER-FREE!)

[u]FIRST OF ALL: ACCESSIBILITY![/u]
(because i dont see a lot of steam reviews mention it, on any game.)

[list]
[*]game difficulty can be adjusted, whether you want to play easy due to accessibility, or if you still want a bit of a challenge even if youre bad at games! 
[*]captions work great, along with great voice acting that's clear and audible. 
[*]lots of movement required. this is either an upside or downside, depending on how your body is about gettin some exercise. personally made me very achy, very fast, but thats due to my specific chronic pain issues so take it with a grain of salt
[*]big modding community so if you need somethin you can probably find a mod for it somewhere. 
[*]easy-to-learn controls, but may cause issues for those with motor skills/hand-eye coordination problems. still generally do-able though! 
[*]THE GAME CAN BE LOUD!! because theres guns explosions etc. but overall more accessible audio-wise than any other half-life game! (and most first person shooters in general, tbh)
[*]contains various common emotional and sensory triggers (blood/gore, body horror, aliens, loud audio and sudden noises, along with flashing) while none of this is new for the half-life franchise, i think its especially important to mention due to it being a VR title. stay safe, and err on the side of caution if any of this may cause you serious medical issues!
[/list]

^ ive also allowed comments on this review if anyone has other accessibility questions! comments unrelated to accessibility will be ignored, sorry!

[u]OVERALL REVIEW[/u]

quite literally the most beautiful game i've ever played. in so many ways.

in the time that it took me to finish the game over years (due to inconsistent access to vr hardware) it was always so easy to get back into it after being away for a long time. after becoming unable to properly play in the way i used to, i did NOT let that stop me from seeing the absolute gorgeous entry via watching a playthrough on youtube. while it's possible to play without vr with mods, or just watch it online, i guarantee you that they DID go to the absolute fullest when selecting virtual reality as a medium. its genuinely the best vr experience, maybe even game as a whole, known to humanity. without exaggeration. and while its enjoyable in any format you consume it in, i highly encourage use of VR equipment to play this yourself.

after seeing the ending, i woke up the next day back to being obsessed with half life like i was years ago. and now im dead set on adjusting my setup to allow me to play with vr controllers even with my disability and limited hardware from my bed. im not kidding when i say that this game is so beautiful that im finding workarounds for getting it to work on a gaming laptop with outdated hardware just so i can play it again with my disability. 

level design is intuitive, clear, and gorgeous. graphics are gorgeous. overall visual design is gorgeous. game ran great for me, with little to no framerate dropping. lots of fun with both central game mechanics AND story. heart wrenching writing that made me want to throw up from getting emotional about it. easy-to-learn gameplay that never takes long to pick up, no matter how long youve been gone.

my criticisms: jeff scared me. but seriously, the only thing i have is more of a warning that applies to vr in general. take breaks!! 1-2 hour gameplay sessions with 15 min breaks worked best for me. any longer than that and i ended up achy, nauseous, and disoriented due to the heavy action and movement present within the semi-frequent combat areas. 

10/10 game, worth every penny.

Half-Life: Alyx is a monumental masterpiece that redefines the boundaries of virtual reality gaming. Valve has done the impossible by delivering an experience that not only lives up to the storied legacy of the Half-Life series but also sets an unprecedented standard for VR gaming as a whole. From the moment I put on the headset, I was transported into a world that felt so real, so engaging, and so utterly captivating that it's hard to put into words.

The attention to detail in Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of awe-inspiring. Every corner of the game world is meticulously crafted, immersing you in a post-apocalyptic City 17 that oozes atmosphere and authenticity. The visual fidelity is breathtaking, with lifelike textures, intricate environmental design, and lighting effects that make you forget you're in a virtual space. Valve's Source 2 engine is a true marvel, and it's clear that the developers have pushed it to its limits to create an experience that pushes the boundaries of what VR can achieve.

Gameplay-wise, Half-Life: Alyx raises the bar for VR interactions. The game brilliantly leverages the immersive capabilities of virtual reality to make every action feel natural and intuitive. Picking up objects, solving puzzles, reloading weapons – it all feels incredibly satisfying. The physics-based interactions make the world feel tangible, and the level of interactivity is unmatched. Even after hours of gameplay, I found myself constantly amazed by the sheer depth of the mechanics and how well they integrate into the narrative.

Speaking of the narrative, Half-Life: Alyx delivers a gripping story that fills in the gaps between Half-Life and Half-Life 2. Players assume the role of Alyx Vance, a beloved character in the series, as she fights against the oppressive Combine forces. The writing is top-notch, filled with the kind of storytelling and character development that the Half-Life series is known for. The pacing is impeccable, seamlessly blending action-packed moments with quieter, more atmospheric segments that allow you to soak in the world around you.

One of the standout features of Half-Life: Alyx is its innovative use of VR to create tension and immersion in ways that traditional gaming cannot. The suspense of creeping through dark corridors, the rush of frantically defending yourself against enemies, and the heart-pounding encounters with terrifying creatures – all of these are heightened by the VR medium. The game's sound design and spatial audio play a crucial role in this, allowing you to hear enemies approaching from all directions and creating an uncanny sense of presence.

Valve has also shown a commitment to accessibility with Half-Life: Alyx. They've included a variety of comfort options that cater to players with different levels of VR experience, ensuring that everyone can enjoy the game without feeling overwhelmed or nauseous.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Alyx is a monumental achievement in gaming, pushing the boundaries of what's possible in virtual reality. Valve has not only delivered a worthy addition to the Half-Life series but has also set a new gold standard for VR game development. If you own a VR headset, playing Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute must. It's an experience that will stay with you long after you've put down the headset – a testament to the power of immersive storytelling and groundbreaking gameplay.

Pros:

Stunning visual fidelity and attention to detail
Innovative and intuitive VR interactions
Gripping narrative that expands the Half-Life universe
Tense and immersive gameplay unique to the VR medium
Thoughtful accessibility options for all players
Cons:

Requires a VR headset, limiting accessibility for some gamers
Verdict: Half-Life: Alyx is a true masterpiece that sets a new standard for virtual reality gaming. Valve has outdone themselves, creating an experience that's not only a must-play for Half-Life fans but a showcase of the incredible potential of VR as a storytelling and gameplay medium.

Played this with the valve index. I don't know what it feels like to play on any other VR headset, but with the index this was easily the best game I ever played. With some mods the replayability is endless. I played until my legs were so tired of standing, crouching, leaning over edges. Most of the game can be played without pressing any buttons (except for triggers for guns and unloading clips). The grip input on the index controllers are absolutely phenomenal. Tossing grenades, healing, shooting, hiding, crouching, surviving! The story was great; and absolute half life experience. But it's the mechanics that blew me away. VR is no longer just a gimmick. With the index and half life alyx the threshold for true VR gaming on triple A titles has been crossed. This has been the most immersive experience in a game I've ever been a part of.

While many are hopelessly waiting for valve to be able to count to 3 one day, they surprised everyone by making this stunning VR adventure/FPS in the half life universe. No Gordon Freeman in sight, but Alyx is just as good.

Built from the ground up for VR, and only playable on VR, it is a true masterpiece. The graphics are absolutely stunning. I have the luck to have a system that can run this on ultra highest settings and it is incredible. The details, not only in textures, models, but also the maps themselves, are a joy to behold.

The game guides you very nicely through the entire story. And yes, it is very very linear. You don't have many points that let you stray far from the given path, and sometimes that feels a little like a missed opportunity. Some extra rooms, corridors etc on the side would have been nice.

Cans, books, etc,  moves as you tough them. Although not everything is 'touchable' like in bonelabs/boneworks, they found a very good balance.

The biggest 'flaw' I see in this masterpiece, is that the 3 or so guns are not held on your person. And it is a dial menu that lets you select them. This is the only immersion breaking point. I would have liked to see some holsters on your person instead.

But aside that, I can completely recommend this game.

Although I am a huge Half-Life nerd, you don't need to play any of the other games to understand and enjoy the story. The story is told through complex set building and quippy dialogue. Within the first few minutes, I was blown away; that new Valve intro, the massive Striders, the sprawling back alleys of City 17, the first elevator Combine scene, and the first Headcrab scene.

Even with my cheaper, inaccurate Windows Mixed Reality set, I was still able to fully enjoy the experience. Source 2's graphical fidelity, art direction, sound design, and physics are the best in all of VR.

The price being a triple-A $60 is worth it, but consider waiting a sale when it is considerably discounted. However, being a VR experience, it is no replacement for a full "Half-Life 3" PC experience. But being one of the first of its kind, this is the best VR experience you can have right now.

The main issues of the game that I had were fixed extremely quickly after launch. The addition of snap turning and Steam Workshop, and the removal of the disappearing hand bug gave me an impression of Valve's professionalism.

Compared to HL1's nine guns (excluding crowbar and ordinances) and HL2's seven, Alyx simplifies to just three guns, and though I felt it was very inadequate, it was necessary for our current generation of primitive motion controllers. My only big complaint is the lack of the classic Quake-like PvP deathmatch--a mainstay of past titles.

All in all, it was worth it to get a glimpse at the future of gaming, as well as the power of Source 2. Now we just sit and wait for the next big Valve title.

Edit: The next big Valve title is Counter-Strike 2



An Addendum For Us Nerds
2015's Source 2 is not an impressive engine by today's standards. However, some of the effective and innovative, VR-optimized techniques used are:
- PBR textures
- Parallax-corrected cubemaps
- Static-to-dynamic shadow transitions
- Smooth enemy locomotion animations
- Dynamic glass breaking
- Rubikon physics engine
- Fluid shader for bottled beverages
CS2 will add a life-like and robust water caustics shader to the engine.

Let me preface this review by saying I haven't beat it and I'm pretty sure I'm fairly far off from doing so. Usually I try to wait until I complete the initial stories of singleplayer games but I have rare exceptions. This game is amazing. 

The physics are next level in this game, nearly every object can be interacted with, objects have collision with your guns and such. It's so immersive. It's horror fairly horrific in some sections which take place in dark places where you need to use external lightsources to see. The gunplay is fun but not over the top. It's very basic, you just aim, shoot, press a button to remove mag and load the clip it, then slide the slide back to chamber a round. It's that simple but each gun has different mechanics for reloading that are easy and fluent to do. 

The story is the real outlier because it is just.. valve goodness. It is so good and well paced. Do I recommend this game? Surprisingly it's a great game to learn VR and get your VR legs in so I can safely recommend it for ANY players that play VR, new or old.

This game is great. Like the two games in the series before it, it's revolutionary. That's why it's so disappointing that I have to write this negative review. The game doesn't have an optional walking movement system, forcing plays into archaic jumping movements. This is great for those new to VR, but very limiting to those who are experienced. 

The worst offence this game has to offer is it's horrible optimization. Any time there is a large area loaded, the game comes to a screeching, 10 fps halt. The only fix for this is to load your save. However, half the time you do this, the game will completely freeze in the loading screen. My right lens flickers on and off for the 5 minutes it's loading, and then the game either crashes and then freezes your computer, or finally loads you back into the game, completely stable(for now).  This is not hardware dependent, as I've had this problem on my computer since release. I met the minimum specs then, and more than surpass them now, but the issue remains. 

This is an amazing game that sets the industry standard for VR, but hasn't gotten the TLC it's needed since release to polish out the serious flaws it has. The story is great, the characters are well written, the gunplay is engaging, and the world is fun to explore. It's terribly saddening that the game is nearly unplayable in the second half, because that's where the game shines most.

its 5am and i just now figured out why i couldnt open the fkn menu for the past hours of my life. IF YOURE LEFTHANDED: GUESS YA FUGGED! 

Using a pico 4, being left handed and playing this game will result in y, x, b and a no longer working, thus the menu wont even open to switch it back. And guess what, in the main menu: you cant change preferences, so the actual changes i wanted to make are now impossible. GJ valve, 3 years later and ya didnt learn shid.

edit: 
Anyway, I have found one workaround for now, which is to go to Program Files\Streaming Assistant\driver\bin\win64\RVRPlugin.ini and change controllertype=3 to controllertype=1. This makes the Pico software "emulate"/pretend the controllers to be Rift CV1 controllers (as opposed to Pico/Quest 2 controllers by default).

I think some SteamVR games can't quite handle newer generic controllers yet, so this fallback is a workaround.

Half-Life: Alyx is, even 3 years after its release, one of the best VR games out there. It is clear that the developers went all out on this game. The story, the mechanics, the environment, the interactions, puzzles and hidden secrets make the game feel very alive.

I would consider the game more an adventure rather than a FPS. The game houses 3 different guns you can upgrade as the play the story. Unfortunatly the game has no melee wepons for you to use. Besides weapons and grenades you are equiped with a set of Gravity-Gloves, a special set of gloves that allows you to pull in items from around you. While the gloves are not as obviously usefull like a gun, they can be used in a lot of creative ways to help you, both in and out of combat.

The movent the game offers are both locomotion and teleport. Crouching is done by, well, crouching. Jumping is however, not part of the game. 

The story takes place in a city you won't travel far in. Map wise is seems like a short walk but the levels are plentyfull. On the streets,  though the building, metrostations and even further underground you will face many different environments on a play-through. The story is intense and well-paced. Everywhere you find silly humors and funny achievment challenges. 

Half-Life: Alyx is a must play for those who have a VR set. And when you do get to play the game, say hi to Jeff for me.

Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute VR gem that has redefined the possibilities of gaming in virtual reality. As a fan of the Half-Life series, stepping into Alyx's shoes was a dream come true. The attention to detail, immersive environments, and seamless gameplay mechanics left me awestruck from start to finish.

The game's narrative is gripping and seamlessly fits into the Half-Life universe, providing new insights and depth to the story. The puzzles are ingeniously designed, making use of VR to challenge both your wits and reflexes. Each encounter with enemies feels intense and strategic, pushing the boundaries of what VR gaming can achieve.

Graphically, Half-Life: Alyx is a showcase of VR capabilities. The level of realism in the world, from the smallest objects to the grandest vistas, is jaw-dropping. The sound design further enhances the immersion, with every creak and whisper adding to the suspenseful atmosphere.

Valve has truly outdone themselves with Half-Life: Alyx. It's a game that demands to be experienced by any VR enthusiast and a must-play for Half-Life fans. This is not just a game; it's a landmark achievement that sets a new standard for VR gaming. Kudos to Valve for delivering an unforgettable journey that will have you craving more.

Let me make this *very* clear. Half-Life Alyx is a perfect game. There is nothing quite like actually using your hands to physically block a headcrab from attacking you, or actually hiding behind cover or bending down to avoid gunfire from Combine Soldiers. The ending was *really* unexpected. Not gonna say what just because it's (very obviously) spoilers for the game, although the game *has* been out for the past 3 years. The fact that this game also has Source 2 Film Maker, Hammer and other Source engine development tools along with a workshop that allows people to add simple maps, model replacements (or even new models for use in S2FM) is amazing. Valve really tried when making this game. Genuinely, if you have the money and a VR, try this game. Or even if you just have the money! someone made a NoVR mod for this game so you don't need one! Although, it does *really* remove the fun from the game. short version of this review: fun game, headcrabs are silly, 10/10!

A good example of how to make a VR shooter properly, and a continuation of the Half-Life series.
But it's over-hyped. For the first half an hour it's impressive, but after that it plays just like any other shooter - not something I expected from VR. 
Shooting with your hands in games is an old idea. As they say, "Everything new is well-forgotten old".
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2837745276
'90 arcade machines had physical guns, for 2 players. NES/Famicom, PlayStation 1 had lightgun games. Time Crisis is one of the good examples. Not only is it the same principle, but it's also cheaper and better. Instead of using this expensive helmet and clunky controllers to shoot a gun with shaking hands, you get an actual physical gun to shoot things from the screen (you might buy the big screen). And it's feels great. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LSgwlemX_Oc&ab_channel=JohnRiggs
You can make it so on PC through emulators, by the way.
So why all the fuss with VR? Just make a new Valve lightgun, which will be accessible to many people because it's a very simple (cheap to produce) device, and revive the genre of lightgun shooters.

Without a doubt the best VR game I've played. 

Much like with Half Life 2, it feels like Valve have really invested the time (and considerable expense) to push the boundaries to see what could be accomplished with cutting edge technology. Graphically its outstanding, the gameplay is fun and incredibly immersive. The story is simple, but well executed and paced.

The journey from start to finish took around 18 hours for me, although better players may be able to get through it in a few hours less. 

My one criticism isn't really a critique, but the horror sections are incredibly tense and utterly terrifying. This is a testament to how good Valve were at implementing them, but also it was too much for me personally as I don't have the stomach for stuff like that. 

Strongly recommend, this will be the blueprint for serious VR games in the future.

It's an incredible game that's ruined with many unfortunate choices on the devs part. There's only a few problems I have but they're pretty big in my opinion. First, there's no run button or running of any kind. WTF!? This is a game that really requires it; a game where you're constantly running (walking?) away from horrible creatures. A huge fu ckup. Not sure what the pathetic excuse was because it wasn't because it wasn't possible. Second, they put a flashlight on one hand and the gun on the other with no option of putting the light on the same hand as the gun or as an attachment to the gun itself, whatever so long as the light points to where I'm aiming. Again, WTF!? This was another huge blunder that has so far ruined the game for every place that requires a light. The light is a piece of crap too. One of those I'll point a narrow bright beam that leaves it completely dark outside the tiny diameter beam so I'm constantly pointing it frantically all over the place and when you move it the graphics are so awesome that the shadows in the light are annoying, constantly bouncing around with the frenetic searching. PUT THE LIGHT ON THE GUN!!! Idiots, seriously, how can they spend so much time and effort to create something so grand and to ruin it with stupid choices that make no sense. To completely eliminate basic controls and logical, possible options. Then there are the standard VR complaints that go with whatever system you have. I have a Rift and I can't alter the height of the ground, so my VR ground is always a foot or so below the real ground. Lucky Rift S and Quest owners have a simple option in the settings. Us that bought early and supported them first have been ignored and sh it on by oculus and meta for not buying a newer system. So I can't touch or open anything that's below my floor. I've only just started and I'm sure there's going to be more complaints.

for a game that is deliberately telling people that its not half life 3, and is therefore not going to be as groundbreaking has half life 3 would be, it still features great game design and use of vr's capabilities with features that wouldnt be possible in a 1st person shooter. such small and intricate spaces meant to be explored up close instead of vast open areas, seamless interaction with objects and puzzles (although they do get stale by the late game) that feels natural because of the way the hands can be controlled, and cover based shooter combat that is actually fun without being as overwhelming as an actual war.

the gravity gloves are a really good choice for the most important specific action the player preforms in the game because the average office or bedroom is of course not as large as the in game environments, so the gloves allow the player to interact with distant objects and pick things up without it being as tedious as in real life and breaking the pacing. additionally they perfectly fit into the half life universe thematically.

and even while making a soup of good game mechanics the devs didnt forget that the purpose of vr is immersion. so even though my janky computer cant handle the graphics without lagging out my quest 2 every 20 minutes i was still immersed in the beautiful environments because i find alien flesh growths beautiful. even if the game had no story and was just called explore abandoned buildings simulator ft. a hundred headcrabs i would still give it a good rating.

and that is because the story isnt the focus. its pretty simple and easy to follow on its own but in the context of having played half life 2 is probably a genius retcon type situation that solves the cliffhanger of episode 2 and creates a new one for the story of a new game to use. that being said i havent played half life 2 yet and i dont fully know how im meant to interpret the story even after watching an explanation video so i can write this review accurately.

the game doesnt have any outstanding drawbacks reducing its quality and the largest issue for me was the small amount of content and little replayability, but both of these issues can be fixed with mods which the game openly supports in the form of custom maps and addons.

so while i dont recommend spending $400 or so just to play this game (or any individual game), it is a must have for anybody that already has access to vr.

Cornflake Corn Cake


Prep Time:
10 mins
Cook Time:
25 mins
Cool Time:
15 mins
Total Time:
50 mins
Servings:
8

Ingredients
1 teaspoon butter to grease pan

1 large egg

1/2 cup white sugar

6 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted

1/2 cup plain yogurt

1/2 cup milk

1/2 cup cornmeal

1 cup all-purpose flour

1 teaspoon salt

1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder

1/4 teaspoon baking soda

2 1/2 cups cornflakes, divided


Directions
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease a 9-inch round cake pan generously with 1 teaspoon butter, and place a circle of parchment in the bottom. 

Whisk egg and sugar together in a bowl until light and fluffy, about 1 minute. Whisk in melted butter, yogurt, and milk until combined.

Add cornmeal, flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda to egg mixture; whisk until dry ingredients are moistened. Fold in 2 cups of the cornflakes with a spatula. Transfer batter to the prepared pan, and smooth the top.

Scatter remaining 1/2 cup cornflakes evenly over the top; press in lightly with your fingers.

Bake in the preheated oven until a skewer inserted near the center comes out clean, about 25 minutes.

Cool cake in the pan for 15 to 20 minutes before removing to a plate. Cool completely before serving with fresh fruit or a fruit sauce.

Incredible experience, it's easy to tell that a ton of care and time went into this. Left me hungry for more.

[Spoilers] Since there's so much that's good about HLA I'm going to describe the problems that mostly everyone seems to gloss over.

The story being rewritten in a short amount of time, resulting in something that's honestly very bland and could have been a lot better, the twist of it being Gman in the vault was the most obvious thing ever with no attempt to keep it a surprise, the ending being a retcon of Ep2's ending is really stupid. 
They also have a part where you watch the shadow of a lady from the cut story communicating with an Advisor, this gives the impression that she's going to be revealed later as some essential character to the plot but no, she has no relevance.

The Jeff area is cool but I personally felt it went on too long, it should have had some other segment in the middle to break it apart.
I also think Jeff has a garbage design, he just looks like a generic sc-fi humanoid monster thing, it would have been better if there was some connection to headcrab zombies incorporated in the design, something like the poison zombie from HL2 and the Gonome from Opposing Force.

The Antlion's suck, the way they walk looks stupid and the way you fight them makes you feel like your playing a rail shooter in an arcade and ruins your immersion, I'm not sure how they could have handled them but they didn't do it well.
The design of the Antlion worker also sucks, instead of using the superior design from Ep2 they went with something that mostly looks like a recolor of the normal Antlion.

Enemies are way too bullet spongy, it's insanely annoying, it takes so many head shots just to kill a grunt.

The lack of melee combat, not only that but you can't even damage enemies with props, not even head crabs, meaning if you run out of ammo you can't do anything.

I'm honestly not a fan of the arsenal, It's very small and you don't get to pick up the soldiers weapons which sucks.
I also get they wanted everything to be usable with one hand but I would have much preferred a pump shotgun.
I have astigmatism so my right eye is very blurry and makes it hard to aim since I'm right handed, so I tend to get the Laser Sight upgrade, the problem for me is that the same upgrades on different weapons are priced differently, so if I want the laser sight on the shotgun its the cheapest upgrade for only 10 resin, but on the pistol it's the most expensive for 35, kind of annoying.

From my limited experience playing VR games, this was easily the best one I've ever played. The story is good, the gameplay works flawlessly and the graphics are amazing. Every level is detailed with loads of things to discover and interact with.
Would definitely recommend.

This review is 3+ years late but I was thinking about this game again and I needed to jot my thoughts down.

I got a VR headset, a 1st gen Vive, originally for trying out this new, unexplored territory of virtual reality gaming and what it could offer. I played a few games, all of which were really good in their own right but had their flaws... then I played Alyx. 

Alyx absolutely [i]ruined[/i] ruined VR games for me. Not because it's bad, but because it's so unbelievably f--king amazing. Alyx makes you feel totally connected to its environment through pretty much very small detail; how guns work, how characters in person interact with you, how you as the player interact with the environment through random things you can touch, puzzles, and how you have to actually throw stuff around off shelves and scavenge for supplies, how you have to traverse the world, and so much more. When you're behind a pillar taking pot shots at a large amount of combine, or trying to find ways to slow down zombies to buy yourself time to reload or scavenge, it really feels.like you're there doing these things. The world feels real which makes it all the more wild when the world starts breaking the rules of reality.

I don't want to spoil too much but, essentially, this game takes full advantage of its medium to deliver single handedly the best VR experience pretty much ever. And it's completely spoiled me. No other VR game comes close to being as engaging as Alyx does; not even 3+ years later. And it makes all the older VR games not fun to play because you just want to recapture that same feeling of awe, wonder, and engagement that Alyx provides.

You need to play it. You just have to. But be warned it'll ruin any other VR game for you.

Half life Alyx has to be THE BEST VR game available right now. Not because of its gameplay or mechanics (although they are really great and probably the most refined on the market) but because of the story.

WORTH IT.

If you're new to VR, do yourself a favor: DON'T make this your first VR game. You're setting the bar too high, it'll ruin all other VR titles for you. Nothing else comes close to the level of polish, interactivity, gameplay, and storytelling of HL: Alyx. Go play Virtual Rick-ality or something. Come back to this game after you're bored with all of the crap.

Years late to the review, but having finally gotten my ultra high-def wireless VR perfected with a 7900XTX and Virtual Desktop, it was time to revisit Alyx.

In short, the hype is real and reviews are true. There is simply nothing on the market like Alyx. It is THE defining VR game. To the point where... think of your favorite 10/10 VR game... and realize Alyx is still way above that scale. You cannot rate it against other VR games. It's like being 3 years old at Disneyland. An untouchable, mesmerizing, unique experience. You believe you're in it. A smile creeps across your face as the Combine death sound plays, a life-sized Vortigaunt talks to you, and a [redacted] or a [redacted] or [REDACTED] is in your face. The immersion is so far above anything else and the storytelling and pace is classic Valve. I don't know why they're so frightened of public response to HL3 because Alyx proves they haven't lost a step.

It is nearly correct to say "do not buy VR without buying Alyx". You need it. It is what VR should've been and should continue to be (and evolve from). And I'd highly recommend Virtual Desktop too if your local wifi can handle it -- makes it much more enjoyable.

Half-Life: Alyx is an incredibly captivating and immersive virtual reality game that has left players in awe. The attention to detail and the level of realism achieved in the game is truly remarkable. From the stunning graphics to the intricately designed environments, every aspect of Half-Life: Alyx has been carefully crafted to create an unparalleled gaming experience.

One of the standout features of Half-Life: Alyx is its perfect blend of gameplay mechanics and storytelling. The game seamlessly combines elements of first-person shooting and puzzle-solving with a rich and engaging narrative, keeping players on the edge of their seats throughout the entire experience. The intense moments of gunfights are balanced with moments of exploration and discovery, creating a well-rounded gameplay experience that appeals to a wide range of players.

Moreover, the Gunman Contracts mod for Half-Life: Alyx adds an exciting twist to the already fantastic gameplay. This mod introduces a new level of challenge and strategy by incorporating contract-based missions into the game. Players are tasked with eliminating specific targets within a given time frame, requiring them to carefully plan their approach and make tactical decisions. The mod enhances the replayability of the game, offering new and unique experiences even after completing the main storyline.

In summary, Half-Life: Alyx is not only a technically impressive game but also a masterclass in storytelling and gameplay design. Its attention to detail, realistic visuals, and engaging mechanics make it an absolute must-play for any fan of the Half-Life series or virtual reality gaming in general. With the added excitement brought by the Gunman Contracts mod, the game becomes even more compelling and guarantees hours of thrilling gameplay.

This game does not fucking want you to play it. I've never seen a more insufferable opening in my life – you walk slowly through empty environments and set pieces while one of the most cretinous radio sidekick characters I've ever heard delivers lines that never fail to irritate. And he does not shut up. Alyx isn't really any better – almost every single line is some boilerplate snippy response. She's ingenuine. 

After an hour of pain, the game trusts you to be able to shoot enemies, and it turns into a very simplistic first person shooter. It seems designed for people who have never worn a VR headset before. Compare this to the VR mod for Half Life 2 and it's just insulting... where was I at this point in that game? Bashing those flying drone enemies with my crowbar in the sewer? Paying utmost attention to my surroundings because of the multiple types of threat that had been introduced at this point? Here it's walking forward slowly and shooting headcrabs with the pistol when they appear.

Eventually, I did find an encounter that posed some challenge; multiple headcrab zombies came after me in a fairly tight arena. Perfect time to load some bullets into the shotgun, so I press the button to open the shotgun up, grab some ammo from the shoulder, load it into the gun... Oh, not only did the ammo not grab but the gun inexplicably closed when I performed the loading action. I tried again two more times. Nope. Fourth time's the charm, but two shots isn't enough, so I went for a fifth attempt... nope. I threw the headset off as I heard the headcrab zombies chewing Alyx to bits. Good. It's what she deserves. Let's hear her try to be sarcastic when her head's been gnawed off. Stupid fucking bitch.

I've mentioned the character's slow walk a few times. For some reason, this game is designed with the expectation that you use teleporting. I despise this. I don't ever want to teleport in a VR game. By all means, include it for people who need it, but why gimp the player character's smooth walking speed so they have to use it? And why design the game without a normal jump? I want to feel some sort of immersion here, isn't that largely the point of VR? The moment you start warping around you might as well pull the headset off and play on the monitor because any illusion of being in a real place is gone. It surely wouldn't be difficult to give the player these options. Faster walking speed, a sprint and a jump. Maybe there's a mod that does this. I hope so.

I realise I'm only a couple hours in but it was disappointing enough that I brought myself to write this. It feels like the entire reason this game gets credit is because it's a big budget VR game. To be fair, it does look nice. I'm playing on a Pico 4 with dynamic res scaling turned off and 3000-something horizontal and vertical pixels per eye (via Virtual Desktop's Godlike mode) at 90FPS using an RTX 4080, streaming through the router. I'm beyond the point of being amazed by seeing depth in VR, sadly, so I wasn't walking around and poking my head into every surface, but I probably would have a few months back when I got the headset.

I'll continue to play the game but I have a feeling my opinion won't change... I feel as if the game has shown its intentions and probably will continue to be designed in this geriatric kind of way.

Half-Life Alyx continues to be the most developed and ambitious VR game made to this day, in 2023. Across all VR platforms and the PC that exist as of right now, Valve managed to not only release a new installment 13 years after the last Half-Life title with a twist that re-wrote the end of Half-Life 2 Episode 2, but also combine everything I constantly miss about VR games - fluid gameplay in all actions with polished technical elements, all into one package.

I'm particularly fond of the Gravity Gloves, which are super quick to learn and super easy to use. It's not on a level like Half-Life 2's sandbox gameplay with it's Gravitron, but still allows for cool moves in the world. Sometimes foregrounded physical objects that you accidentally pull towards you can be the reason you get frustrated when using them, but those moments are pretty rare.
And speaking of physical objects: Every object in the world can be interacted with as you would expect in real life: Understandable, with weight, sometimes requiring two-handed actions. I found myself very often just playing around with rattling a box of matches near my ear to hear them moving in the box or just throwing and jiggling cardboard boxes around. It's a lot of fun.

The weapons serve their purpose in the world, although I would have liked to see a rudimentary melee weapon to knock down wooden slats or headcrabs, even though i can sort of understand why it is missing in the world because it can make inventory management a whole lot easier, taking away the situation Alyx is in. But a pipe you can smack something like 3 times with would've been cool nonetheless. What i dislike about the weapon selection is the pistol, which like in many VR games, takes the design of the 1911. We've had enough games that use this as a standard. Other than that, the game shifts the focus from the pistol being the main weapon to the SMG in the second half of the game with the shotgun being the weapon which is the most coolest out of them, but also the one barely used because of how few shotgun shells you find for it.
The multi-tool is cool and is also well incorporated into the game world.

The story is well-written and i liked to experience it while playing, although the connection to Half-Life 2 Episode 2 in this game makes me want to see another game in the franchise again. Normally, when people beg Valve for another Half-Life game, i often roll the eyes, but now Valve brought it up to themselves with the ending. Characters in the world are also very well designed, have amazing voice actors and body motion within the world, with the exception of Alyx' voice. Russell is normally a character i'd despise of in real life, but through the conversations i had with him, i started to like him more and more. The conversations with Eli are often only "I miss you baby" and "I can't believe it". A little bit uncanny is the Vortigaunt's mouth when speaking, since i was so used to the design in Half-Life 2.

The game world is very well designed and fun to move around in, with the only thing in it that i can't understand being the existence and placement of resin balls which are used for weapon upgrades, or the fact that there is always ammunition scattered around and on some people and ONLY the ones YOU need, which makes the feel of the world a little bit out of place. SMG rounds being found somewhere is fine, since it's a weapon actually used by someone else than you, but finding shotgun shells and pistol magazines when seemingly no one else has a weapon like it doesn't make a lot of sense to me.

But even with little logical mistakes or irritating design choices - at least in my eyes - the game is a must-have for everyone who owns a capable PC and a VR headset. The community-made campaigns, especially Levitation, are also incredibly well-made, making them the big cherry on top of your dessert. And especially in a sale for about 24 euros, which is a bit more than Blade & Sorcery or Pavlov VR outside a sale, it's totally worth it. Welcome to the world of Half-Life: Alyx, an immersive virtual reality (VR) game that pushes the boundaries of storytelling, gameplay mechanics, and the overall gaming experience. Developed by Valve Corporation, this highly anticipated addition to the Half-Life series takes players on an unforgettable journey as Alyx Vance, an iconic character in the Half-Life universe. Prepare yourself for a mind-bending adventure filled with intense combat, stunning environments, and a gripping storyline that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

Game Mechanics and Combat:
Half-Life: Alyx offers an innovative blend of first-person exploration, puzzle-solving, and visceral combat. Using the power of VR, players can physically interact with the game world, pick up and examine objects, and even manipulate the environment to overcome obstacles. The intuitive controls provide a seamless experience, allowing for precise aiming, quick weapon switches, and strategic movement.

When it comes to combat, players will face a variety of formidable enemies. Armed with an array of weapons, such as the iconic gravity gloves, players can grab, throw, and manipulate objects to take down foes. From intense firefights to stealthy takedowns, the combat in Half-Life: Alyx offers a perfect balance of action and strategy, ensuring players feel fully immersed in the heat of battle.

Environment and Character Abilities:
Step into the dystopian city of City 17 like never before. With stunning VR graphics and meticulous attention to detail, Half-Life: Alyx transports players into a beautifully crafted world. Explore richly designed environments, ranging from dilapidated buildings to underground laboratories, all teeming with life and interactivity.

As Alyx Vance, players will possess a host of special abilities. Utilize the gravity gloves to interact with objects from a distance, enabling creative solutions to puzzles and combat encounters. Alyx's keen intellect and resourcefulness make her a formidable protagonist, as she navigates the treacherous environments and unravels the mysteries surrounding the Combine forces.

Player Weapons, Story, Enemies, and Bosses:
Arm yourself with an impressive arsenal of weapons, each with unique characteristics and attachments. From the versatile pistol to the powerful shotgun, players can upgrade and customize their loadout to suit their preferred playstyle. Experiment with different weapon combinations and adapt to the ever-changing challenges that lie ahead.

The story of Half-Life: Alyx serves as a prequel to the events of Half-Life 2. Dive deeper into the Half-Life universe as Alyx Vance, alongside her father Eli, uncover secrets and embark on a mission to save humanity from the oppressive Combine regime. Engage in intense encounters with a diverse range of enemies, including Combine soldiers, vicious alien creatures, and imposing mechanical monstrosities.

Prepare yourself for epic boss battles that will test your skills and strategic thinking. Confront towering adversaries and unravel their weaknesses, utilizing your wits and arsenal to overcome seemingly insurmountable odds. These encounters are not only visually stunning but also provide a thrilling and memorable experience.

Controls, Graphics, and Audio:
Half-Life: Alyx takes full advantage of VR technology, providing players with intuitive controls that enhance immersion and responsiveness. With smooth locomotion, snap turning, and various comfort options, players can tailor their experience to their preferences.

Featuring stunning graphics, Half-Life: Alyx sets a new standard for visual fidelity in VR gaming. The level of detail and realistic lighting effects make every corner of City 17 come alive, captivating players from the very first moment. Combined with an atmospheric soundtrack and expert sound design, the audio further elevates the immersion, drawing players deeper into the world of Half-Life.

Man I really wish Valve would make an official NoVR update/addon for Alyx
This was an absolute blast, played with the NoVR mod by the GB_2 team, and it worked well enough, but has issues currently.
I might be in a minority of HL fans but personally I wasn't a fan of the Episodes 1&2, they were a bunch of wheel spinning ending in sour cliffhangers, I always just feel like replaying HL2 and then ignoring the Episodes over the last two decades. Alyx, and the plot developments it has, it's own cliffhanger, redeems those episodes for me, and I really really wish Valve won't just again stop development for another two decades before we see the next entry.

Even outside of VR, I think Alyx is a great game.
What the modders trying to translate Alyx VR into NOVR need to understand is that Alyx is a lot more Survival Horror mechanically than just vanilla Half-Life FPS, stop trying to force Alyx into the mold of HL1/2 and instead look at Amnesia/RE.
All the weapon upgrades and much more intense scavenging, the way enemy encounters, AI and combat environments are set out, your puzzles and environmental interactions.
If the modders would just copy the homework of Resident Evil 7/8 & Amnesia/SOMA in how you interact with objects/environments, how you move and aim and shoot, inventory system and HUD implementations, then I feel like Alyx would have been perfectly translated to a normal flatscreen experience without losing its core identity.

As it stands, Alyx with the current versions of NOVR mods are incomplete experiences less because of what lofty "immersion" is lost from VR but more because they are simply put unfinished:
-Half of weapon upgrades are straight up disabled because modders couldn't implement them mechanically or visually.
-Environmental interactions are buggy and limited (hitting "E" doesn't even always register, can't interact with all objects, only vanilla HL2 style interaction)
-Puzzles are downright missing and "autocompleted" when you interact with them (This can result in confusion with progression, as you aren't following power lines but wondering what on earth you now need to go and interact with, you can easily sequence break/softlock this way)
-Sprinting is half-baked (if it took a page from RE, you'd have faster sprinting but no shooting, and normal movement with shooting but inaccurate, instead current sprint is barely faster than normal speed which is also surprisingly low)
-Jumping is required for normal traversal as you collide with incidental debris, jumping puzzles are half-baked as you can't pinpoint jump easily or collide with ceilings-- You WILL need noclip still in some places.

Still, with the frustrating limitations of the current NoVR mods and their direction, I still really enjoyed my time with HL Alyx.

The story, without going into spoilers, is just in my opinion something HL needed after all this time to revitalize that spark, to add a twist to the plot developments we've seen, and the execution of those developments, even without fancy VR, still were powerful.
The gameplay, I envision would be really, really fun, if it just handled better, and I can see that ideal flatscreen translation in my mind, where Alyx controls more like Ethan Winters in RE7/8, she can sprint fast, but needs to slow down or ideally stop to get proper accurate aiming with her pistol/SMG/shotgun, and thus getting the lasersight upgrades, the reflex sight upgrades, would feel impactful, they'd help and be meaningful improvements to aiming like they would literally in RE games (see lasersight literally in RE4R). Alyx's "wristpockets" would be a smaller but still important inventory system that you'd need to manage, and if you'd adapt the weapon wheel of VR into noVR, you could add to the UI the wrist pocket slots from where you could then pull the items you'd have (currently in noVR by BG_2 you can only store 2 health syringes, no grenade tradeoff, no random items like for Russell the vodka bottle - & weapon selection is the crude HL1/2 method of cycling, then clicking to confirm, why??? You only have a pistol, shotgun, SMG, just cycle through those without a need to click!).

Even in a flatscreen noVR experience, just walking in the environments was really entrancing, because they had to put effort in to making it all look and feel immersive in VR, it is bound to spill over to a noVR experience as well, not many regular FPS games where entering a boring room with some shelves and a desk and a corpse will have you just turning the place upside down interacting with everything before moving on, it still is fun to look at the highly detailed props and decals and vistas, and exploration, scavenging is just as fun, to find the right angle to look at something to see the obscured little loot, resin, ammo, whatever, just rewarding you constantly for observation.
The mood, atmosphere, with environmental sounds and the music, the effects, the improved lighting and materials, just standing in a place listening and watching feels pretty great.
It all holds up really well on zooming in and such, City 17 has never looked more impressive, and I just really liked the Quarantine Zone as a place, something that was kind of missing from HL2, a place that still is kind of a no-man's-land of xen infestation and combine trying to clear it out but half-heartedly. Shame no sonic doggos or bullsquids still didn't make a comeback. 

Combat, is funnily enough almost better than HL2, it has more to do with the fact that current HL2 is broken, Valve in their infinite wisdom while "upgrading" the Source engine over the years broke many features that were present on release in 2004, lots of visual touches, and gameplay ones like enemies used to twitch from every singe bullet shot, but after the 2009 & 2013 updates a lot broke, and Valve haven't bothered to fix anything except a handful of tiny things in 2019/20 when they made HL2 work on the Deck.
Alyx you have a lot of fun enemy animations, staggers, twitches, flinches, stuns, limping, their death ragdoll reminds me of FEAR, mixing animations blending into a ragdoll. So even with a limited arsenal of a pistol, SMG, shotgun & grenades, still, they felt a lot better than their counterparts in HL2.

Performance was rock-solid, even with only 4GB VRAM, a laptop with an i5-11400H, 3050RTX & 16GBRAM it ran capped 60fps on Ultra settings minus texture resolution on 1024 which still looked surprisingly decent even on closeups. You can modify stuff with commands easily, like the bloom effect was a bit too strong so I disabled it with r_post_bloom. 
Honestly kind of impressive how well it ran while looking gorgeous, but you do see some limits, aggressive culling, shadows that rematerialize when you look around, LODding even rather close, but nothing super distracting.

I wish Valve would make the game even more open to modding, if that would help at least a bit with stuff like making a noVR mod faster more feature-complete.
Or just make the noVR patch/addon themselves, just take a few pages from Amnesia/RE Valve, you already technically did in the game itself.

Alyx & Entropy Zero 2 made me crave for so much more HL stuff, Valve, get on it (& fix HL2 already, preserve 2004 legacy features like 343i did for Halo 1&2)
If I have downside for Alyx itself and not just the noVR mod, it's that it's 67 gigabytes of space for an 8-15hour campaign, so reinstalling this for a replay will require a high threshold as I choose what space to clear and games to uninstall to make room for this.

I would say if you're not a hardcore HL fan then maybe wait for the noVR mods to become more polished and feature-complete, but personally I just liked the game too much so a thumbs up from me.

With that said - this game is probably the only valid reason for you to buy the VR set
Unless you dont have enough budget/big enough room/problems with wearing such a thing

But since NoVR mod (on ModDB) is working pretty great and will have neat updates in the future, we gotta look into that deeper.

[h1]Main features[/h1]
Visuals, immersion and the huge level of details in level design - if you like this stuff - you will love this game. With or without VR - this game takes you in and you will struggle to leave.
Liquid physics, lighting, props everywhere, great optimization on an average PC. There a lot to tell.
Basically, its a very neat tech demo for Source 2.

[h1]But you are not Gordon Freeman and you do not have the HEV suit[/h1]
Now, if you came here for amazing gun blazing gameplay - dont expect a lot. You will shoot stuff from time to time, solve some basic puzzles(some are not present in Non-VR atm), some of which will require a standart awareness of your surroundings. Frankly, Half-Life 2 wasn't that great with shooting either, but in this game, if you play Below Hard - you will be bored, probably. On hard though - enemies are just bullet sponges. Although its cool that almost every enemy has a little trick to beat him fast like - shoot a propane tank, a parasite, or throw a grenade, or wait for him to reload etc, etc. There's really not too much enemies or their variety so yeah, there's that.

Also, there's lots of looting, scavenging and an okay-ish upgrade system (some of which are not present in Non-VR atm)

[h1]Embrace "Combined" Earth[/h1]
The events of the game - is a prequel to HL2 with an amazing twist at the end, though, expectable.
You are Alyx Vance - a rebel who will be dragged in some dramatic events pretty soon after start of the game. 
You will meet a couple of new characters, destroy a lot of property, explore some weird places and shoot a bunch of angry soldiers. At the end - well, there's a lot.
Expect lots of easter eggs and nostalgia emotions.
Soundtrack is...eh, its forgettable, in comparison to HL2+Episodes music. While the sound design is pretty great.
Level design is awesome, lots of things to mess around with (like the famous piano, pool table, touching everything you see)
Dialogues between Alyx and Russel (her partner-in-crime so to speak) are pretty cute and occasionally funny
And as for replay factor - only if you wanna hang around the whole game with the Damn Gnome. Or wanna play Fan Addons.

[h1]NoVR shenanigans[/h1]
The installation is easier than easy, they made it automatic this time.
Controls are decent, although you will occasionally noclip because the button is pretty near to Use Inventory buttons
Alyx will clip through some of the objects (will be fixed in next update)
Animations of the guns is whack (will be updated)
Enemies hit hard and you will fly through the whole room from time to time 
Some puzzles are already solved or require only one push of a button (will be updated)
Upgrades are pretty buggy and there's not too many of them atm (dont know about that one)
Final battle is too easy because of the workaround
Props will meddle with your movement a lot.
Currently 8 achivos are broken because of the scripts that rely on Alyx's Hands THAT DO NOT EXIST in the mod.
And some story scripts are broken and can be skipped completely  (giant hatch after Jeff moment for example)

Can you beat the game without Noclip though? - yes
Are there any critical bugs that made game unbeatable? - no.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
Really good idea to add this to your collection if you are a Half-Life fan or if you have a VR set
You might wanna think twice (or thrice) otherwise since NoVR is Not Perfect.

Wow...

In my other reviews for Half-Life titles, I point out that having a PC without Half-Life is like having an Xbox without a Halo game or a nintendo console without a Mario game. This extends to VR and this game, and then some.

This is indeed the next Half-Life fans have been waiting for over a decade. It's great and not so great at the same time that it's VR exclusive. Great, because the experience cannot be the same in non-VR. Not so great, because not that many people can actually play it.
 

Also it has a pretty terrifying horror section, that doesn't even need to be in VR to be terrifying. Ravenholm is gonna be a trip through disneyland after this. 

And good lord, that ending... [spoiler] Another Half-Life, another cliffhanger [/spoiler], well, here's to another decade and a half.

I do have some criticisms though. There's never a shortage of pistol ammo and almost always a shortage of shotgun ammo. Everything else other than ammo and resin there are only 2 inventory slots.
Now I did play on normal difficulty, but there was really no sense of dread due to overabundance of pistol ammo and health items. Toning down with the combine soldier's health for normal difficulty sounds way better in my opinion. You wouldn't need so much pistol ammo if they didn't take 7 shots to the head to kill.

Also, why does the flashlight have to work only when it decides to? There's plenty of dark areas where it would've been useful, but it only works automatically in certain parts. I realize VR controllers have limited buttons for such things, but having it as a headlamp, for example, and having to press trigger near your forehead would've made its use much more pleasant.

I also have mixed feelings about the changes to enemy design. I understand they're for gameplay purposes, but in some cases, it's almost at the complete cost of consistency. 
Some creatures have new traits that weren't seen in events before and after this game's events, with no explanation whatsoever.

I will add more to this if I notice more issues.

That aside though, after 13 years, Valve can rest assured that this one was definitely worth the wait. I don't know how many reviews the devs read, but if this was one of them, I hope you take the criticism into consideration when making the next title.

Everytime I review any Half life game, i feel the need to say that I am a gen z so I don't have much nostalgia for older games so in other words I was sort of going into this game blind. Knowing part of the lore to understand who the characters were, but not enough about how the world works (combine, head crabs, ant lions, etc). 

But it was immersive. from physics, graphics, dialogue, characters, environment (so beautiful), and SO MUCH MORE. Its just so charming and the fact that it went from a pretty decent 1998 game with basic physics to being INSIDE the world of half Life, the enemies like the combine were TERRIFYING looking around a corner only to see a tank with a shotgun, and being with low ammo, it really makes you forget that youre in vr, the guns feel so good. 

But the best part is that not every situation you're put in can be solved with a gun, sometimes you need to be stealthy because the enemy you're facing is too dangerous to fight or there are too many that challenging them would be too risky. and exploring other places are encouraged cause sometimes you can be rewarded with loot like resin or ammo. Sometimes you  can see people talk to each other and it geniunley feels like those were real people, cause theiur dialogue gives them so much character. 

Thats not even close to describing how scary the atmosphere and places can be in Half life Alyx, from head crabs in cages, rooms full of dead bodies (who knows maybe one of them arent dead), 

if you have the money and the power (for pc graphics) get this game. I recommend it as  a person who has played half life both 1,2 and now Alyx.

Overall obviously a good game...

But plagued by a host of minor issue that turn it into a fairly tedious experience. It's very arcade-y: stay on the rails and do what you're expected inside your playpen and no one gets hurt. I spent the first hour just wrestling with the controls and keybinds, confused about the lack of obvious actions such as jumping, sprinting, turning the flashlight on/off(that one came a little later, but fits into the same vein of confusion), and trying to get the game to accept my preferred VR controls with my irl muscle memory for gun handling. Similarly, the amount of items you manage is very obviously and obtrusively managed for you. Every time the game reminds me that the "backpack is ONLY for resin and full magazines" I can't help but think of that joke about women's clothes having no pockets. Honestly I'd switch out storing resins for the ability to store items in the backpack since the upgrade system was kind of lackluster.

I understand that it was likely to facilitate optimal flow for players, ensuring that they don't need to worry about resources because those will spawn appropriately as you need them outside of combat, so that they can simply enjoy the game... But when a good third of said game is about rummaging through every drawer, shoebox, basket, and fridge with the physics-engine-enabled trash panda experience, that seems REALLY counter to the game's core design. I definitely spent more painstakingly moving my hoard of valuables from one area to the next than actually fighting and needing those items. Not because I really needed all those heals or booms, but because hoarding them is its own reward. I was also immensely disappointed when the keycards were single-use and offered no secrets later down the line when I opted to keep them past their obvious uses. And when I would find an obvious "no coming back up that"-ledge I would run back to my cache of goodies to ensure nothing would be left behind, and in a few cases even ended up reloading an earlier save because the level-load areas came unexpectedly in plain rooms...

Going back to resins, I found most of the upgrades relatively useless and ended up saving before each to really think about whether I wanted to keep some new obtrusive feature on my guns, and to listen to the banter before moving on without them. For example the tactical sights were a distraction and annoyance over the plain iron sights, and I mostly ended up using it as a Dragonball Scouter over my eye to sweep rooms quickly. Instead of weapon-specific upgrades, I think it would have made more sense for the upgrades to be like Aftermarket parts irl; things you can freely put and remove from a gun (at the upgrade stations), switching around which part is on which gun to suit your need, with perhaps the ammo upgrades being the only truly gun specific ones, This way you could print as few or as many as you wanted of say, a laser or tactical sight, rather than having to buy it (at different costs, too???) for each gun to try out. It's a shame because the resin hunting itself is quite enjoyable and I ended up doing more for its own sake than because of the supposed benefits. 

Going back to how arcade-y the game is, I was continually startled by my entire field of vision turning orange from going out-of-bounds whenever I leaned a little too far back against a wall while doing CQB sweeps, how clunky the smooth movement was, and how "sticky" the physics interactions felt. My hands would seem to get stuck in drawers and doors, under and behind at un-intuitive angles. In combat the dissonance between "geriatric shuffle" and "instant point-to-point teleport" made for rather strange pacing and made turtling down my preferred tactic, especially as my hitbox seemed much larger than it should be given my careful management of angles and silhouette. And once it came time to defuse mines I actually ended up having to revert gun-hand settings to default once. Between the aforementioned orange vision issue, Alyx's badonkadonk dump truck ass pushing open a door and triggering a tripmine, and the my VR set-ups angles of coverage for hand tracking, it was impossible to defuse that one mine hidden behind the half-open door, ruining an otherwise very clever part of the game I was initially delighted to spot.

The way handedness also annoyed me, since I would have liked being able to switch hands when clearing corners, making use of my relative ambidexterity, or having the option to place the flashlight on my gun hand, along with the lack of ability to adjust the virtual hands alignment, as the handle of my oculus controls do not match the gun, throwing off my intuitive aim (which I eventually fixed IRL by 3d printing a gun handle for my controller, somewhat fittingly for the game's resin upgrade system).

Annoyingly, the game is also apparently considered a masterpiece, so the modding scene seems very reluctant to modify the game mechanically the same way say Skyrim VR's modders do. Say what you will about Bethesda, but their incompetence, laziness, and greed make their games better by virtue of irreverent modders than they could ever actually do themselves.

Still very enjoyable, though.

The game finally picks up, throws tons of enemies at you with cool set pieces, and then it just ends. The mid-section is just meandering about, sifting through garbage, and occasionally being more mechanically advanced than a rail shooter.

I mean it has some advancements over the prior HL titles. Enemies are a bit more reactive when shot at as opposed to barely flinching in like HL1/2 despite being mag dumped with submachine gun. It’s cool they managed to get on par with Doom 1 in terms of how the shooting feels. But this game is never really demanding to the player in combat, you can hold a corner and solo the entire game with your Colt .45. The shotgun and plasma gun feel situational. Two of the only three guns in the game don’t feel particularly useful. The enemy AI is persistently less aggressive in comparison with HL2. 

You’re just rummaging about in industrial areas and places taken over by some xeno-infestation. Doing some boring ass puzzle solving. A fungus infected guy named ‘Jeff’ stood out as a highlight. But if you played any prior game with stealth segments and a shift in tone to horror, you know this game was outplayed and done by them. Thief Gold, Thief: Deadly Shadows, and TLOU come to mind.

Ya remember Boneworks? Supposedly, the devs were proposing a new HL title. What if they had a budget and they worked on HL: Alyx instead with Valve’s input? It would probably have been a better game.

This game carries itself on novelty. That novelty being the first AAA VR game done by competent devs. But afterwards, it just felt like you consumed air. It’s bewildering this game is held on a pedestal. It is because all the other VR games are boring hogshit tech demos that never go anywhere? I’d say yes.

When Star Trek: The Next Generation aired, 30+ years ago, when I saw that first episode, I knew that my dream was to have a holodeck once. It's been 30 years now and this is about as close to a proper 'holodeck' experience as you can get with consumer grade technology. 

This game changed the way I approach gaming in general. It was why I wanted to save a year for a good VR headset. I played this on the Vive Pro using Index controllers and I loved every minute of it. The first play through is an experience I'll never forget. It was also the first VR game I ever played and to be introduced to VR in this manner is one of the best experiences in terms of 'gaming' you can get. It was very scary at times.. but I never felt that it was overwhelming or impossible. You are given the tools to survive and the game guides you through the experience in a somewhat interactive manner. 

There are many reasons to replay this title over and over again, first for the story, then for the visuals and surroundings, then for the interaction and the collectibles, then to platinum all achievements, all of which are worth it.. (even the gnome one).. Then you can explore the workshop items for it --some of which are gems--. 

If you can afford it, or already have a headset and use it for gaming other than sims/flying/race exclusively, then you should definitely experience this 'holodeck' for yourself.
