Half-Life: Alyx is more than just a game - it's an innovative, immersive journey that dramatically reshapes the landscape of virtual reality gaming. As my first serious foray into the VR realm, I found it to be the most refreshing and original gaming experience I've encountered since Half-Life 2 in 2005 and World of Warcraft in 2007.

Stepping into City 17 in VR is a breathtaking experience, offering a sense of immersion that truly makes the player feel a part of this dystopian universe. The lovingly detailed environments and the realistic physics interactions make the world come alive like never before.

One of the core strengths of Half-Life: Alyx is its seamless marriage of the familiar and the new. The game embraces the beloved elements that have come to define the Half-Life series - the menacing headcrabs, the shambling zombies, the relentless Combine soldiers, and the iconic arsenal of weapons are all faithfully represented in their VR incarnations.

However, it's the introduction of new mechanics - specifically designed to take full advantage of the VR platform - that truly propels this game into uncharted territory. Whether it's the intuitive gravity gloves that allow you to manipulate objects with a flick of your wrist or the innovative ways to interact with the environment, these mechanics open up exciting possibilities that evolve and expand all the way to the game's thrilling finale.

Alyx also offers a compelling extension to the Half-Life lore. As a prequel to Half-Life 2, the story is richly layered and is sure to pique the interest of series veterans and newcomers alike. It pushes me to revisit the previous episodes to piece together the intricate narrative tapestry that Valve has so masterfully woven.

The game also brings a whole new level of physicality to the Half-Life experience. Crouching in your room, using in-game objects for cover while evading Combine fire is a wholly unique experience that no traditional keyboard and mouse setup can replicate. It's both hilarious and intense, as the VR environment drives an unmatched level of player engagement.

Half-Life: Alyx is an exceptional addition to the Half-Life series, that utilizes VR to its fullest potential, improving on an already brilliant formula in groundbreaking ways.

Lastly, I would like to say that while I managed to snag this game at a 50% discount, it is undeniably worth every penny of the full price. If you're on the fence about making the purchase - don't waste your time on waiting. Valve has once again raised the bar in the realm of gaming, proving that they still possess the magic touch. Half-Life: Alyx is a must-have for any VR gamer.

Half-Life: Alyx is a groundbreaking and awe-inspiring virtual reality (VR) game that pushes the boundaries of immersive storytelling, game-play, and technological achievement. Developed by Valve Corporation, this long-awaited addition to the Half-Life franchise delivers an unforgettable experience that showcases the incredible potential of VR gaming.

One of the standout features of Half-Life: Alyx is its captivating and well-crafted narrative. Set between the events of Half-Life and Half-Life 2, players assume the role of Alyx Vance, a key character from the series, as she fights against the oppressive Combine forces in City 17. The story unfolds through a series of immersive encounters, intense combat situations, and thought-provoking puzzles. The writing is superb, with engaging dialogue, memorable characters, and surprising plot twists that keep players invested in the unfolding events. The game seamlessly blends storytelling and game-play, creating a truly immersive and unforgettable narrative experience.

The game-play in Half-Life: Alyx sets a new standard for VR gaming. Every interaction feels intuitive and natural, thanks to the meticulously designed mechanics and precise controls. From physically manipulating objects to solving intricate puzzles, the game takes full advantage of VR technology to immerse players in its world. The combat is intense and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and tools at your disposal. The need to physically dodge, duck, and take cover adds a heightened level of immersion and intensity to the combat encounters. The level design is exceptional, offering a mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense action sequences that keep players engaged and on their toes.

Visually, Half-Life: Alyx is a technical marvel. The game boasts stunning graphics, detailed environments, and impressive attention to detail. From the decaying urban landscapes to the alien-infested areas, each setting feels richly realized and contributes to the game's immersive atmosphere. The lighting effects, particle systems, and realistic physics simulations further enhance the visual fidelity, creating a world that feels alive and reactive to player actions.

The audio design in Half-Life: Alyx is exceptional, adding another layer of immersion to the experience. The sound effects are incredibly detailed, capturing the subtle nuances of environmental interactions and combat encounters. The spatial audio enhances the sense of presence and realism, allowing players to accurately pinpoint the direction of sounds in the game world. The voice acting is superb, with the performances of the cast bringing the characters to life and adding depth to the storytelling.

One of the most impressive aspects of Half-Life: Alyx is its ability to deliver a sense of presence and immersion that only VR can provide. The game makes excellent use of VR technology to create a truly interactive and lifelike experience. From physically reaching out to grab objects to leaning around corners to peek at enemies, every action feels tangible and responsive. The sense of scale and presence in the virtual world is astonishing, making players feel like they have truly stepped into the Half-Life universe.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Alyx is a masterpiece of virtual reality gaming. Its compelling narrative, immersive game-play, stunning visuals, and exceptional use of VR technology combine to create an experience that is both groundbreaking and unforgettable. Valve has demonstrated the immense potential of VR gaming through this title, showcasing the power of the medium to deliver unprecedented levels of immersion and engagement. Whether you're a fan of the Half-Life series or simply looking for a transformative VR experience, Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute must-play that sets a new standard for what VR gaming can achieve. Prepare to be transported to a world where you'll fight for survival, uncover mysteries, and experience gaming like never before.

A must-play if you own VR. Easily the best VR game on the market, not even close. 
There are several VR games that focus on interesting mechanics but overused gameplay or simple gimmicks, or have one trick that's hella fun but only that one trick, or they feel great to play but lack in character, story, etc. But with VR being still a relatively new market, it's hard to come across something with all of those. It's a bit too early for premium quality triple-A games to be in the immersive virtual world.

To that idea Valve said "f*ck you, here's a game with as much quality as any other big release console or PC game, crafted to take full advantage of virtual reality."
Not only is this a game that continues the story of Half-Life and finally gives us some new content after 13 long years, but it also, yknow, has a story. It has a gripping, super cool plot and fun characters throughout, with the Valve quality we've come to love. Dialogue is funny, animations are so damn realistic and graphics are so phenomenally appealing they make you actually feel like you're in City 17 in your headset, and music is all fantastic.
And that's just setting the scene. The gameplay... OH BOY THE GAMEPLAY.
Valve keeps their crown for being second to none in creativity. They are the most innovative and crafty studio in the world, and that reflects beautifully in this game. There is shooting, yoinking physics objects with your specialized Gravity Gloves, and creative puzzles with objects and wires with Alyx's handy Multi-Tool. And you bet your ass they thought of taking advantage of the hardware they made this game for too. You'll be ducking behind cover, twisting and turning through levels, and moving all around in the shoes of the Eli Vance's daughter. The game is only about 12-15 hours long, and is worth every second and every cent. God dammit Valve, you did it again. You made a masterpiece.

tl;dr, the best vr game that exists as of now imo, and the highest quality, polished, and standalone amazing VR game that exists as of now objectively. 10/10 absolutely recommend.

Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute game-changer in the realm of VR gaming. This highly anticipated title from Valve is a masterclass in immersive storytelling, innovative gameplay, and breathtaking visuals.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Alyx Vance, you're transported to the dystopian world of City 17 like never before. The attention to detail is mind-blowing, with every nook and cranny meticulously designed. The graphics are stunning, pushing the limits of what VR can achieve, and the level of immersion is unparalleled. Exploring the meticulously crafted environments, interacting with objects, and solving puzzles feels incredibly natural and satisfying.

The gameplay itself is a perfect blend of action, exploration, and puzzle-solving. The combat mechanics are superb, utilizing VR technology to its fullest potential. The ability to physically duck behind cover, aim and shoot with precision, and wield a variety of weapons feels incredibly intuitive and immersive. The encounters with enemies, especially the terrifying headcrabs, will keep you on your toes and your heart racing.

What sets Half-Life: Alyx apart is its captivating narrative. The story is a prequel to the events of Half-Life 2, and it weaves seamlessly into the existing lore of the series. The characters are well-developed, and Alyx Vance takes center stage as a compelling protagonist. The voice acting is top-notch, and the dialogue is engaging, adding depth and emotional resonance to the overall experience.

One minor downside is that the game's length may leave some craving more. While the campaign offers a solid 15 to 20 hours of gameplay, dedicated players might finish it quicker. However, the replayability factor is high, thanks to collectibles, hidden areas, and the desire to experience the game's world again.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Alyx is a monumental achievement in VR gaming. It raises the bar for what can be accomplished in virtual reality, delivering a captivating story, intuitive gameplay, and breathtaking visuals. Valve has once again demonstrated their mastery of game design, creating an experience that is both thrilling and unforgettable. Whether you're a fan of the Half-Life series or a VR enthusiast, this game is an absolute must-play that will leave you in awe of its immersive world and innovative gameplay mechanics.

I just finished this game, putting it off for years so I didn't ruin other VR games for myself. Half Life Alyx has made every other VR game feel half baked, it's really set the golden standard for what a VR game should have: immersion, story, fun gameplay mechanics, all coupled together with great visuals and humor. Whenever Valve does release a game, it changes the gaming community in some way, such as how Half Life 2 pioneered physics in gaming. Half Life Alyx's port over to virtual reality is an amazing step in the right direction from Valve, and I honestly hope going forward that this will be Valve's new standard going forward: virtual reality. It adds such a unique flavor that can't be achieved in flat screen gaming. There were moments in HLA where I was terrified just with how immersive the experience was. I desperately await Valve's new VR  titles, if they're even half as good as HLA, it'll be an amazing experience (fingers are crossed for Left 4 Dead 3, Portal 3, Team Fortress 3 all in VR)!

Half-Life: Alyx is the single greatest VR title out, even now in 2023. This is the premier title that shows exactly what VR is capable of and how every VR game should play. I played through the whole game on the OG Vive on a 1070 and i7 6700 at 90hz and it was great. Now with a new build and an index headset + knuckles controllers, the game at 120hz feels brand new.

It sounds trite to say that the audio is a major part of a game but in HL:A, the sound design and music and positional audio really take you into the world. Even in spots where I knew there were going to be sudden enemies I was still startled due to how good the audio is and how good the level design is.

MILD SPOILERS AHEAD: The story follows Alyx on a quest to save her father after the combine kidnap him. There are a small handful of other characters and they all feel like they fit in and belong there. The game does have some jumpscare parts and one scary sneaking section but they are tastefully done and they teach you about safe navigation through the world and add to the immersion. I am startled easily and I was still able to enjoy the whole experience.

There are a handful of weapons in the game that fill their respective roles well. Reloading weapons is "realistic" enough to make you feel powerful but also "arcady" enough to not get in the way of the flow of combat. Upgrades are not mandatory but they add variety to the gunplay and there are a few QoL upgrades too (optics, bigger magazines, alt-fire modes, etc.). Make sure you are searching under every box and behind every half-wall for the upgrade material.

If you have a VR headset and don't have this game, you are majorly missing out. My hope is that Valve makes more VR games because HL:A alone makes the investment worth it. After finishing it once, I recommend playing through again with the developer commentary. 

Tips: 
0. If you are having a "mongoose timeout" error, add "-novid" (without the quote marks) to the launch properties. It will just skip the Valve into video with the bald guy with the valve in his head and has no effect on the rest of the game.

1. If you are startled easily or get too immersed, I recommend lowering the sound and use off-ear audio. You still get immersed but have a little more grounding to reality.

2. Even on the hardest difficulty, the game provides enough healing items and ammo to get the job done if you are paying attention. If you want to make it extra hard, try throwing away some ammo or healing items. You can also try to limit yourself to using only one of the two available "pouches" to store a healing item or grenade (or use neither for even more challenge).

3. Don't forget to check out the workshop for a small but high quality collection fan-made mods and new levels and some totally different stories!

I cannot express just how much I enjoy this game, I have completed the main story twice and specific chapters multiple times. It's actually very unfortunate how good this game is as it just sets the bar for what a VR game could be SO high, nothing I have played since has come anywhere even close to this, it's not nostalgia for the 'Half-Life' franchise either as this is the first game played from the series, in fact after playing this I decided to purchase half life 2 and try the community made VR mod within that game.

Playtime:
I am actually not sure how long it took me to complete the game, as mentioned before I have completed it all the way through twice and played a couple of the Community made maps with their story and am only just over 20 hours. I never felt that the game dragged on, I was actually quite upset when I completed it the first time round because I got so invested in it.

The Story:
Easy to understand, has very likeable characters even to someone who has no knowledge of the Half-Life lore.
Although avoiding any spoilers I will say that I found the ending quite upsetting, I feel like It should have had a rock solid ending that cleared up all my questions and concerns but instead I found the ending rather sour, leaving me even more confused. 

Gameplay:
Very, very controlled, basically just keep moving forward, once you have moved on from an area you cannot go back unless you reload the previous chapter, for some players this may be too controlling but for me it was perfectly fine.

Map Design:
At a certain point I did start getting a little irritated about the large amount of time you spend underground and in subway tunnels rather then seeing the graphically impressive outside world, after playing a little more though and getting more into the combat I realised it did make sense for the developers to (and this is of course all a guess) make it more playable on lower end hardware and focus the player more on the gameplay.

The Graphics:
As mentioned before, the game looks incredible even on the lower end headset display that I used, the Meta Quest 2, even with that headset though, I was in shock the whole time, It's actually quite hard to compare it to any other games (both VR and Non-VR) that I have played, The best way to see what it's like is to just watch some gameplay or the trailers online.

Community Features:
There are tons of hours to be spent in Half-Life Alyx, not only in the main story but with all of the community made maps and custom campaigns. Even if you don't want to dive into a new story at all there are still loads of things you can customise like custom Resin Models and Weapon remakes from the old Half-life games.

The Price: 
Whilst a little pricey, I would highly recommend grabbing it.

10/10 Overall

[*][h1]About[/h1]
[/list]
Does it need further introduction? Ok I get it... you may have not been around long enough to experience true classics due being busy playing fortnite. While i'm sure everyone is/was waiting for Half Life 3 (but got this instead) is a bit disappointed... I am here to tell you that... it did not (despite still high hopes and dreams for HL3). This story is set years before HL2 where you play Alyx Vance and as usual will need to put a stop to those meddling combine aliens. While VR may not be for everyone, this is likely, despite being released 3 years ago, still one of the best VR titles in the space for its genre, which is sad to an extent... but shows VR capabilities (if companies are willing to throw a butload of money at it).

[list]
[*][h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[/list]
As any Half Life game to date... this one has it all... exploration, combat, puzzles, story... and even the occasional jump scare.
Personally one of the most satisfying things in VR is the level of interaction with the environment and this game took it a step further where i can interact with the most random and useless things that have zero contribution to the actual game. 
The physics in this game are simply amazing. To illustrate... when you fire your pistol... not only you can clearly see the bullet case jumping from the gun... but that same bullet case is actually interactable to the point that if it hits a movable object in its trajectory (e.g. a soda can...) it will throw it down. If that isn't mind-blowing...
The AI is fairly smart in combat/events and one of the best things i found is that you actually need to manage your ammo since you don't necessarily have a crowbar to help you :)

[list]
[*][h1]Graphics[/h1]
[/list]
The best graphical detail (to date) I ever saw in a VR game. It is also the heaviest game where even a beefy computer will struggle if you max out everything but worry not as I personally played on medium settings and everything was equally amazing since for the level of quality experienced this game seems to have been extremely optimized.

[list]
[*][h1]Length | Replayability[/h1]
[/list]
You can expect to take anywhere from 12 to 18 hours on the main story depending on how much time you spend gazing at how amazing this game is and trying to investigate every corner of every area. On top of that there is a substantial amount of mods available, with new maps, weapons, enemies and more, developed by the community that are also amazing and provide further hours of gameplay.

[list]
[*][h1]Worth Buying?[/h1]
[/list]
Not only worth but mandatory if you enjoy VR as this game sets the bar for what is possible. The price without any discount is in my view worth it, especially when comparing with other titles that are no where near but charge top dollar, however if you are not in a rush, it goes on discount every now and then

Half-Life: Alyx does not push the medium of virtual reality to its limits by any means. But the execution of the game is where it truly shines. Game mechanics refined to a point of near perfection, this game is a shining example of what Triple A game quality should look like in VR. The detail of the headcrab's claws and belly create a truly immersive atmosphere, as well as the textures. It was almost as if I could get a feel for the game by looking at it. The softness of the headcrabs, the smooth surface of the Combine's mask, the rough, tough nature of the walls, it all screams immersiveness. Although sound design is often overlooked, Alyx takes account of echo and ambience to deliver a truly immersive experience. As a VR game, it plays it safe, but manages to surprise, please, and wow the player in many ways. It is truly the pinnacle of virtual reality experiences. Walking down a dynamite filled hall to grab a valve, the ambience and growling of headcrab zombies being all you hear through the earth-shattering quiet, Alyx manages to immerse the player in a way most VR games never succeed to do. When people tell you how VR is amazing, THIS is what they are talking about. As a Half-Life game, it has nice bits of lore, top-notch story (for a prequel anyways), and a good quality you expect from Valve. However, as a fairly experienced VR player, the game felt a little campy in some aspects. Valve knew this would be many peoples first foray into virtual reality, launching alongside the Index. However, four hours in, I have not died yet. This isn't truly a criticism and more of an observation though, as I never thought the game felt "too easy", only in comparison to other Half-Life games. Other than that bit, Alyx is a state of the art VR game that Meta and Sony should take note of. Truly a masterpiece of its medium.

I had so many issues getting this game to run without crashes, glitches, computer locks, stuttering and what ever other problem known to mankind. And this is the only VR game I've played so far that had this many issues. I use a HP Reverb G2 on a RTX 3070 with I7-12700K and 48GB RAM.

Long story short, i googled for a week and i browsed the steam forums for any clue on how to make it better. And after a week of trial and error and testing everything in human knowledge, i finally got the game to run stable and without any crashes.

And what i have to say about this game is that it's definitively a worthy installment in the Half-Life franchise. I spent hundreds of hours playing the first Half-Life with every story expansion and multiplayer, and Half-Life 2 the same way, and i consider those games to be among the top 3 games I've ever played.

Looking past the issues i had with Alyx to begin with, when it works, it's not only a fantastic game at it's core, it's also a showcase on how to do VR correctly, Valve just set's the bar with this game, a bar for which every one else will struggle to match, let alone surpass.

I might just have been extremely unlucky with my headset and setup, i don't know. The main thing that fixed my problems was to change from Direct3D 11 to Vulkan API. So i don't count my technical issues into my review, they were annoying beyond belief, but the game redeemed itself once it was working.

Still probably THE title to play if you're curious about the potential of VR in gaming. The sheer quantity of content, and the care that went into preserving the Half Life cannon are staggering.

- disappearing items, 
- collision errors,

- backpack only holds resin and ammo (probably infinite at that), but not any health recharger syringes, grenades, or mission items

There is some trickery going on in the background with automatically scaling graphics settings and performance that makes some youtubers and articles say to set it to ultra even on potato computers and others saying to set to low even on NASA machines... I am a 62 y.o. retired male, definitely one of the more mature people who've played this game. It was only two years ago during the pandemic when I had lost a patient I was operating on during ER. She was the first one I've lost. At first I only thought of it as "just another respiratory illness" among the multitude of seniors flooding in. But a child no older than my 7 y.o. niece? I pulled everything out of my bag of tricks but there was only so many treatments for advanced pneumonia-like symptoms. They said hundreds of thousands are dying all around the world, but for me, a child is a child. A life is a life. Did I choose the wrong profession? Am i betraying God's will by trying to save those who shan't be saved? Was my oath taken in pride and vanity. I had to leave, hoping if fate lures me back I'd reconsider it then.

Retirement was as expected: someone who's been working his ass off his entire life rarely has time for personal endeavors. And with the pandemic, inability to travel. My friends and colleagues thought I was crazy not to be living it up and doing everything I wanted to do now that I'm out of the grind. My take: I'm such a pathetic wretch, I don't even have one single hobby. A confidant recommended I check out the tech industry, starting with VR (as it was also making the medical rounds). Enter Half-Life: Alyx. Wow, while I was cutting up bodies the nerds were busy cutting up circuits. The visuals in VR are simply stunning. Sure this dystopian sci-fi setting was not mellowing out the lockdown mood but the writing was more intriguing than most Hollywood scripts. Every dead body I passed by reminded me of the collateral casualties of recent times; I proceeded uneasily. But the last straw: I had to jab myself with the medical syringe...the flashback was like someone woke you up from a dream with a pail of cold water. Natalie? Was that her name? I shut off everything right then and there.

A few months passed and I tried out a few more hobbies, one more intense than the other: mountain biking, sportsbike track days; yes, things more suited for those 30 years junior but concentration or death kept recent events off my mind. Recently, the FB metaverse in the news reminded me of VR and this game. Although I dreaded having to open drawers and doors like an OCD person, I jumped back into the rabbit hole. Maybe enough time had passed, but I think hearing Alyx's voice helped me push through to completion this time. I can't credit this game enough for helping me through the unknowing guilt, but I felt a tremendous weight lifted off my shoulder and am at peace. This game is a life saver, and will never be uninstalled.

The overall story of Half-Life: Alyx is amazing. It takes place between Half-Life and Half-Life 2. They added new aliens, guns, equipment, concepts, etc. which keeps it fresh. There, of course, are tons of puzzles you have to navigate to advance further. The dialog from all of the characters, including Alyx, is FUNNY! I catch myself chuckling at the sarcasm and commentary from Russell a lot throughout the game. And it's interesting hearing Alyx make comments or ask questions about life before the seven hour war- also something we're not used to because we never heard Gordon speak. Something I really like about the series is you're learning everything as Gordon/Alyx is learning. There's no cutting to story or really any elaboration beforehand. Obviously we have context from the previous games for Half-Life: Alyx, but I really like that they continued doing that. The game is beautiful! The attention to detail is insane! As I'm defeating enemies, I often have to take an extra look around to make sure I didn't miss any ammo or resin. And being able to upgrade your firearms??? SUCH a cool feature! Special shout out to Jeff, as he's absolutely terrifying! They did a great job making you feel like you're really there. To the few jump scares, size of enemies and even being able to feel your heart beat in the controllers when you're low on health, you're totally immersed. I am more than satisfied with this game. I'll probably play it a few more times and try to get all of the achievements. Highly recommend to Half-Life fans or not. It really is just that good!

Half Life Alyx is probably the only VR title out there (that I’ve played) that deserves a perfect 10. 

Is it the most replayable VR game out there? Ehh not really.. There are some insanely top quality mods on the workshop that are must play in my opinion (Gunman contracts, return to rapture, etc.)  but it’s really a one maybe two playthrough kind of game. But that playthrough is fantastic, the story is an absolute masterclass as to be expected from Valve, the immersion and interactivity with the world and objects found within is great, and the music/sound design is really top notch. 

As an added bonus Half Life Alyx is one of like 2 VR games to make me genuinely scared. Not by cheesy gimmick or jumpscare but just genuine immersive horror. Also the gnome achievement is super surreal to complete in VR. 

If I had to give one negative about the game it would be the lack of melee combat since there is really something to be said about being able to physically beat the s*** out of enemies, but admittedly, it probably wouldn’t fit this game very well given the layout of combat encounters. 

Perfect 10 since it’s the only VR title that I’ve played that feels like a “real” AAA game.

You see I liked it, but I *do* have some problems with this game. My review will explain. 
Half Life Alyx has a great story, great gameplay (Tho, a bit easy). There are a multiple movement modes for comfort and preference, but regular walking (No blink, no teleport) is not great since it's slow and there is no sprint. 
Half Life Alyx is great to me, as I never experienced Half Life 2 "Change Gaming". But I got to experience that partially with Alyx. I say 'partially' for the reason that Alyx just isn't accessible. Half Life Alyx is better than Boneworks, but it is still a tech demo in a way. Let me say, it never ever felt like a tech demo (Because of incredible gameplay, story, characters, and scenery). 
But you can tell this game is best played with the Index, with how good the game looks and since it was meant to be paired with the index. 
Good Scenery? Index's Resolution.

Well, let me tell you something, my friend. You're talking about Alyx, and yeah, it's true, that game is something else. It's like a shot of pure adrenaline straight to the heart. I mean, you put on that VR headset and suddenly you're transported to a whole other world. It's like stepping into a dream, but a dream that's realer than real.

And let me tell you, as someone who's been around the block a few times, that game is something special. It's like nothing I've ever seen before. It's like the guys who made it took everything that VR can do and turned it up to eleven. It's like they said, "Okay, we're gonna make a VR game, but we're not gonna do it like anyone else has ever done it before. We're gonna blow people's minds."

And you know what? They did. They blew my goddamn mind. That game is so immersive, so intense, that sometimes I forgot I was even in my own living room. I was so caught up in the action, so swept away by the story, that I lost myself completely. And that, my friend, is what gaming is all about. It's about losing yourself in another world, another reality, and feeling like you're really there.

So yeah, you're right. Alyx is significantly better than everything else VR has to offer right now. And I wouldn't be surprised if it stayed that way for a good long while. Those guys who made it are geniuses, and they've set the bar pretty damn high. But you know what? That's okay. Because even if nothing else ever comes close to Alyx, we'll still have that game. We'll still have that feeling of being transported to another world, of being a part of something incredible. And that, my friend, is something truly special.

Is Half Life:Alyx the best game ever made? No.

Is it the best VR game? Probably...

Valve have done it again. The Half Life franchise is basically PC game royalty and Half Life: Alyx keeps up the almost impossible standards of quality that we've come to expect from the series. If you've got a VR headset and haven't played this yet, then why did you bother buying one?!

The Good
-----------
[list]
[*] Really immersive. The atmosphere, the graphics, the controls, the sound, the lighting, the physics - everything comes together to make this the most immersive experience I've had so far in VR. Whenever I came back to Alyx after playing another VR game, it immediately just felt better and far more immersive than anything else out there.
[*] It has a fantastic story that ties in extremely well with the other Half Life games, especially Chapter 2. That ending... Just wow! (Make sure you sit through the credits for the post-credit scene)
[*] Superb voice acting. Russell is new to the series and added some much-needed levity throughout. I believe that the actress who plays Alyx is different from the original but she does such a good job that I wouldn't have noticed if someone else hadn't pointed it out.
[*] The horror bits are great. That section in the lift - aaaargh!! The action bits are great.
[*] The VR game design has been incredibly well thought out. Everything feels natural from picking things up, from reloading the guns, the gravity gloves never get old. It's a joy to play and soon feels really natural.
[*] The enemies are familiar but the game presents them in way that you haven't experienced before; i.e., killing ant lions is definitely done differently from HL2. The "electricity dogs" were my favourite but I'm glad there weren't too many of them!
[*] Fantastic graphics. These are the best I've seen in a PC VR game so far by a long way. Great lighting as well.
[*] The difficult level is pitched to just the right challenge. I died quite a few times and while there are a couple of tough sections I think that most gamers will be able to complete the game.
[*] Excellent performance. Valve have shown that you really can have your cake and eat it when it comes to graphics and performance. I start playing on a Ryzen 2600X / 5700XT set up and had no performance problems on Medium settings, half way through I upgraded to a 13700K / GTX 4080 so got to play with everything set to maximum quality.
[*] The sound effects take you straight back to HL2 and they've extended them to the VR universe brilliantly. Nostalgia done in the perfect way. The soundtrack is pretty decent too.
[*] The puzzles make good use of the environment and VR set-up. The repeated puzzles for opening containers and the upgrade machines gradually increase in difficulty as the game progresses and do not outstay their welcome.
[*] The game is a good length and will take most people 16-20 hours to complete, I think. The chapters are long enough that you can comfortably play one chapter per sitting before VR-fatigue sets in.
[*] Pedantic, but I like that you lose your ammo if you reload too soon. Most games, apart from the serious combat sims, just let you reload all the time, constantly, without any consequences.
[*] No bugs encountered throughout my play through.
[/list]

The Bad
---------
[list]
[*] Movement speed is painfully slow. While I appreciate that this may be done deliberately - certainly at the beginning - to help people orient themselves in the VR environment, it feels daft that you're walking around at a snail pace while involved in a firefight.
[*] No melee fighting, which seems an odd and obvious missed opportunity given how much Half Life is associated with crowbars. While I appreciate that it is Gordon's crowbar, plenty of other things lying around (i.e., wrenches) could be used as melee weapons.
[*] The action scenes are awesome but there aren't too many of them. 2-3 more would have been very welcome.
[*] You will look stupid when someone walks into the room to find you crouching behind a wall that they can't see and shooting blindly over it. Lock the door!
[*] It reminds you just how good Valve are at making games - and frustrates you that they don't make more!
[/list]

Half-Life: Alyx is my first ever VR game. And I think this has set an extremely high benchmark for what I would expect from the VR games I play in the future. From the moment I stepped into the immersive world of City 17, I was blown away by the level of detail, interactivity, and atmosphere that the game had to offer.

The game's attention to detail extends beyond just gameplay mechanics, as every aspect of the environment and sound design work together to create an incredibly immersive experience. As you explore the ruined City 17, you'll be surrounded by incredible sights and sounds that truly transport you to another world. From the eerie silence of abandoned buildings to the cacophony of Combine machinery and the unsettling whispers of headcrabs, the game's sound design is second to none.

The game's visual design is also a marvel to behold, with stunningly detailed environments that are filled with intricate textures, lighting, and particle effects. Whether you're exploring a Xen infested apartment or a Zoo, you'll be constantly amazed by the level of detail and polish that has gone into every aspect of the game's visuals.

But what really sets Half-Life: Alyx apart is its attention to detail. From the physics-based interactions with objects to the way enemies react to your gunfire, every aspect of the game has been meticulously crafted to create an unforgettable experience.

It's simply the best VR game you can play, and I can't recommend it enough.

I started my Half Life: Alyx journey by dual wielding beer bottles. I tipped them down my gullet confused why I couldn't feel the beverage pouring down by throat. Then i froze, "I REALLY hope no one can see me right now". But I was having so much fun I didn't care. 

Such a bizarrely fun experience this VR stuff is.

I wandered the empty streets trying to finger pigeons who foolishly allowed me dangerously close. I had no idea what sort of sadistic arse i'd become immediatly in this digital world, I thought I'd be saving terrified guards from zombies, but no, I was trying to finger dirty pigeons on the street for hours after misbehaving with endless bottles of liquor. What a ****ing gem this game is.

Five minutes into this mind altering experience and i picked up a plastic bottle and held it up to my eye and it just completely blew my mind the level of detail that continued all the way through. I cannot get over how immersive this game is. The shaders, the textures, the lighting. All absolute top notch. 

Peering into that plastic bottle, trying to spin something in the air, or tossing an object and seeing it land exactly where you expected it to with amazing precision. Goofing around in the world it dawned on me: Half Life Alyx isn't just a game, it's the most advanced, incredible toy ever made, and it can even be enjoyed even by jaded, old sob's like me. 

Alyx represents not just years of game development, but years of innovation to interactivity, Head tracking, interface, and graphics by one of the largest most advanced talent pools in human history. If you're new to VR, this experience hits like a ton of bricks with all the competency and innovation that goes into this experience. It's a revelation. The mind wanders wondering if we'll get full on movies and entirely new genres of entertainment now that Valve has shown a small bit of the potential of VR.

I'm not saying this with hyperbole. Half Life Alyx is the pinnacle of technical innovation in all of entertainment up to this day, and as you experience this artful story and setting, you can pick up anything around you and be a total fruit @$$, throwing it at anyone in the world, or make any kind of obscene action you wish in this world without any embarrassment. This is true freedom from all the mundane social niceties as you teabag zombies and toss their bodies about with joy, unless of course someone is watching you make a total fool of yourself with this stupid headset on. 

I kinda felt like Mr. Bean playing this, a total weirdo, devoid of shame, thinking of all manner of ways to interact with the world around me to be a total bafoon for the fun of it all. I haven't encountered a single enemy yet, because I have been carefully walking the rooftops, clay jars in hand, looking for some poor soul to walk by so I can toss it with all my might and try to smash their heads in. Jolly good fun.

Is it worth the pain in the butt setup? Is it worth installing VR, learning the kinks of the interface and finally getting the game running?

A RESOUNDING "yes". 

The game is so good one has to wonder why there isn't more chatter. Perhaps it's that the tech is improving so fast that no one wants to dev for it. Or maybe it's just too expensive for mass adoption. Or the massive investment cost. Or maybe Valve just isn't in bed with the right major companies to get the attention they deserve with this project.

I'm so blown away by the tech and immersion that I haven't even commented on the stellar animation, interactive puzzles, and story interjected within this joyous romp. And frankly, i don't even care to remark on the 10/10 game because the tertiary elements eclipse the core game. I'm going to have to play this again to give the dialogue and story the attention they deserves, because as I'm being told about the danger my (Alyx's) father is in, all i can think about is how cool it is to smash bottles, and pull things towards me and catch them with these perfectly implemented force powers. Holding weapons, reloading them, chambering rounds, using force like powers... it's all so damned rewarding, and as you master this incredibly organic interface system, you start feeling like a real badass, as you make weird motions alone in your living room. Shooting things has so much tangibility, that it's hard to go back to pressing a mouse to fire in other FPS's.

My first review!  Half Life Alyx has officially ruined me for 2D video gaming!  This is what I have been looking for from VR since I bought my Oculus Quest 2 about a year ago.  The way this game takes me back to the original Half Life  and Half Life 2 is nothing short of incredible!  A combination of nostalgia while pushing back the boundaries of VR gaming is nothing short of amazing.

My setup is i7 8700, RTX 3060ti, 16Gb DDR4 3200mhz, Windows 11 on SSD @ read speed 450mb/s, game is on NVME PCIe 3.0 @ read speed 3500mb/s.  Oculus Quest 2 running @ 120 mhz with a latency of around 6ms on a USB 3.2 type c to c 16 ft cable

My average gaming session in this configuration was 1 to 2 hours.  There were some glitches using this setup but I'd say 95% reliable.  Sometimes when I got moving around a lot with the cable it would glitch and crash.  It seems like a little movement at the headset connector would cause it to crash.  I would be playing and my peripheral vision would start to go black with fine lines and the controls would stop responding.  The only solution seemed to be reset the headset.  I ended up solving it by zip tying the cable close to the headset connector securely .  I don't love using the cable but I found gaming for an hour or more it would only use 10 to 20 percent of the headset charge.  I did connect very successfully with Airlink but found it would go from 85% to 30% charge in about 40 minutes.  The headset would then take almost 2 hours to recharge with a 20 watt Anker type c to c charger.  If you don't use your Quest for other things this may not bother you but I found it annoying, however Airlink did work for me with no issues.

before I started playing this game I went through some very helpful tutorials 1) for PC/Quest performance and 2) for Airlink performance.

1) (youtube) 'The Ultimate VR Performance Guide' by AEXLAB
2) (youtube) 'How to play PCVR on Quest 2 in 2023 with Airlink, Virtual Desktop' by VRelity
also (youtube) 'Air Link Setup | Meta Quest 2' by Meta Quest
also (youtube) 'HOW TO PLAY STEAM VR GAMES WIRELESSLY IN MINUTES' by My Tech Gear

Key things for Airlink, turn off your VPN if you have one.  Use a 5G setting on your router.  I'm using a 4 year old Shaw (my ISP) router that has a 2.4Ghz channel and a 5Ghz channel.  I started with the 2.4Ghz channel and had problems but once I switched to the 5Ghz everything ran smooth.  You can also use a USB 3+ type A to type c for a wired connection but understand that it won't charge the headset while you play.  I bought a cheap unbranded type c to c cable off Amazon.ca for $30 (CAD) and it has worked flawlessly for me.  Another tip for the cable is I took 2 small squares of duct tape and close to the PC side I taped the cable to the floor.  When you get flailing around in combat if you pull on the cable the duct tape gives you a bit of a safeguard against ripping it out of the PC.

If there are any negatives for this game and honestly there aren't, I would say that when you reload the pistol, especially in the heat of battle I would bang the 2 controllers together and 50% of the time end up not reloading.  It was frustrating but eventually I did get the hang of things.  The other weird part of the game is when an enemy gets right in your personal space you just seem to die.  There's no close combat and there's no way to really tell what's going on and suddenly you're just dead.  Not really a short coming of the game but more really just VR itself.  There's no haptic feedback to really get a sense of what is going on in this scenario.  You just learn to stay a couple arms length away from enemies.

Thank you Valve,  this game is nothing short of a masterpiece.
